text: On the 18th, we finished the journey by a nine mile march to Bocking, and there settled down
name: Real College Essays

text: into billets for the rest of our time in England. Though we were spoilt at Harpenden, we are
name: Real College Essays

text: sure that all ranks have nothing but pleasant recollections of the time spent at Braintree
name: Real College Essays

text: and Bocking, where one and all treated us with the greatest kindness, and we hope were sorry
name: Real College Essays

text: to lose us. Where all were so kind it is almost invidious to mention names, but one feels (though
name: Real College Essays

text: they themselves would be the first to deny it) that a special debt of gratitude is owed to
name: Real College Essays

text: the Nuns of the Convent at Booking, whose kindness and care for those who were billeted at
name: Real College Essays

text: the Convent, and for all with whom they came in contact, were beyond all praise.
name: Real College Essays

text: In order to prepare for any possible German landing on the Essex coast orders had been issued
name: Real College Essays

text: for a series of trenches to be dug to form defensive lines for the protection of London, and
name: Real College Essays

text: we were at once set on to this work, which was pushed on as rapidly as possible, systems of
name: Real College Essays

text: trenches, redoubts, gun positions, and other defensive works being put in hand. Our work was
name: Real College Essays

text: mainly at Panfield, Marks Farm and Black Notley. It was not an ideal season for trench digging,
name: Real College Essays

text: especially in the clay of Essex, which was the "genuine" article, and we were glad when the
name: Real College Essays

text: bulk of it was finished by Christmas. This work was carried out under Royal Engineers' supervision
name: Real College Essays

text: and was in some ways instructive, although we thought that the principles we had been taught
name: Real College Essays

text: in the Military Manuals were frequently violated by the siting of trenches along the sides
name: Real College Essays

text: of prominent hedgerows. Nevertheless, what we did was more after the nature of what we were
name: Real College Essays

text: to meet in France, and therefore of considerable practical value. That our work was satisfactory
name: Real College Essays

text: was testified to by the insertion in Central Force Orders of January 23rd, 1915, of the General
name: Real College Essays

text: Officer Commanding-in-Chief's keen appreciation of the soldierly spirit and enthusiasm shewn
name: Real College Essays

text: for the work by all ranks. All the same, we have no regrets that it was never necessary to
name: Real College Essays

text: occupy the trenches for actual warfare.
name: Real College Essays

text: Owing to another scare Christmas leave was cancelled. Scarborough had been bombarded on December
name: Real College Essays

text: 22nd, and there was apparently a bit of a "breeze." According to one writer this was due to
name: Real College Essays

text: a little lack of liaison between our Naval and Military authorities. The former had apparently
name: Real College Essays

text: spread a rumour that an invasion of the German Coast was to take place, and the enemy concentrated
name: Real College Essays

text: numbers of troops there in case it happened. This concentration came to the knowledge of our
name: Real College Essays

text: military spies, who, however were not told of the cause, and their report appears to have caused
name: Real College Essays

text: our War Office to think that an invasion of England was contemplated. We were not, however,
name: Real College Essays

text: by any means dull at Christmas. On December 24th, we beat the 6th Battalion 2--1 in the first
name: Real College Essays

text: round of the Divisional Football competition, Vann being skipper, and in the evening the Warrant
name: Real College Essays

text: Officers and N.C.O.'s had a dance at Braintree Corn Exchange. On Christmas Day there was Church
name: Real College Essays

text: Parade at Braintree, when the Bishop of Derby preached. Later, dinners were issued on a sumptuous
name: Real College Essays

text: scale, and in the evening the Officers were entertained at the White Hart by the Colonel and
name: Real College Essays

text: Major Fowler.
name: Real College Essays

text: In a later round of the Divisional Cup Competition, we beat the Divisional Mechanical Transport
name: Real College Essays

text: Column 3--0, and got into the semi-final, when, however, we were badly beaten by the 4th Leicesters
name: Real College Essays

text: at Bishop's Stortford, by 3 goals to nil. In a Brigade paper chase which was held on December
name: Real College Essays

text: 26th, Pvte. Allen of E Company came in first.
name: Real College Essays

text: On December 28th, we returned to Luton by train to carry out final firing practices at the
name: Real College Essays

text: Wardown and Galley Hill Ranges, and field firing practice at Dunstable in appalling weather,
name: Real College Essays

text: when frost, snow and rain made accurate shooting perfectly impossible, and we were glad indeed
name: Real College Essays

text: to get back to Bocking on January 6th, 1915.
name: Real College Essays

text: The rest of our time was spent in final training, mainly carried out at Gosfield Park and Abbot's
name: Real College Essays

text: Hall, and in preparations for going out, in which the inspection and completion of equipment
name: Real College Essays

text: of all kinds played a prominent part. This was not too easy a job for the young Company or
name: Real College Essays

text: Section Commanders, as the men by this time were up to all the "old soldier" tricks, and were
name: Real College Essays

text: very clever at making one article appear almost simultaneously in half-a-dozen different kits.
name: Real College Essays

text: Drill included a certain amount of new bayonet fighting and other exercises under Major A.
name: Real College Essays

text: C. Clarke, who had attended a course at Chelsea. Mules arrived in January and were objects
name: Real College Essays

text: of much interest; our miscellaneous transport vehicles were discarded and replaced by new ordnance
name: Real College Essays

text: pattern issues, to which were added two Lune Valley Cookers, kindly presented by the ladies
name: Real College Essays

text: of Nottinghamshire. At the end of January the Battalion had to be completely reorganised in
name: Real College Essays

text: order to come into line with the regular Battalions: the old 8-Company system was abolished,
name: Real College Essays

text: and the 1914 Double Company organisation introduced, entailing an immense amount of work and
name: Real College Essays

text: keeping us busy right up to the time of our departure. The situation was not helped by the
name: Real College Essays

text: absence of Major Fowler with eight Subalterns and 407 recruits, who were away carrying out
name: Real College Essays

text: musketry classification practices at Luton from February 3rd to 20th.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our chief relaxation at Bocking in the early part of 1915 was night searching for elusive spies,
name: Real College Essays

text: who were supposed to carry on lamp signalling; more often than not when these were tracked
name: Real College Essays

text: down they turned out to be innocent stable guards doing their nightly rounds. At other times
name: Real College Essays

text: we picketed the roads to hold up motor cars which were supposed to be acting as guides to Zeppelins,
name: Real College Essays

text: but it is doubtful whether either of these occupations did a great deal towards bringing about
name: Real College Essays

text: the more rapid conclusion of the war.
name: Real College Essays

text: One also remembers the excitement caused by the first Boche aeroplane dropping bombs within
name: Real College Essays

text: a mile of the village, which we, of course, imagined had been dropped for our especial benefit.
name: Real College Essays

text: One of the Scouts secured a "dud," which was the object of much interest to everyone, up to
name: Real College Essays

text: the Divisional Commander.
name: Real College Essays

text: It was about this time that the first distinguishing patches were allotted to Battalions. Our
name: Real College Essays

text: first was a square green patch worn behind the cap badge, undoubtedly very smart, and the envy
name: Real College Essays

text: of the other Battalions in the Brigade. When we got to France the Officers of the Battalion
name: Real College Essays

text: had to wear two short vertical green stripes at the top of the back of the jacket, to enable
name: Real College Essays

text: them to be picked out from behind, as all ranks were more or less similarly dressed and Officers'
name: Real College Essays

text: swords were discarded. Later still these marks were worn by all ranks in the Battalion, and
name: Real College Essays

text: the practice was continued up to the end of the war.
name: Real College Essays

text: On February 15th, confidential orders were received that we were to proceed abroad at a very
name: Real College Essays

text: early date. Final preparations were put in hand, equipment, stores and clothing were issued
name: Real College Essays

text: to complete, and everything was made ready for a move.
name: Real College Essays

text: On February 16th, Col. Huskinson received notice of his appointment as Commander of Base Details
name: Real College Essays

text: on Lines of Communication with Capt. G. Clarke as his Adjutant. Col. Huskinson had been to
name: Real College Essays

text: a great extent responsible for the recruiting of the Battalion to full strength before the
name: Real College Essays

text: war, and his keenness and enthusiasm throughout the difficult times of reorganisation and training
name: Real College Essays

text: during these first six months of the war, contributed largely to the high standard of morale
name: Real College Essays

text: and general efficiency reached in England. One and all were sorry to lose him, but we were
name: Real College Essays

text: glad indeed to find that Major Fowler was to succeed him in Command of the Battalion.
name: Real College Essays

text: On February 19th, we had the honour of being inspected with the rest of the Division by H.M.
name: Real College Essays

text: the King, at Hallingbury Place, near Bishop's Stortford.
name: Real College Essays

text: Into the last few days was crowded an immense amount of work, for the final arrangements never
name: Real College Essays

text: seemed to finish, and changes took place right up to the last. We were made up to establishment
name: Real College Essays

text: in Officers by the arrival of Lieuts. G. S. Heathcote and F. B. Lawson, and 2nd Lieuts. C.
name: Real College Essays

text: L. Hill and T. H. F. Adams, whilst large reinforcements from the 2/8th Battalion on February
name: Real College Essays

text: 22nd, brought us up to full strength, and when we left Bocking on February 25th, we were 31
name: Real College Essays

text: Officers and 996 other ranks. Second Lieut. R. E. Hemingway was left behind with 100 men as
name: Real College Essays

text: the First Reinforcement, and the Orderly Room was handed over to the care of Col.-Sergt. Instructor
name: Real College Essays

text: F. Kieran. We left by two trains at 7.50 and 9.15 a.m., and by 4.0 p.m. had all detrained at
name: Real College Essays

text: Southampton Docks.
name: Real College Essays

text: On the whole the Battalion was well equipped, and physically everyone was fit. The chief drawback
name: Real College Essays

text: appeared to be that we had rather a large percentage of young and inexperienced Officers and
name: Real College Essays

text: N.C.O.'s, but as all had much to learn of the kind of warfare actually going on, this was no
name: Real College Essays

text: great disadvantage. With so many late additions and the very recent reorganisation, few Commanders
name: Real College Essays

text: had had the opportunity of getting to know their men. So far as training was concerned we had
name: Real College Essays

text: covered in a way the whole of what the books had to say, and were fairly well acquainted with
name: Real College Essays

text: ordinary methods of fighting. There was a tendency towards staleness at the moment, and it
name: Real College Essays

text: is doubtful whether prolongation of our training in England would have been beneficial. We
name: Real College Essays

text: felt somewhat ignorant of many practical points affecting trench warfare, into which the fighting
name: Real College Essays

text: on most of the Western front had degenerated, and though we had received useful hints from
name: Real College Essays

text: Major Hume, who had been out, we yet had a great deal to learn; this we did in France, in the
name: Real College Essays

text: hard school of bitter experience. Whatever our shortcomings, we felt proud indeed to belong
name: Real College Essays

text: to the first complete Territorial Division to embark for France.
name: Real College Essays

text: As soon as the detrainment was completed, we proceeded on board the "Mount Temple," with certain
name: Real College Essays

text: Royal Field Artillery Details, the ship being under the command of Major Kent, R.F.A. At 6.30
name: Real College Essays

text: p.m. we dropped down to Netley, imagining we were off, instead of which we anchored there for
name: Real College Essays

text: the night. The greater part of the next day, February 26th, was spent on board in physical
name: Real College Essays

text: and other exercises and inspections. Late in the afternoon, much to our surprise, orders were
name: Real College Essays

text: received that 21 Officers and 763 other ranks were to disembark, presumably because it was
name: Real College Essays

text: not desirable for so many troops to cross on a slow going boat like the "Mount Temple." Having
name: Real College Essays

text: left on board Major Clarke, Capt. Ashwell, and Lieut. Heathcote with two-and-a-half platoons
name: Real College Essays

text: of A Company, and Capts. Hodgkinson and Davenport with the Signal, Transport and Machine-Gun
name: Real College Essays

text: Sections, the remainder of us disembarked about 6.30 p.m., and proceeded to a Rest Camp about
name: Real College Essays

text: three miles outside Southampton. It was very disappointing to be split up, but there was nothing
name: Real College Essays

text: to be done but to make the best of it. We cannot say that our two days' stay at the Rest Camp
name: Real College Essays

text: was exactly enjoyable, for the camp was uncomfortable, and no passes were allowed to the town.
name: Real College Essays

text: We therefore fully appreciated the kindness of the ladies of the St. John Ambulance Association,
name: Real College Essays

text: who had huts near the camp, and gave us most excellent meals.
name: Real College Essays

text: On February 28th, a further contingent of 101 men under Captain Becher embarked on the "Caledonian,"
name: Real College Essays

text: and later in the day the rest of us went on board a small Clyde pleasure steamer, the "King
name: Real College Essays

text: Edward," where we were crowded beyond description. Neither party sailed, however, that day,
name: Real College Essays

text: and we spent the night on board. The next day those on the "King Edward" had to disembark once
name: Real College Essays

text: again! This took place early in the morning, and after a little wandering we ultimately obtained
name: Real College Essays

text: billets for the Officers at the Central Hotel, and for the men at the Watt Memorial Hall.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the end we embarked on the "King Edward" on the afternoon of March 2nd, and sailed the same
name: Real College Essays

text: night. There was so much to interest everyone until we got out to sea that we had little time
name: Real College Essays

text: in which to indulge sentimental feelings. That gliding down Southampton Water in silence broken
name: Real College Essays

text: only by the throbbing of the engines, with lights out, sentries posted, and in some cases Machine-Guns
name: Real College Essays

text: mounted, the sudden appearance out of the darkness from somewhere off the Isle of Wight of
name: Real College Essays

text: a destroyer to pilot us across the Channel, the challenge to the ship as to who we were, and
name: Real College Essays

text: the order to "carry on," the numberless rays of searchlights sweeping around on all sides--such
name: Real College Essays

text: was the start of our great expedition, precisely the same, no doubt, as that of most other
name: Real College Essays

text: troops who crossed during the war.
name: Real College Essays

text: We had an excellent crossing and anchored off Havre early the following morning, disembarking
name: Real College Essays

text: about 7.30 a.m. The morning was spent amongst the hangars at the docks, drawing sheep-skin
name: Real College Essays

text: coats and other equipment. Here we were met by Major Clarke who reported that Capt. Ashwell
name: Real College Essays

text: with two platoons had already proceeded up country, and that they had all had a very uncomfortable
name: Real College Essays

text: time at Havre, sleeping in trucks or wherever they could. They had been joined by M. Lacolle,
name: Real College Essays

text: who was to be attached to the Battalion as Interpreter. After dinner we marched down to our
name: Real College Essays

text: entraining point, and were able to entrain more or less at leisure during the afternoon--our
name: Real College Essays

text: first experience of a French Troop train. Later on we got accustomed to their ideas, but certainly
name: Real College Essays

text: for the men, and often for Officers too, the French way is not quite in accordance with our
name: Real College Essays

text: own ideas, and we must confess it went very much against the grain to have to crowd 36 to 40
name: Real College Essays

text: men in nothing more or less than a cattle truck. "Hommes 40: Chevaux 8," may be all right for
name: Real College Essays

text: the "Chevaux," but for the "Hommes" we consider a revised number is required.
name: Real College Essays

text: During these first few hours spent at Havre we learnt to appreciate the Y.M.C.A. huts, which
name: Real College Essays

text: supplied much excellent refreshment, and the Officers will certainly not forget the delicious
name: Real College Essays

text: tea and cakes so generously provided by Mrs. Pitt.
name: Real College Essays

text: We left for the North at 5.15 p.m. At Rouen a halt was made for the engine to take in water,
name: Real College Essays

text: and ourselves coffee and rum. The taste of the latter was new to most of us, but we liked it
name: Real College Essays

text: well enough to hope that we might make its acquaintance again. Early in the morning of March
name: Real College Essays

text: 4th, we had a short "halte repas" at Abbeville for breakfast, and continuing via Calais and
name: Real College Essays

text: St. Omer we eventually, about 1 p.m., after a 20 hours journey, detrained at Cassel, which
name: Real College Essays

text: if tradition does not lie, was the happy hunting ground of the good old Duke of York, who
name: Real College Essays

text: "Had ten thousand men,
name: Real College Essays

text: He marched 'em up to the top of the hill,
name: Real College Essays

text: And he marched 'em down again."
name: Real College Essays

text: If the English Tommy of those days was anything like the modern "Old Bill" he probably had
name: Real College Essays

text: something pointed to say about the Hill of Cassel, and was equally unappreciative of the magnificent
name: Real College Essays

text: view one got from its summit!
name: Real College Essays

text: Capt. Ashwell met us at the Station and acted as our guide to the little village of Oudezeele,
name: Real College Essays

text: which we reached about 5 o'clock after a trying seven miles' march. The men were tired after
name: Real College Essays

text: their long, cramped journey; many wore new boots, whilst all were weighed down with enormous
name: Real College Essays

text: packs, which had been added to by the newly drawn sheep-skin coats. It was not surprising that
name: Real College Essays

text: under such conditions many fell out, and that most of us were thoroughly weary by the time
name: Real College Essays

text: we reached our destination. Ashwell and his party too, had not had a pleasant time. Strangers
name: Real College Essays

text: in a strange land without Battalion, Brigade or Divisional Headquarters--or any of the other
name: Real College Essays

text: luxuries which make life worth living--they had found existence rather precarious. Ashwell
name: Real College Essays

text: himself had walked 45 miles in three days in search of rations, so that our arrival with the
name: Real College Essays

text: transport was more than welcome.
name: Real College Essays

text: We found our billets rather strange after the houses and cottages to which we had become accustomed
name: Real College Essays

text: in England, as they consisted mostly of scattered farms, several platoons and sometimes a whole
name: Real College Essays

text: Company or more being billeted at one farm, generally in barns.
name: Real College Essays

text: Capt. Becher and his party arrived late the following day, having been kept three days on the
name: Real College Essays

text: Caledonian, and the Battalion was once more complete. As the rest of the Brigade had crossed
name: Real College Essays

text: before us and had already gone up for trench instruction, we were temporarily attached to the
name: Real College Essays

text: Lincoln and Leicester Brigade.
name: Real College Essays

text: We spent a few days training at Oudezeele, including one or two route marches to get accustomed
name: Real College Essays

text: to the pav?? roads, and Edge, as newly appointed Sniping Officer, gave a little special instruction
name: Real College Essays

text: in that branch of warfare. We had a visit from Major-General Stuart-Wortley, who discussed
name: Real College Essays

text: the training to be carried out, and our coming duties in the trenches. The weather was very
name: Real College Essays

text: cold, and a good deal of work was in the shape of lectures in billets, and the reading of various
name: Real College Essays

text: routine and other orders issued to troops on arrival.
name: Real College Essays

text: It was during one of our route marches in this district, which took us through the little village
name: Real College Essays

text: of Wormhoudt, that we made our first acquaintance with French troops. Many of them were back
name: Real College Essays

text: resting in billets, and the warm welcome they gave us as we passed through the narrow streets
name: Real College Essays

text: of the village crowded with French "poilus," the whole Battalion whistling the "Marseillaise,"
name: Real College Essays

text: was an experience which will not be readily forgotten.
name: Real College Essays

text: On March 9th, we marched with the Lincoln and Leicester Brigade via Cassel, Caestre (where
name: Real College Essays

text: General Smith-Dorrien saw us march past), and Strazeele to Merris, where we joined up with
name: Real College Essays

text: the rest of our Brigade, back from their course of instruction in the trenches. Fortunately
name: Real College Essays

text: the fur coats which had caused us so much trouble on the last march were now carried for us
name: Real College Essays

text: by motor 'bus. At Merris we saw our first real signs of fighting, both the Church and the Hospice
name: Real College Essays

text: having been hit several times by shells, whilst there were isolated graves of both French and
name: Real College Essays

text: English scattered about the surrounding country. Here too, we saw our first "fighting" aeroplane
name: Real College Essays

text: (armed with one short French Rifle), which had crashed just outside the village. It was also
name: Real College Essays

text: at Merris that we had our first experience of paying a Company "in the Field." Instructions
name: Real College Essays

text: on the subject had led us to believe that this was a complicated performance, but in practice
name: Real College Essays

text: it turned out to be quite easy. Company "Imprests" were at a later date done away with and
name: Real College Essays

text: a Battalion Imprest instituted, which was much more convenient, as also was the very handy
name: Real College Essays

text: Officer's Advance Book, which was introduced later. At first there seemed but little check
name: Real College Essays

text: on the money that was drawn, and Field Cashiers appeared to issue money to all and sundry on
name: Real College Essays

text: the flimsiest authority.
name: Real College Essays

text: Preparations were being made about this time for a British offensive at Neuve Chapelle, and
name: Real College Essays

text: our Brigade was attached temporarily to General Gough's 2nd Cavalry Division, with the object,
name: Real College Essays

text: if the attack succeeded, of breaking through in the region of the Bois du Biez. In order to
name: Real College Essays

text: be nearer the scene of operations we were moved from Merris at an hour's notice at noon on
name: Real College Essays

text: March 10th, and marched via Rouge Croix to Bac-St. Maur. This was a memorable experience, but
name: Real College Essays

text: later on we became accustomed to rapid movement, and the great concentration of troops which
name: Real College Essays

text: was necessary when fighting was imminent. Transport marched brigaded, and in passing through
name: Real College Essays

text: Sailly-sur-Lys in the darkness seemed to be so mixed up in the seething mass of men that we
name: Real College Essays

text: almost began to doubt if they would ever extricate themselves. Under the guiding hand and voice
name: Real College Essays

text: of Capt. Davenport, however, our Transport eventually got clear. During this operation "Davvy"
name: Real College Essays

text: evidently made a great impression on one soldier (a Regular), by his forcible language, as
name: Real College Essays

text: the latter was heard to remark "There's a bloke what knows 'is job." Confusion was great in
name: Real College Essays

text: Bac-St. Maur too, for when we got there, the billets which we had been allotted were still
name: Real College Essays

text: occupied by Canadians. Eventually, we all got shelter of a kind, in probably the dirtiest and
name: Real College Essays

text: poorest billets we ever had either in France or Belgium. This was our first meeting with our
name: Real College Essays

text: Canadian friends, and we can hardly say we were impressed, though we all knew well what they
name: Real College Essays

text: were made of. We have specially vivid recollections of one Canadian sentry on duty at night
name: Real College Essays

text: opposite D Company's billet, evidently "well away," loosing off his rifle at intervals, apparently
name: Real College Essays

text: to let us know that he was "present and correct." One bullet was close enough to be unpleasant,
name: Real College Essays

text: and fetched a lump off the tree just outside the window. In this area we were nearer to the
name: Real College Essays

text: line than we had yet been, some of our guns firing from quite close to the village, and we
name: Real College Essays

text: found it an interesting experience to see for the first time an aeroplane being shelled.
name: Real College Essays

text: We stood by for two days, ready to move at a moment's notice, hearing much of the noise of
name: Real College Essays

text: the battle. The attack, however, was not successful and the Bois du Biez plan, therefore, fell
name: Real College Essays

text: through. On March 13th, we got orders to move to fresh billets. We had to travel light as we
name: Real College Essays

text: were still regarded as a "flying column." Much superfluous kit was left behind, to be sent
name: Real College Essays

text: for later on, and the weird bundles left at the Estaminet at Bac-St. Maur will not readily
name: Real College Essays

text: be forgotten. We marched that afternoon via Estaires to Neuf Berquin, where we had again to
name: Real College Essays

text: be content with rather crowded, if somewhat more comfortable billets than we had left.
name: Real College Essays

text: One or two changes in personnel had already taken place. Capt. Hodgkinson gave up the appointment
name: Real College Essays

text: of Quar.-Master owing to some technicalities, and for the moment acted as Censor. In this capacity
name: Real College Essays

text: he was obliged, to our great annoyance, to carry out the order to relieve us of our cameras,
name: Real College Essays

text: which were sent home,--no doubt on the whole a wise and necessary precaution. Capt. Hodgkinson
name: Real College Essays

text: was succeeded as Quar.-Master by Lieut. Torrance, who was destined, with a short break in 1918,
name: Real College Essays

text: to carry out the duties up to the end of the war. He performed them with much success, and
name: Real College Essays

text: in a way that only Torrance could. On his appointment as Quar. Master, the Orderly Room came
name: Real College Essays

text: under the charge of Corpl. R. Harvey, who carried out his difficult task with the utmost devotion,
name: Real College Essays

text: without a break until the last man of the Battalion was demobilised. Second Lieut. G. W. Fosbery,
name: Real College Essays

text: who received his Commission as we were about to cross to France, took over his platoon from
name: Real College Essays

text: Handford, who as Signalling Officer had enough other work to keep him busy.
name: Real College Essays

text: We stayed at Neuf Berquin for ten days and did a considerable amount of useful training, but
name: Real College Essays

text: unfortunately at this time many men were sick, owing to the bad water, so that parades were
name: Real College Essays

text: somewhat small. In addition to continued route marches to keep feet in condition we practised
name: Real College Essays

text: formations for advancing through woods in the Bois d'Aval, open warfare attack under the watchful
name: Real College Essays

text: eye of General Gough, and several trench-to-trench attacks on the leap-frog principle, the
name: Real College Essays

text: first line capturing and holding the front trench, and other lines passing through them to
name: Real College Essays

text: attack the support trenches. We also began to practise making and throwing the old "jam-tin
name: Real College Essays

text: bomb," the beginning of the attack of "bomb fever," which unfortunately was to play such a
name: Real College Essays

text: prominent part in the warfare of the next two or three years, undoubtedly to the detriment
name: Real College Essays

text: of all sound training and tactics.
name: Real College Essays

text: Arrangements had meanwhile been made for our initiation into the mysteries of real trench warfare,
name: Real College Essays

text: and with that object in view we were moved on March 24th, to Vieux Berquin, and on the 26th,
name: Real College Essays

text: across the frontier to Romarin in Belgium, being once more attached to the Lincoln and Leicester
name: Real College Essays

text: Brigade. Much to our regret the rum issue was stopped the next day!
name: Real College Essays

text: We were attached for instruction to the 10th Infantry Brigade, 4th Division, and the programme
name: Real College Essays

text: arranged allowed each Company to spend two nights in the trenches, with a break of 24 hours
name: Real College Essays

text: in billets. The Battalions to which we were attached included the Royal Irish Rifles, 2nd Royal
name: Real College Essays

text: Dublin Fusiliers, Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, 2nd Seaforth Highlanders, and 2nd Royal
name: Real College Essays

text: Warwicks, who held the trenches about Ploegsteert and opposite Messines.
name: Real College Essays

text: The first night each Officer and man studied the work of his counterpart in the Battalion to
name: Real College Essays

text: which he was attached, and the second night platoons were allotted definite lengths of trench,
name: Real College Essays

text: for which they were held responsible. This first experience was not exactly full of incident,
name: Real College Essays

text: as on the whole we had a very quiet time, but for us, as for all others on their first visit
name: Real College Essays

text: to the line, many little incidents of everyday trench routine were novel and exciting. Recollection
name: Real College Essays

text: lingers on the long, slow tramp to the trenches, along corduroy tracks in thick darkness lighted
name: Real College Essays

text: up from time to time by Very lights from our own trenches and by the infinitely superior ones
name: Real College Essays

text: from the enemy (we recollect that some of us, faithful to our instructions, but slightly misguided,
name: Real College Essays

text: began ducking quite five miles behind the line when a flare went up), the constant order to
name: Real College Essays

text: keep closed up, the whizz of bullets, at every one of which we ducked instantly, the cracking
name: Real College Essays

text: of rifles, the 'dead cow' smell which afterwards became so painfully familiar, the arrival
name: Real College Essays

text: at the trenches and the posting of sentries. Later the cautious creeping over the parapet to
name: Real College Essays

text: look at the wire and at dawn stand-to, followed by the frizzling of bacon and the brewing of
name: Real College Essays

text: tea (in these days each side had a more or less respectable breakfast, evidenced by the columns
name: Real College Essays

text: of smoke that went up from the respective front line trenches directly after stand-down). Such
name: Real College Essays

text: incidents we feel sure were sufficiently novel at the time to impress themselves vividly on
name: Real College Essays

text: the memories of those whom a kindly fate has preserved to read these recollections.
name: Real College Essays

text: Probably the most uncanny feeling some of us had was, when on starting from Battalion Headquarters
name: Real College Essays

text: for the trenches, we met a stretcher party carrying out one of our own men, Comp. Sergt.-Major
name: Real College Essays

text: Hopkinson, who had been wounded by a sniper, and was our first casualty. It was an experience
name: Real College Essays

text: that everyone had to go through, but it was not pleasant. Hopkinson and two men of D Company
name: Real College Essays

text: wounded by shell fire were our only casualties during our instructional tours. That we did
name: Real College Essays

text: not make a bad impression is attested by a letter written from an Officer of the 2nd Seaforths,
name: Real College Essays

text: who says:--"I thought your Officers and men most awfully keen, and I was immensely struck by
name: Real College Essays

text: the way your men came into the trench--no noise at all, and perfect discipline and quietness
name: Real College Essays

text: and keenness. They were awfully willing to act up to any small suggestions you made as to what
name: Real College Essays

text: they ought to do. They came in so much better than Regulars, and I was genuinely filled with
name: Real College Essays

text: admiration for them. They were a splendid body of men." It is, perhaps, needless to say that
name: Real College Essays

text: we on our part much appreciated the great kindness shewn us by the units to which we were attached.
name: Real College Essays

text: Those of us who happened to be in or near Petit Douvre Farm during this attachment were much
name: Real College Essays

text: interested in finding some of the early drawings of Bairnsfather, as done for the "Bystander."
name: Real College Essays

text: The interior walls of the farm were covered with his charcoal sketches, in some cases to the
name: Real College Essays

text: order of Commanding Officers who were to follow! It was at the same farm that Pvte. Cottam,
name: Real College Essays

text: of D Company, acted as head butcher in the slaughter of an abandoned pig, causing a good deal
name: Real College Essays

text: of excitement before final despatch. Most of the men brought away with them "souveneers" of
name: Real College Essays

text: this first visit, none more unaccountable than the dud 77 mm. shell carried about in his pack
name: Real College Essays

text: for several days, by a sturdy sanitary man of A Company--in fact, until discovered by a rather
name: Real College Essays

text: alarmed Company Commander.
name: Real College Essays

text: On March 31st, we left Romarin, and marched back to our old billets at Vieux Berquin, being
name: Real College Essays

text: met at Doulieu and escorted from there by the 6th Battalion band. Only one band had been allowed
name: Real College Essays

text: to come out with the Brigade, and after some discussion that of the 6th Battalion was selected,
name: Real College Essays

text: and carried on up to the end of the war, virtually as a Brigade Band.
name: Real College Essays

text: Orders were received on April 1st, for our Division to take over its first portion of the British
name: Real College Essays

text: front in relief of the 28th Division, and on April 2nd we marched with the rest of the Brigade
name: Real College Essays

text: via Bailleul to Locre, in Belgium. As few, if any of us, had ever studied Flemish, the language
name: Real College Essays

text: question in some of the villages of Flanders presented a little difficulty, but with his guiding
name: Real College Essays

text: principle of "tout-de-suite, and the touter the sweeter," the British Tommy never seemed to
name: Real College Essays

text: have any trouble in getting what he wanted. We were disposed to think sometimes that the Belgians
name: Real College Essays

text: did not look very kindly on us. Perhaps it was because in our early days we were rather inclined
name: Real College Essays

text: to take too much notice of the frequent reports we heard of supposed Belgian spies, and of
name: Real College Essays

text: Belgians being in communication by various means with the Boche on the other side of the lines.
name: Real College Essays

text: One well remembers the suggestion made from time to time that signalling was carried on by
name: Real College Essays

text: means of the windmill on Mont Rouge, or by the display of washing laid out to dry on the ground
name: Real College Essays

text: by Belgian housewives. At any rate we did find a house at Locre, where a number of pigeons
name: Real College Essays

text: were kept, a fact which aroused the suspicions of some of the Officers of D Company, and in
name: Real College Essays

text: the same house were discovered quantities of British stores of all kinds, which must have been
name: Real College Essays

text: got from our troops in a not too straightforward manner. Some of the inhabitants, too, treated
name: Real College Essays

text: us with scant courtesy. It was here that the lady of the establishment removed the handle from
name: Real College Essays

text: the pump where Sergt. Markham's platoon was billeted, and not content with that went a step
name: Real College Essays

text: further, and for some reason best known to herself, gave him a cold douche when asleep one
name: Real College Essays

text: night. Some of us, on the other hand, were more fortunate in our billets, and all who went
name: Real College Essays

text: to the Hospice can have nothing but the most pleasant recollections of the great kindness of
name: Real College Essays

text: the Mother Superior and other ladies. Padre Hales, who left us to be attached to Brigade Headquarters,
name: Real College Essays

text: when we crossed to France, was billeted there with our Field Ambulance, and we were allowed
name: Real College Essays

text: to go there for baths when out of the line, and always received much kindness and hospitality.
name: Real College Essays

text: Unfortunately during the German onslaught in 1918, this delightful place was completely destroyed.
name: Real College Essays

text: The bathing arrangements in general at this time were somewhat poor, the nearest military baths
name: Real College Essays

text: being at Bailleul, about four miles away, so that we were very delighted at receiving during
name: Real College Essays

text: our stay at Locre, from Miss Gilstrap, of Winthorpe, Newark, three galvanised iron baths, with
name: Real College Essays

text: boiler complete. With these and other local devices we were able to get the men bathed at their
name: Real College Essays

text: own billets, which was a great boon. Another similar consignment from Mrs. John Becher, unfortunately
name: Real College Essays

text: got lost in the post, but we trust was of benefit to some other unit.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the afternoon of Easter Eve, April 3rd, we attended a Church Parade, taken by the Bishop
name: Real College Essays

text: of London, of which many of us have bitter recollections, as owing to a mistake in Divisional
name: Real College Essays

text: Orders, we were rigged out in full marching order. Further, as it was a damp and windy day,
name: Real College Essays

text: few of us could hear a word of the address, and all wanted to get as much sleep as possible
name: Real College Essays

text: in view of the great adventure before us. The same night, which turned out to be miserably
name: Real College Essays

text: wet, we left Locre, to take over the trench sector in front of Kemmel held by the 1st Devons.
name: Real College Essays

text: Company Commanders had already been in the trenches for 24 hours to get the lie of the land,
name: Real College Essays

text: and they, together with the guides of the Devons, met us at the appointed rendezvous, the celebrated
name: Real College Essays

text: band stand at Kemmel. There were, of course, no lights; rations and trench fuel, which had
name: Real College Essays

text: been taken up by the Transport, were issued in sandbags, and water in petrol tins, and each
name: Real College Essays

text: platoon was then led off by itself. When one looks back on trench reliefs, one is inclined
name: Real College Essays

text: to wonder how on some occasions they were carried out at all, the possibilities of going wrong
name: Real College Essays

text: seemed so great. In the present case, however, nothing untoward happened, and we set off by
name: Real College Essays

text: our various routes to the front line, passing such favourite spots as the "Sahara Desert" (the
name: Real College Essays

text: final resting place of every bullet fired within a radius of five miles, or so it seemed),
name: Real College Essays

text: the "Willows," "Irish Farm" or "The Orchard," and into the G and H trenches. In our heavy greatcoats
name: Real College Essays

text: and with full packs, which we continued religiously to carry for many months for no apparent
name: Real College Essays

text: reason, the journey was not pleasant, and we were not sorry to get into the trenches, where
name: Real College Essays

text: the relief was completed about 11 p.m. C Company being mainly composed of miners and under
name: Real College Essays

text: the command of a Mining Engineer, were put in the right sector where was our only mine, much
name: Real College Essays

text: to the relief of, at least, one Company Commander, who had mental visions of a mine as a large
name: Real College Essays

text: black cavern, where hand-to-hand fighting went on incessantly! A Company had the centre and
name: Real College Essays

text: D Company the left, B Company occupying the two supporting points and billets in Kemmel Village.
name: Real College Essays

text: Battalion Headquarters were at the Doctor's house in Kemmel, and the Transport and Quar.-Master's
name: Real College Essays

text: Stores remained at Locre.
name: Real College Essays

text: There was practically only one trench line at this time, and this, like most of the trenches
name: Real College Essays

text: in Belgium and the low lying districts, was a line of breastworks with very little wire in
name: Real College Essays

text: front, and only one or two small supporting points. The opposing front lines varied from 25
name: Real College Essays

text: to about 300 yards apart, being closest at "Peckham Corner," on the right. Shelters were built
name: Real College Essays

text: mostly of timber and corrugated iron, strengthened with sandbags, and were generally in the
name: Real College Essays

text: parados of the trench.
name: Real College Essays

text: Easter day--our first day holding a bit of line on our own--was fairly quiet, except for a
name: Real College Essays

text: little shelling of D Company on the left during the afternoon. On the right, some men of C
name: Real College Essays

text: Company sang hymns, and the enemy made overtures for a truce by showing a white flag. About
name: Real College Essays

text: 40 of them appeared on the parapet, and a brisk conversation ensued for several minutes across
name: Real College Essays

text: No Man's Land. A somewhat unflattering remark from one of the enemy who had a wonderful knowledge
name: Real College Essays

text: of forcible English, ended the armistice rather hurriedly.
name: Real College Essays

text: On most nights during these early days of the war, each side had its turn at five or ten rounds
name: Real College Essays

text: rapid to relieve the monotony of things. In this we were on equal terms with the enemy, but
name: Real College Essays

text: during the day we were hopelessly outclassed owing to the great shortage of periscopes, and
name: Real College Essays

text: the lack of telescopic rifles and well constructed loophole plates, of all of which the Hun
name: Real College Essays

text: seemed to have an abundant supply. It was long before we got anything like adequate numbers
name: Real College Essays

text: of these very necessary trench requisites. It was not surprising, therefore, that for some
name: Real College Essays

text: time the Boche snipers had the upper hand and could do almost what they liked. Their shooting
name: Real College Essays

text: was extremely accurate, and as the trenches were enfiladed on all sides, and there was in many
name: Real College Essays

text: cases little parados, we soon had casualties, most of which were sentries shot through the
name: Real College Essays

text: head. Our first fatal casualty was Pvte. Hyde, of A Company, shot in this way on April 6th.
name: Real College Essays

text: We were also short and entirely inexperienced in the use of rifle grenades and trench mortars,
name: Real College Essays

text: with which the enemy made very good practice. A large trench mortar certainly did find its
name: Real College Essays

text: way up to the trenches by some means one day, and provided considerable amusement to our men.
name: Real College Essays

text: It is reported to have dropped its first bomb into the enemy trench, and its second into our
name: Real College Essays

text: own--its erratic behaviour ultimately making it no doubt more annoying to ourselves than to
name: Real College Essays

text: the enemy. Lieuts. A. Hacking and Hollins were the pioneers in the use of rifle grenades, with
name: Real College Essays

text: which they eventually did good work at "Peckham Corner."
name: Real College Essays

text: After a tour of four days which were most uncomfortable owing to constant rain, we returned
name: Real College Essays

text: to Locre. The system of four days in trenches and four in billets, taking turns with the 6th
name: Real College Essays

text: Battalion, continued for some time with little variation. When out of the line we, of course,
name: Real College Essays

text: had to find those never-to-be-forgotten working parties, which had become part of the normal
name: Real College Essays

text: trench warfare system. Having had a hard four days in the trenches, it was never a pleasant
name: Real College Essays

text: duty to have to march up three or four miles on one or perhaps two nights out of our few days'
name: Real College Essays

text: rest, to do a job for the Royal Engineers or some other specialists in the trenches. Otherwise,
name: Real College Essays

text: our stays at Locre were fairly pleasant. There were no great attractions, but we had enough
name: Real College Essays

text: to do as a rule in general training and cleaning, and the country round about was extremely
name: Real College Essays

text: pleasant, either for walking or riding. Perhaps the greatest excitement was to go down to Bailleul
name: Real College Essays

text: to shop and call on "Tina." Such luxuries as Canteens for supplying the wants of the inner
name: Real College Essays

text: man were quite unknown in these early days, when we had to rely mainly on parcels from home
name: Real College Essays

text: or purchases in the local towns.
name: Real College Essays

text: Work in the trenches consisted mainly of strengthening or rebuilding the parapet and parados,
name: Real College Essays

text: and in putting out barbed wire defences. As a rule, we wanted far more sandbags than were ever
name: Real College Essays

text: forthcoming, but in these days they were used indiscriminately, and in consequence many very
name: Real College Essays

text: weak structures were built, which could not possibly stand without support through a single
name: Real College Essays

text: wet season. The barbed wire defences were very poor, and as soon as we got into the way of
name: Real College Essays

text: doing it much time was spent in that not too pleasant work, for Boche snipers did execution
name: Real College Essays

text: by night as well as by day, and made themselves very objectionable. Our entanglements consisted
name: Real College Essays

text: mainly of "knife-rests"--wooden frames strung with barbed wire. These were made by the men
name: Real College Essays

text: in the Brigade workshop at Kemmel, run by Major Wordsworth, the Staff Captain, to which each
name: Real College Essays

text: Battalion contributed a quota of pioneers and trade specialists. One Officer learnt a very
name: Real College Essays

text: practical lesson in their use from the enemy. He had some carefully placed in position one
name: Real College Essays

text: night, where he thought his wire particularly weak, but his spirits fell to zero the following
name: Real College Essays

text: morning, when on looking over the top he saw his precious knife-rests in position guarding
name: Real College Essays

text: the Boche trenches opposite! From that time onwards knife-rests were securely fastened to each
name: Real College Essays

text: other and to the ground. Our Brigade (hereafter known as the 139th Infantry Brigade) had a
name: Real College Essays

text: good reputation for trench work, and the digging element was used to great advantage by the
name: Real College Essays

text: 6th Battalion commencing what was one of the first long communication trenches dug on the British
name: Real College Essays

text: front. It extended from the front line nearly back to Kemmel and was for ever known as the
name: Real College Essays

text: Via Gellia. In its later stages it was worked on by ourselves. This trench was a great convenience,
name: Real College Essays

text: as it enabled reliefs to be carried out much more securely by avoiding going over the open,
name: Real College Essays

text: and permitted of visits of inspection to be made by daylight, and the wounded to be carried
name: Real College Essays

text: back to the dressing station at Kemmel. In the early days they remained in the trenches until
name: Real College Essays

text: it was dark enough for the journey to be made over the top.
name: Real College Essays

text: On April 22nd, we experienced a little of the backwash of the first Hun gas attack against
name: Real College Essays

text: the French and Canadians in the Ypres Salient a few miles North of us. During most of the time
name: Real College Essays

text: we had been in this area there had been considerable activity in that quarter, and the shelling
name: Real College Essays

text: and burning of Ypres could be plainly seen from the Kemmel trenches. This attack was the beginning
name: Real College Essays

text: of the second battle of Ypres. The only effect on ourselves of the gas used on this occasion,
name: Real College Essays

text: was to make our eyes smart and a few men sick. It did, however, cause a commotion on all sides,
name: Real College Essays

text: and with unaccustomed speed, the first consignment of respirators was sent out to us--pieces
name: Real College Essays

text: of gauze which had to be filled with tea-leaves, damped, and fastened round the mouth in the
name: Real College Essays

text: event of attack. These were improved from time to time, and a little later we got a gas-proof
name: Real College Essays

text: smoke helmet--the earliest form known as "P," and the later as "P.H." Vermorel sprayers were
name: Real College Essays

text: also provided in due course, and some solution for spraying the trenches to clear them of gas.
name: Real College Essays

text: Bells and gongs formed of shell cartridge cases or pieces of iron were also hung in the trenches
name: Real College Essays

text: to be sounded by the sentry if any sign of cloud gas was seen. There was perhaps a natural
name: Real College Essays

text: tendency to imagine gas when there was none, and an official report of gas by C Company on
name: Real College Essays

text: the night of May 8th, was found to be due to the proximity of a dead cow.
name: Real College Essays

text: April 24th witnessed our first serious bombardment. We had already had several somewhat severe
name: Real College Essays

text: baptisms, but they were trifling in comparison. About 6 p.m., after an exceptionally quiet
name: Real College Essays

text: day, and just before we were to be relieved, the enemy began an organised trench mortar bombardment
name: Real College Essays

text: of G1 and 2, occupied by platoons of C and D Companies, and H 4 held by Lieut. Vann and his
name: Real College Essays

text: platoon of B Company. It lasted for about an hour, and made large breaches in the parapet of
name: Real College Essays

text: G1 and 2, and practically demolished the whole of H 4, a small isolated trench on the extreme
name: Real College Essays

text: left, opposite Petit Bois. Both these trenches were completely enfiladed by the Boche, so that
name: Real College Essays

text: their shooting was extremely accurate. It was thought at one time that the enemy might attempt
name: Real College Essays

text: a raid on G1 and 2, but this did not develop. A Machine Gun team consisting of L.-Corpl. Sharrock
name: Real College Essays

text: and Pvtes. Hopewell and Davis, which was posted in G1, behaved most coolly, and Sergt. A. Phillipson,
name: Real College Essays

text: of D Company, did very gallant work in the same trench under heavy fire with Pvtes. Coombes
name: Real College Essays

text: and Durand, all in a more or less dazed condition, helping to dig out the wounded. On the left
name: Real College Essays

text: Vann and his platoon had a very bad time. Whilst he was digging out wounded a bomb fell close
name: Real College Essays

text: by, killing four and burying three others, and blowing Vann himself several yards across the
name: Real College Essays

text: open at the back of the trench, and practically wiping out the garrison. Major Becher brought
name: Real College Essays

text: up reinforcements and helped Vann to get the position made good, and great assistance was given
name: Real College Essays

text: by 2nd Lieut. Hollins and L.-Corpl. Humberstone. Pvtes. F. Boothby and A. Gleaden of B Company
name: Real College Essays

text: also did excellent work, helping to dig out and dress the wounded, most of the time in full
name: Real College Essays

text: view of the enemy, not more than 70 yards away. The 2nd Royal Scots on our immediate left,
name: Real College Essays

text: also gave us valuable assistance. Our total casualties during the hour's bombardment were 14
name: Real College Essays

text: men killed and two Officers (Vann and Gray), and 14 men wounded. When we were back at Locre
name: Real College Essays

text: after this tour, General Shipley spoke to the Battalion on parade and thanked them for the
name: Real College Essays

text: good work done, especially congratulating Vann, and on the following day the General Officer
name: Real College Essays

text: Commanding our Division also congratulated the Battalion on its behaviour under fire.
name: Real College Essays

text: Several changes took place during April, owing to casualties. Capt. Allen went down sick on
name: Real College Essays

text: April 6th, and Lieut. James took over the command of D Company until the 14th, when Capt. Hodgkinson
name: Real College Essays

text: was appointed. He, however, also had a short stay there, for on April 22nd, when in an excess
name: Real College Essays

text: of zeal to see what was going on opposite G1, where some suspicious work was reported, he apparently
name: Real College Essays

text: thought he could sufficiently camouflage himself behind a pair of field glasses to gaze over
name: Real College Essays

text: the top of the parapet, the almost immediate result was a bullet which just grazed his head,
name: Real College Essays

text: and he, too, had to leave us. D Company then came under Capt. Lane. Second Lieut. Eddison,
name: Real College Essays

text: our first fatal Officer casualty, was killed on April 21st, being hit by a bullet whilst out
name: Real College Essays

text: wiring, and though help was instantly rendered by Drummers Newton and Robb, who pulled him
name: Real College Essays

text: out of the shell-hole of water, into which he had fallen, and carried him into the trench,
name: Real College Essays

text: he died in a few minutes. Four Officers were down for a short time with measles, including
name: Real College Essays

text: Capt. Martyn, who unfortunately was invalided to England, and was succeeded in command of C
name: Real College Essays

text: Company, by Capt. H. G. Wright. Martyn served later in Ireland and France, as Second-in-Command
name: Real College Essays

text: of the 2/8th Battalion and in command of the 2/7th Battalion, and won the D.S.O. and M.C. Lieut.
name: Real College Essays

text: Lawson got a shell wound in the shoulder and had to leave, and 2nd Lieuts. Gray and Vann also
name: Real College Essays

text: had to be in hospital for a short time from what was later known as "shell-shock." A great
name: Real College Essays

text: loss, too, was Sergt. Wilmore, a very gallant soldier, who was sniped one day when outside
name: Real College Essays

text: his trench.
name: Real College Essays

text: May found us beginning to feel our feet. The Commanding Officer had talks with Officers as
name: Real College Essays

text: to a more aggressive attitude being taken up; we had a lecture from Major Howard, R.E., at
name: Real College Essays

text: Kemmel as to the construction of an invisible loophole, low down in the parapet, and so built
name: Real College Essays

text: as to afford a good field of fire and permit of our replying better to the Hun snipers. Sergt.-Drummer
name: Real College Essays

text: Clewes also got into action with his telescopic rifle from sniping posts cunningly placed behind
name: Real College Essays

text: the front line, the only possible position from which really successful sniping could be done,
name: Real College Essays

text: and was not long in getting quite a good "bag." Shortly afterwards he was put in charge of
name: Real College Essays

text: the newly-formed Brigade Sniping Section. A trench mortar was actually got into use, and did
name: Real College Essays

text: a certain amount of damage to the Boche trenches, but naturally produced considerable retaliation.
name: Real College Essays

text: Further efforts to fire rifle grenades met with some success, whilst a "Gamage" catapult introduced
name: Real College Essays

text: to throw bombs provided, at any rate, a little amusement. In patrolling considerable progress
name: Real College Essays

text: was made. Second Lieut. A. Hacking did some very daring work at "Peckham Corner," and near
name: Real College Essays

text: Petit Bois; 2nd Lieut. Hollins and L.-Corpls. Heath and G. Gadd of B Company made splendid
name: Real College Essays

text: reconnaissances of the enemy's wire; and 2nd Lieut. Edge, who was always to the fore in wiring,
name: Real College Essays

text: no matter how bright the night, carried out a daring daylight reconnaissance, the first attempted
name: Real College Essays

text: in the Battalion, getting nearly up to the German front line in company with Pvte. C. E. Bryan,
name: Real College Essays

text: of A Company. Pvte. W. O'Brien, of the same Company, was another who knew no danger; in fact,
name: Real College Essays

text: at night it was difficult to keep these two men in the trench at all. Daring patrols were also
name: Real College Essays

text: carried out by 2nd Lieut. Vann, Sergt. Pickering and L.-Corpl. Humberstone. Perhaps the most
name: Real College Essays

text: successful was a fighting patrol, which went out on the night of May 9-10th under 2nd Lieut.
name: Real College Essays

text: Oates, with the object of rounding up a Hun patrol. Oates, who had a party of six men with
name: Real College Essays

text: him, went forward with Pvte. Nicholson, leaving the remainder behind, to within about 50 yards
name: Real College Essays

text: of the German wire. On their way back they ran into a Boche patrol. Oates promptly shot one
name: Real College Essays

text: man, Nicholson bayoneted another, whilst two others who were wounded got away. Oates and his
name: Real College Essays

text: party got back safely.
name: Real College Essays

text: On May 14th, we carried out one of those little manoeuvres which may have been of immense importance,
name: Real College Essays

text: but appeared to us at the moment to be so much waste of time, trouble and energy. Instead of
name: Real College Essays

text: proceeding to the trenches that night according to programme, we got sudden orders to "embus"
name: Real College Essays

text: for Hill 60, in the Ypres Salient, to dig there under Royal Engineers' supervision for the
name: Real College Essays

text: 5th Division. The net result was that of the 600 who went, 400 dug for one-and-a-half hours,
name: Real College Essays

text: and 200 for three-quarters-of-an-hour, after which the party returned to Locre in the 'buses.
name: Real College Essays

text: The idea, doubtless, was a good one, as it was necessary to dig more trenches where part of
name: Real College Essays

text: our line had given way during the recent fighting, but the organisation of the work seemed
name: Real College Essays

text: to leave a good deal to be desired. It was the remnants of a Canadian Battalion returning from
name: Real College Essays

text: this fighting in the Salient shortly after midnight on one occasion, whilst we were back at
name: Real College Essays

text: Locre, which made us think we must have had more than an ordinary nightmare, for we awoke with
name: Real College Essays

text: a start to hear the strains of a brass band coming along the pav??,--at 1 a.m. such a proceeding
name: Real College Essays

text: seemed decidedly strange. It was not long, however, before we found that all was well, and
name: Real College Essays

text: that it was our own Brigade Band playing the Canadians through the village. This was evidently
name: Real College Essays

text: appreciated by them, for one of their number in a letter to the Daily Telegraph, after describing
name: Real College Essays

text: the magic effect of the music on his men, concludes with the remark: "The Canadians will remember
name: Real College Essays

text: how the band of the Sherwood Foresters played them through the darkness at midnight out of
name: Real College Essays

text: 'Bloody Ypres.'"
name: Real College Essays

text: About the middle of May we began reliefs with the 7th Battalion, and our sector was extended
name: Real College Essays

text: slightly left to include some of the J trenches opposite Petit Bois. An interesting entry in
name: Real College Essays

text: the War Diary is that May 16th, the day following relief, was the first day absolutely free
name: Real College Essays

text: from casualties since we took over our portion of the line. This, however, must have been an
name: Real College Essays

text: exceptional day, for bad luck so far as casualties went pursued us with great regularity. Capt.
name: Real College Essays

text: Lane was badly wounded on May 26th, when out wiring, and the command of D Company then passed
name: Real College Essays

text: to Lieut. James. Capt. H. G. Wright, to the great regret of his friends in all ranks was killed
name: Real College Essays

text: on June 6th, being shot, through the double loophole plate from which he was firing, and was
name: Real College Essays

text: succeeded in command of C Company by Capt. G. S. Heathcote. Lieuts. Kirby and Weetman and 2nd
name: Real College Essays

text: Lieut. Fosbery were wounded in May, and 2nd Lieut. Oates early in June, and all had to leave
name: Real College Essays

text: the Battalion. Capt. Ashwell and 2nd Lieut. Edge were also slightly wounded. Our only reinforcement
name: Real College Essays

text: Officers were 2nd Lieuts. N. L. Hindley and G. G. Elliott. Comp. Sergt.-Major Mabbott, of A
name: Real College Essays

text: Company, was invalided to the Base, and was succeeded by Comp. Quarter-Master Sergt. Haywood,
name: Real College Essays

text: Sergt. G. W. Godfrey being promoted Comp. Quarter-Master Sergt. in his place. Comp. Sergt.-Major
name: Real College Essays

text: Mounteney, B Company, was invalided to England and Sergt. Chappell was appointed Comp. Sergt.-Major
name: Real College Essays

text: of that Company. Sergt. J. A. Green was appointed Comp. Sergt.-Major of C Company in place
name: Real College Essays

text: of Comp. Sergt.-Major Hopkinson wounded, and Sergt. T. Powell became Comp. Sergt.-Major of
name: Real College Essays

text: D Company after Comp. Sergt.-Major Spencer left, also wounded. The latter obtained a Commission
name: Real College Essays

text: some time later, only to be killed in France when doing excellent work in command of a Company
name: Real College Essays

text: of another Battalion of the Regiment. A change had also taken place in the Brigade Staff, Major
name: Real College Essays

text: E. M. Morris, the Brigade Major, who had worked so strenuously all through our period of training
name: Real College Essays

text: in England, and done so much to help us in learning our job in France, having left on June
name: Real College Essays

text: 1st, to take command of the 2nd Royal Irish Rifles. He was succeeded by Major W. G. Neilson,
name: Real College Essays

text: D.S.O., of the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders.
name: Real College Essays

text: Early in June we moved still further left and took over more of the J and K trenches, with
name: Real College Essays

text: the reserve company at Siege Farm, and Battalion Headquarters at Rossignol Farm. Our numbers
name: Real College Essays

text: at this time were swelled by the presence of a Company of the 8th King's Royal Rifle Corps
name: Real College Essays

text: who were attached for instruction--the first of Kitchener's Army that we had seen.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our severest handling in the Kemmel area occurred on the last day of our last tour there, and
name: Real College Essays

text: was begun by the blowing of enemy mines, a form of warfare which had already developed considerably
name: Real College Essays

text: at various points along the battle front. Tunnelling Companies of the Royal Engineers had been
name: Real College Essays

text: formed, but their numbers were not sufficient to cope with all the work, and in order to help
name: Real College Essays

text: them Mining Sections were formed in some of the Infantry Brigades as well. From the miners
name: Real College Essays

text: of the 139th Brigade, it was not difficult to select suitable men for this purpose, and towards
name: Real College Essays

text: the end of May, a small party was taken from the Battalion to join the Brigade Mining Section,
name: Real College Essays

text: which was put under the command of Capt. Piggford. Included in the party were Corpls. Boot
name: Real College Essays

text: and Attenborough, both of whom later received decorations for gallantry in underground work.
name: Real College Essays

text: These Brigade Sections were normally used for defensive mining only--broadly to prevent the
name: Real College Essays

text: enemy blowing up our trenches. The Royal Engineers' Tunnelling Companies on the other hand,
name: Real College Essays

text: were employed for offensive work in blowing up the enemy. Where mining was feared, sentries
name: Real College Essays

text: in the front line had to report at once if any suspicious sounds were heard, which might indicate
name: Real College Essays

text: that the enemy were mining in the neighbourhood, in order that protective measures might be
name: Real College Essays

text: taken. The J trenches, which varied from 30 to 70 yards away from those of the Boche, were
name: Real College Essays

text: mostly built on water-logged ground, where to sink shafts and drive galleries was not an easy
name: Real College Essays

text: task. Nevertheless, for some time signs and sounds had been reported which seemed to indicate
name: Real College Essays

text: that mining on the part of the enemy was going on in this very region. Attempts had, therefore,
name: Real College Essays

text: been made by us to sink shafts and take counter measures, but these had proved unavailing owing
name: Real College Essays

text: to the bad nature of the ground. The enemy, however, succeeded where we failed, and on June
name: Real College Essays

text: 15th, exploded three mines, one of which blew up a portion of J 3 Right. This took place at
name: Real College Essays

text: 9.10 p.m., when the 7th Battalion were just beginning to arrive to relieve us. At the same
name: Real College Essays

text: time a terrific fire was opened with artillery, trench mortars, rifle grenades, Machine Guns
name: Real College Essays

text: and rifles, and for over an hour an incessant cannonade was kept up on our front line, Support
name: Real College Essays

text: Company and Battalion Dump. Telephone wires were broken--an occurrence looked on later with
name: Real College Essays

text: less anxiety as it happened so often, and we had no S.O.S. signal; pigeon service, which had
name: Real College Essays

text: been established in the trenches just before this time, was, of course, of no avail for night
name: Real College Essays

text: work, and Battalion Headquarters were out of communication with the trenches except by runner.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our reply to the bombardment was almost negligible, and whatever the politicians and their
name: Real College Essays

text: statistics may prove, we know that our supply of gun ammunition at this time was totally inadequate.
name: Real College Essays

text: Some of the enemy got into the mine crater, but were driven out by C Company at the point of
name: Real College Essays

text: the bayonet. Pvte. J. Sharman, of B Company, who was practically the only man left in the trench
name: Real College Essays

text: when the enemy tried to occupy it, shot one and drove off another, both of them having attacked
name: Real College Essays

text: him at the same time. He was hit on the leg by a dud bomb, and got a bullet through his haversack.
name: Real College Essays

text: Excellent work was also done by Corpl. Humberstone in reorganising the garrison, and by L.-Corpl.
name: Real College Essays

text: Templeman and Pvte. Tongue in repairing telephone wires. Eventually things quietened down,
name: Real College Essays

text: and when the relief was complete, we returned to Locre for a few days' well-earned rest. Our
name: Real College Essays

text: casualties were unfortunately heavy, and included two excellent Officers, Eric Dobson and Humphrey
name: Real College Essays

text: Hollins, also Corpl. Wilcox and eight men killed, and 29 wounded, whilst the 6th King's Own
name: Real College Essays

text: Yorkshire Light Infantry, some of whom were in the trenches with us for instruction, also lost
name: Real College Essays

text: several men.
name: Real College Essays

text: This was one of the earliest raids that ever took place, and was planned doubtless to inflict
name: Real College Essays

text: casualties and secure prisoners, but not to capture trenches. One man of D Company is reported
name: Real College Essays

text: to have blamed this affair for the loss of a pair of boots, as he assured his Platoon Commander
name: Real College Essays

text: at a kit inspection a little later "that they were lost when that there mine at Kemmel went
name: Real College Essays

text: up!" As no man had more than one pair at a time the Platoon Commander scratched his head.
name: Real College Essays

text: Thus ended our stay in the Kemmel sector, which was taken over by the 50th (Northumbrian) Division.
name: Real College Essays

text: We were now beginning to feel quite "old hands," but our experience had been dearly bought.
name: Real College Essays

text: We had lost heavily and were sadly in need of a draft, for to balance our total casualties
name: Real College Essays

text: in other ranks of 49 killed or died of wounds, and 120 wounded, we had so far received only
name: Real College Essays

text: 20 reinforcements.
name: Real College Essays

text: The Corps paid a tribute to the work performed by the Brigade during our stay at Kemmel. Far
name: Real College Essays

text: more valuable, however, were our first experiences of trench warfare. The meaning and importance
name: Real College Essays

text: of responsibility and discipline were for the first time really impressed upon the minds of
name: Real College Essays

text: Officers and men alike. Gradually, if imperceptibly, they had learnt something of what would
name: Real College Essays

text: be required of them in the times of fighting ahead.
name: Real College Essays

text: Sometimes one is tempted to compare conditions at Kemmel with trench routine three years later.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the Kemmel days the Platoon Commander lived with his Platoon, and seldom even visited his
name: Real College Essays

text: Company Headquarters and he undoubtedly acquired an intimate knowledge of every man of his
name: Real College Essays

text: Platoon, which was never equalled in later days. This further bred a sense of responsibility
name: Real College Essays

text: and initiative which was all to the good at a time when comfort, safety and enterprise depended
name: Real College Essays

text: so largely on individual initiative. At the same time it must not be forgotten that in later
name: Real College Essays

text: days Officers and men alike were called upon to undertake more patrols and raids, and had to
name: Real College Essays

text: suffer far heavier and more incessant shelling and trench-mortaring than was our general experience
name: Real College Essays

text: at Kemmel.
name: Real College Essays

text: As a school of instruction our time at Kemmel undoubtedly provided a very valuable lesson not
name: Real College Essays

text: only to Officers, N.C.O.'s and men of the Battalion, but to Officers of the Brigade and Divisional
name: Real College Essays

text: Staffs, whose experience of the new form of warfare could hardly have been learnt under better
name: Real College Essays

text: conditions than those which obtained during our first two months of trench routine.
name: Real College Essays

text: The Canadian's description of it as "Bloody Ypres," referring doubtless to the Salient in general,
name: Real College Essays

text: was very apt, and will be endorsed by all who ever had the misfortune to sample it at any period
name: Real College Essays

text: of the war. We have never met anyone who boasted of having found a "cushy spot" in it, and
name: Real College Essays

text: so far as we ourselves were concerned, the three months spent in the Salient were very nearly,
name: Real College Essays

text: if not quite, the hardest months of the war.
name: Real College Essays

text: Leaving Locre on the evening of June 20th, we marched with the rest of the Brigade to the Ouderdom
name: Real College Essays

text: Huts on the Reninghelst--Vlamertinghe Road. These were the first "huts" ever occupied by the
name: Real College Essays

text: Battalion; they were absolutely exposed to view, the surroundings being open ploughed fields,
name: Real College Essays

text: and when the Boche "Sausage" went up "Silent Percy," a German long-range gun, warned anyone
name: Real College Essays

text: walking about that movement must cease. There were, however, deep shelter trenches round the
name: Real College Essays

text: huts, which afforded good protection, and we escaped without casualties, though the Transport
name: Real College Essays

text: having had a few shells in the horse lines, deemed it wise to move back a little. We left there
name: Real College Essays

text: on June 23rd, and marching via Kruistraat and Zillebeke proceeded to "Sanctuary Wood," where
name: Real College Essays

text: we relieved the 5th East Yorkshires in trenches 7 to 12. These trenches were good, being both
name: Real College Essays

text: narrow and deep. There was a good deal of liveliness on both sides, and things were anything
name: Real College Essays

text: but pleasant in the region of a wood. whose title was something of a misnomer. The Transport
name: Real College Essays

text: too, had many good runs for their money when bringing up rations and stores. The congestion
name: Real College Essays

text: on the road each night was intense. Only one bridge, "14," over the Ypres-Comines Canal was
name: Real College Essays

text: available for the transport of all units occupying the centre of the Salient, and the journey
name: Real College Essays

text: from the transport lines to the dump and back, took something approaching seven hours. We were
name: Real College Essays

text: not particularly envious of their job here on many occasions, though never once did they fail
name: Real College Essays

text: to get supplies up to the dump. This was at the South-West corner of "Sanctuary Wood," and
name: Real College Essays
