text: a very unhealthy spot, where we were lucky indeed in not getting very heavy casualties. There
name: Real College Essays

text: was hardly any water fit for drinking in the front area, so that one of the water carts had
name: Real College Essays

text: to be brought up full every night and left in the shelter of the wood, and the empty one taken
name: Real College Essays

text: back.
name: Real College Essays

text: Rain made the trenches very uncomfortable, and we had plenty to do in keeping them in order,
name: Real College Essays

text: and in building shelters, of which we were very short. These consisted for the most part of
name: Real College Essays

text: two or more waterproof sheets laced together, and held in position across the trench, by stones
name: Real College Essays

text: placed on the ends on the parapet and parados. Little was done by us in the way of active operations
name: Real College Essays

text: during our first tour, except a certain amount of patrolling, in which 2nd Lieut. Adams and
name: Real College Essays

text: Pvte. Needham were the leading lights, and got some useful information. A Company had rather
name: Real College Essays

text: a bad time, suffering over 20 casualties from "Whizz-bangs" (77 mm. shells) and salvoes of 5.9's.
name: Real College Essays

text: We were relieved on the night of June 29/30th, after a seven days' tour, by the 5th Lincolns,
name: Real College Essays

text: and moved back to bivouacs at a charming camp near Poperinghe, where we spent 12 of the most
name: Real College Essays

text: enjoyable days we ever had in France. The weather was glorious, and we made the most of it.
name: Real College Essays

text: We were spared strenuous work as far as possible on the very hot days, but carried out much
name: Real College Essays

text: useful training of a general kind, and reorganised and refitted all the units in the Battalion.
name: Real College Essays

text: Two new Officers, 2nd Lieuts. R. E. Hemingway, and E. S. Strachan joined us, the former eventually
name: Real College Essays

text: succeeding Lieut. A. Hacking, who had just been appointed our first Battalion Grenade Officer.
name: Real College Essays

text: A draft of 69 men also arrived, together with 11 rejoined men,--a most acceptable addition
name: Real College Essays

text: to our numbers. Several quite interesting cricket matches were played, the last of which, Officers
name: Real College Essays

text: v. N.C.O's., was won by the Officers. We managed one concert, which was given entirely by our
name: Real College Essays

text: own artistes, and went off very successfully. Poperinghe was quite close, and though possessing
name: Real College Essays

text: no great attraction, yet it was a change to walk or if possible get a horse for the afternoon
name: Real College Essays

text: and ride over there sometimes to see what was going on, and call on our little friend "Ginger"
name: Real College Essays

text: at the caf??, and do any shopping that was wanted. Here for the first time we encountered a
name: Real College Essays

text: Divisional Troupe, and enjoyed many a pleasant evening with the 6th Division "Fancies," with
name: Real College Essays

text: their Belgian artistes "Vaseline" and "Glycerine." But perhaps the greatest source of pleasure
name: Real College Essays

text: to all ranks now, was that great institution "Leave" which had just been started. True it was
name: Real College Essays

text: but four days, and for an extremely small number, but it was something after all, and encouraged
name: Real College Essays

text: those who were not lucky enough to have it at the moment, that their turn would eventually
name: Real College Essays

text: come to get out of the war for a brief space, and return to their families at home. Capt. Ashwell
name: Real College Essays

text: left us whilst we were here to take charge of reinforcements at St. Omer. During his absence
name: Real College Essays

text: of five or six weeks A Company was commanded by Lieut. J. V. Edge.
name: Real College Essays

text: We left camp with much regret on the afternoon of July 11th, and proceeding via Kruistraat,
name: Real College Essays

text: where a halt was made for tea, at the "White Ch?teau," we eventually took over trenches B 2,
name: Real College Essays

text: 3, 4, 7 and 8, in the Hooge sector, from the North Staffords. The trenches here were close
name: Real College Essays

text: together, at some points not more than 25 yards apart. This nearness necessitated in some cases
name: Real College Essays

text: the erection of small-mesh wire netting to prevent the enemy throwing hand-grenades into our
name: Real College Essays

text: trenches. Mining was carried on unceasingly, and with both sides displaying abnormal activity
name: Real College Essays

text: with every kind of war machine invented, life was not at all pleasant. Possibly we had the
name: Real College Essays

text: greatest dislike for the rifle grenades which the Hun was in the habit of showering over on
name: Real College Essays

text: every possible occasion, but his shelling of the whole of our sector, which he carried out
name: Real College Essays

text: with great regularity, was extremely uncomfortable, and casualties mounted rapidly. To the
name: Real College Essays

text: more normal means of trying to wear down the enemy, we were now able to add fixed rifles and
name: Real College Essays

text: rifle batteries. These were laid on definite targets, and fired according to a time table specially
name: Real College Essays

text: arranged, and we hope had the effect desired. Sergt.-Drummer Clewes too, in charge of the Brigade
name: Real College Essays

text: Sniping Section, was always worrying the Huns on every possible occasion, and made some splendid
name: Real College Essays

text: bags. Work in the trenches was of a more or less normal kind, consisting chiefly of strengthening
name: Real College Essays

text: fire and support trenches and putting out wire, not forgetting the never-ending efforts to
name: Real College Essays

text: drain away the water. Good patrols were carried out by Lieut. James and Corpl. Hotson.
name: Real College Essays

text: After a heavy tour of 12 days we were relieved on July 23rd, by the 7th Battalion, and marched
name: Real College Essays

text: back to bivouacs near Ouderdom, a long trek, the last Company not getting there until 7 a.m.
name: Real College Essays

text: the following morning. We were shelled out of this camp almost immediately, doubtless because
name: Real College Essays

text: a Staff Officer anxious for the comfort of the Officers had had four beautiful white tents
name: Real College Essays

text: put up. Unfortunately they had been pitched on the Eastern slope of the field in full view
name: Real College Essays

text: of the "Sausage" already mentioned, and "Silent Percy" soon got busy! On July 25th, we took
name: Real College Essays

text: over another field near Busseboom, where we were left in peace, so far as the Hun was concerned,
name: Real College Essays

text: though as the field had just previously been used by Gunners for horse lines we had in other
name: Real College Essays

text: ways quite a lively time. Here we were joined by 2nd Lieut. Everard Handford and an excellent
name: Real College Essays

text: draft from the 2/8th Battalion.
name: Real College Essays

text: We had little time during this six days' rest to do more than the usual refitting and cleaning,
name: Real College Essays

text: as large fatigue parties were required on two days for Divisional work. Bathing was an easier
name: Real College Essays

text: matter, as we were now able to use the new Divisional baths at "Pop." So far as the washing
name: Real College Essays

text: of clothing was concerned, the men did their own, laundries being very few and far between.
name: Real College Essays

text: We had now in front of us what turned out to be the longest and most trying of all the Battalion's
name: Real College Essays

text: experiences in the trenches, for after relieving the 7th Battalion in trenches B 3, 4, 7, and
name: Real College Essays

text: 8 at "Sanctuary Wood" on the night of July 29/30th, we did not get out for 19 days.
name: Real College Essays

text: Col. Fowler at this time was on leave, whilst Major A. C. Clarke was unfit, and a little later
name: Real College Essays

text: had to return to England. Major Becher, who succeeded him as Second-in-Command was, therefore,
name: Real College Essays

text: in temporary command of the Battalion. Much to our regret our old friend "Doc" Stallard had
name: Real College Essays

text: also just left us for a tour of home duty. Well had he stuck it all through, but he was beginning
name: Real College Essays

text: to feel the strain of his strenuous duties, which were now taken over by Surgeon-Lieut. C.
name: Real College Essays

text: B. Johnstone. The latter had a memorable journey to join the Battalion, which was then in the
name: Real College Essays

text: line, riding up on the front of the horse ambulance that used to go nightly to "Maple Copse"
name: Real College Essays

text: to evacuate the previous twenty-four hours' wounded. The road was very rough and mostly shell
name: Real College Essays

text: holes full of water, and he had a decidedly rough passage. Other arrivals about this time included
name: Real College Essays

text: three new subalterns, Lieut. C. M. Houfton, and 2nd Lieuts. R. V. Harvey and A. H. Date, whose
name: Real College Essays

text: first experience of trench warfare was to be rather more exciting than the average! Comp. Sergt.-Major
name: Real College Essays

text: J. A. Green was temporarily acting as Regimental Sergt.-Major in place of Sergt.-Major Westerman,
name: Real College Essays

text: who had just left for England.
name: Real College Essays

text: The trench system taken over ran partly on the outskirts of "Sanctuary Wood," and partly through
name: Real College Essays

text: the wood itself, which in those days was most picturesque, with delightful wild flowers and
name: Real College Essays

text: thick undergrowth. The right was held by B Company (Lieut. J. W. Turner) and C Company (Capt.
name: Real College Essays

text: G. S. Heathcote) and the left by D Company (Lieut. E. C. A. James), whilst A Company (Lieut.
name: Real College Essays

text: J. V. Edge) were in reserve. By a very happy coincidence, we had with us A Company of the 10th
name: Real College Essays

text: Sherwood Foresters, sent into the line for the first time for instruction. Capt. G. P. Goodall,
name: Real College Essays

text: subsequently killed at St. Eloi, was in charge of this Company, amongst whom our men found
name: Real College Essays

text: many friends.
name: Real College Essays

text: We occupied the left of the 46th Divisional sector, with the 5th Battalion on our right, the
name: Real College Essays

text: 7th Battalion in immediate support in "Maple Copse," and the 6th Battalion in Brigade Reserve.
name: Real College Essays

text: The 14th Division, which had only been in France a few weeks, and had been with us for instruction
name: Real College Essays

text: at Kemmel, had recently taken over the sector on our left, where there had been much fighting
name: Real College Essays

text: during the past few weeks for the possession of Hooge, which centred about the stables and
name: Real College Essays

text: wall running near the Ch?teau. It was there that in our last tour we had seen a brilliant assault
name: Real College Essays

text: by the Gordons and Middlesex, after a terrific mine explosion.
name: Real College Essays

text: At 3.30 a.m. on July 30th, immediately after stand-down, and within a few hours of our arrival
name: Real College Essays

text: in the trenches, on a perfect summer morning, the whole of the wood was suddenly surrounded
name: Real College Essays

text: by a ring of fire, while at the same time a heavy bombardment was opened, concentrating apparently
name: Real College Essays

text: on the trenches around "Hooge Crater." Under cover of this bombardment, and behind "flammenwerfer,"
name: Real College Essays

text: the enemy attacked the point of the salient held by C Company, at the same time throwing the
name: Real College Essays

text: greater weight of his forces against the Hooge sector occupied by units of the 14th Division.
name: Real College Essays

text: The latter, who like ourselves had only come into the line the night before, were undoubtedly
name: Real College Essays

text: surprised by the sudden attack, and by this first use of "flammenwerfer." Their men, dead tired,
name: Real College Essays

text: had just got down to sleep, and the rapidity of the enemy attack left little opportunity for
name: Real College Essays

text: organising successful defence.
name: Real College Essays

text: The result was that the enemy succeeded at once in gaining the whole of the front and support
name: Real College Essays

text: trenches on our left, pushing forward into the North end of the wood, and threatening to cut
name: Real College Essays

text: off the whole of the salient, and leaving the trenches held by D Company in imminent danger
name: Real College Essays

text: of being turned from the rear.
name: Real College Essays

text: The first attack on the point of the salient was driven off by rifle and machine gun fire.
name: Real College Essays

text: Here Pvte. Grantham displayed conspicuous gallantry in remaining at his post, in spite of being
name: Real College Essays

text: surrounded by flames, and killing several of the enemy at close quarters. Very few of the enemy
name: Real College Essays

text: succeeded in getting into our lines, though for a short space of time there was a dangerous
name: Real College Essays

text: gap on the left of C Company, which was filled up by the presence of mind of 2nd Lieut. Hindley
name: Real College Essays

text: and Sergts. Sheppard and Smith, and a platoon of B Company, one of whom, Pvte. Tyne, did particularly
name: Real College Essays

text: fine execution by throwing back unexploded enemy bombs. This platoon lined the parapet, and
name: Real College Essays

text: by opening rapid fire prevented the attack from developing. Unfortunately, an enemy machine
name: Real College Essays

text: gun traversed the parapet, killing many of the men of this gallant platoon, until a bomb thrown
name: Real College Essays

text: a prodigious distance by Sergt. G. F. Foster appears to have fallen on the top of it, evidently
name: Real College Essays

text: knocking it out, and by the volume of smoke produced wrecking a "flammenwerfer." Several of
name: Real College Essays

text: the enemy were seen to be killed or wounded by this lucky bomb.
name: Real College Essays

text: Further attacks by the enemy on the point of the salient were made during the day, and a more
name: Real College Essays

text: serious one early next morning, but they were readily driven off with loss. We should like
name: Real College Essays

text: here to pay a tribute to the magnificent courage and coolness of the men of the 10th Battalion,
name: Real College Essays

text: which contributed very largely to the entire defeat of the enemy's attack on this front.
name: Real College Essays

text: Meanwhile the position on the left was uncertain and very alarming, and Sergt. A. Phillipson
name: Real College Essays

text: in particular, in command of the left platoon, No. 13, had a most anxious and trying time.
name: Real College Essays

text: Elements of the 14th Division straggled from the left with stories of the German advance. These
name: Real College Essays

text: accounts might easily have demoralised our Battalion but for the magnificent example of Lieut.
name: Real College Essays

text: James, his Second-in-Command, 2nd Lieut. Vann and Sergt. A. Phillipson, and the coolness and
name: Real College Essays

text: courage of every man of D Company. The situation on this flank was serious indeed. All the
name: Real College Essays

text: trenches on the left had been captured, and the enemy were reported as pushing into the wood
name: Real College Essays

text: in the rear of our trenches. James acted promptly, and immediately pushed out a left flank-guard.
name: Real College Essays

text: Major Becher at Headquarters sent forward reinforcements from the Reserve Company, and eventually
name: Real College Essays

text: the 7th Battalion from "Maple Copse" were despatched by Brigade and did splendid work in spite
name: Real College Essays

text: of heavy shelling, in digging a switch line connecting the trenches in the neighbourhood of
name: Real College Essays

text: Zouave Wood to our left flank.
name: Real College Essays

text: Early in the afternoon the Reserve Brigade of the 14th Division, who had only reached bivouacs
name: Real College Essays

text: near Poperinghe at three in the morning, returned and made a gallant but fruitless counter-attack
name: Real College Essays

text: to recover the lost trenches. Could it have been expected that men, who had been in the trenches
name: Real College Essays

text: for a week, marched back during the night no less than 12 miles, only to turn once more, march
name: Real College Essays

text: back those interminable 12 miles, part of the time under heavy shell fire, dog-tired, without
name: Real College Essays

text: sleep or food, could without adequate artillery preparation perform a feat which later required
name: Real College Essays

text: a Division of fresh troops, after one of the most carefully planned and destructive bombardments
name: Real College Essays

text: at that time known? The Brigade could but have failed, and to the onlooker it seemed a tragic
name: Real College Essays

text: blunder, but to those who have read the pathetic story of a tragic day, the title given by
name: Real College Essays

text: The Student in Arms of "The Honour of the Brigade" alone provides the excuse for an operation
name: Real College Essays

text: which from every other point of view, was one of the costly blunders of the war.
name: Real College Essays

text: On August 9th, the 6th Division attacked after a very heavy bombardment and re-established
name: Real College Essays

text: the situation. No troops could have done finer work. The enemy who had manned the redoubtable
name: Real College Essays

text: Hooge Crater in great strength, suffered very heavily, but the total prisoners captured in
name: Real College Essays

text: a hard fought attack amounted to five. The 2nd Sherwood Foresters, under that magnificent Officer
name: Real College Essays

text: Col. Hobbs, who in pre-war days had at one time been Adjutant of our Battalion, eventually
name: Real College Essays

text: endeavoured to hold the crater on our left, but this was soon found to be untenable, and remained
name: Real College Essays

text: in No Man's Land.
name: Real College Essays

text: An incident which is not without its humour, while illustrating the tiredness of our men, may
name: Real College Essays

text: be worth recalling. During the bombardment preliminary to the counter-attack, when the noise
name: Real College Essays

text: of our own artillery was deafening, and the proximity of the enemy shelling far from assuring,
name: Real College Essays

text: a platoon commander discovered one of his men fast asleep on the firestep. With some difficulty
name: Real College Essays

text: he was aroused and, rubbing his eyes, he exclaimed, not without a certain degree of indignation
name: Real College Essays

text: that his slumbers had been cut short--"What's oop?"
name: Real College Essays

text: Our casualties during the activities of July 30th and 31st, amounted to 21 killed and 40 wounded,
name: Real College Essays

text: and the 10th Battalion had ten casualties in addition. This total was increased from day to
name: Real College Essays

text: day by incessant shelling, trench mortars and rifle grenades, and by the unfortunate inaccuracy
name: Real College Essays

text: of one of our 6-inch naval guns, which persisted in firing into our trenches until its identity
name: Real College Essays

text: was eventually discovered. During the first fortnight in the line here, our casualties were
name: Real College Essays

text: no fewer than four Officers wounded (Vann, E. M. Hacking, Hindley and G. G. Elliott); 36 other
name: Real College Essays

text: ranks killed, or died of wounds, and 90 wounded. Included amongst the killed were Sergt. A.
name: Real College Essays

text: Phillipson, who throughout had shewn the utmost coolness and gallantry, and Sergt. E. Layhe,
name: Real College Essays

text: who had done very good work as Scout Sergeant. "Jimmy" James, who had struggled on manfully
name: Real College Essays

text: in spite of being very unfit, eventually had to give up and go to hospital, D Company being
name: Real College Essays

text: taken over by Vann.
name: Real College Essays

text: During these days there was much active patrolling in order to make certain of the dispositions
name: Real College Essays

text: of the enemy, and much daring work was carried out by Lieuts. Vann, Turner, and H. B. S. Handford,
name: Real College Essays

text: 2nd Lieuts. A. & E. M. Hacking, Corpl. Gadd, L.-Corpl. Wilson, and Pvtes. Nicholson and Thompson.
name: Real College Essays

text: Vann in particular was much in the good books of General Allenby, the Corps Commander, for
name: Real College Essays

text: his splendid work, though he was once the cause of his very nearly spoiling an immaculate pair
name: Real College Essays

text: of breeches when showing him with much glee a particularly un-get-at-able loophole plate in
name: Real College Essays

text: a very muddy trench. We are led to believe, however, that this crime was forgiven, as Vann
name: Real College Essays

text: was later honoured by the General with an invitation to dinner.
name: Real College Essays

text: Apart from shelling, which continued intermittently, the rest of our stay in the line was uneventful.
name: Real College Essays

text: It was not, however, until August 17th, that the Battalion, reduced in numbers but tried at
name: Real College Essays

text: last in real fighting, were relieved by the 7th Battalion, and marched back to bivouacs near
name: Real College Essays

text: Ouderdom, dead tired but happy in the thought that they could hand over intact the trenches
name: Real College Essays

text: which they had taken over three weeks before.
name: Real College Essays

text: The attack had evidently not been an attempt to break through. The enemy no doubt had hoped
name: Real College Essays

text: to seize our front line system from the right of B 4 trench northwards. There can be no doubt
name: Real College Essays

text: that had this succeeded the difficulty of the counter-attack would have been largely increased.
name: Real College Essays

text: Indeed, at a time when troops could ill have been spared, it is probable that the Ypres Salient
name: Real College Essays

text: would have been considerably reduced, and the morale of the enemy proportionately increased.
name: Real College Essays

text: This was pointed out by General Allenby, who, addressing the Battalion on parade on August
name: Real College Essays

text: 25th, said: "I have read with great pleasure and pride the report of the General commanding
name: Real College Essays

text: your Division, telling of the arduous work which you recently did in the neighbourhood of Hooge.
name: Real College Essays

text: By your boldness, tenacity, and gallantry, you did work of very great importance. Perhaps you
name: Real College Essays

text: do not know that not only did your action have an important bearing on that particular bit
name: Real College Essays

text: of line, but on the whole campaign, because of the political reason for holding the Salient.
name: Real College Essays

text: The town of Ypres is nothing to us, but if the Boche took it they would publish it to the world
name: Real College Essays

text: that they had captured the fortress of Ypres, which we have held since November, 1914."
name: Real College Essays

text: The Battalion also received the special thanks of the Field Marshal Commanding-in-Chief on
name: Real College Essays

text: their efforts during the tour. To the delight of everyone, especially all ranks of B Company,
name: Real College Essays

text: John Becher was awarded the D.S.O., a very well-deserved honour for most splendid work whilst
name: Real College Essays

text: in command of the Battalion, during one of the most anxious periods in its history; Vann for
name: Real College Essays

text: his gallantry here and previously at Kemmel got the M.C. Mention must also be made of the splendid
name: Real College Essays

text: work of our new Medical Officer (Johnstone), his assistants Corpls. Sissons, Martin, and Bescoby,
name: Real College Essays

text: and all the stretcher-bearers, who worked indefatigably day and night, often in circumstances
name: Real College Essays

text: of great personal risk in dressing and evacuating the wounded, not only of our own Battalion,
name: Real College Essays

text: but of the King's Royal Rifle Corps, the Rifle Brigade, and the 2nd Sherwood Foresters. In
name: Real College Essays

text: these operations they established a reputation for gallantry and devotion to duty which in
name: Real College Essays

text: the whole Brigade was conspicuous throughout the war.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our bivouacs were in a nice spot sheltered from view by a small wood. Our rest was not a long
name: Real College Essays

text: one, and was much of the usual type, but had an additional interest in that we were fortunate
name: Real College Essays

text: in getting two very good entertainments from the 46th Divisional Concert Party, the "Whizzbangs,"
name: Real College Essays

text: which had lately been formed, and was to be a source of much pleasure from now on to the end
name: Real College Essays

text: of the war. Whilst there we were joined by two new Officers, 2nd Lieuts. A. H. G. C. Moore
name: Real College Essays

text: and P. C. Hemingway, and 107 other ranks, but we wanted men badly now, as in addition to our
name: Real College Essays

text: heavy casualties in the line, we lost during the month of August 41 N.C.O's. and men, whose
name: Real College Essays

text: term of enlistment expired on the completion of one year's war service. These included many
name: Real College Essays

text: old hands who were difficult to replace.
name: Real College Essays

text: On August 29th, we took over trenches at "Middlesex Wood," where the Brigade were holding the
name: Real College Essays

text: line astride the Ypres-Comines Canal, near St. Eloi, and there we stayed, with one short rest
name: Real College Essays

text: in bivouacs, for a month of more or less normal trench warfare. Perhaps the main points of
name: Real College Essays

text: interest were that we were covered by Belgian gunners, who were not too particular where or
name: Real College Essays

text: when they fired, that we were now getting a supply of sniperscopes (specially constructed rifles,
name: Real College Essays

text: fitted with periscopes, for firing from a trench without looking directly over the parapet),
name: Real College Essays

text: which formed most useful additions to our trench stores, and seemed to cause the enemy considerable
name: Real College Essays

text: annoyance, and that we were able on one or two occasions to make good practice with Col. Fowler's
name: Real College Essays

text: Elephant Gun against some of the enemy's loophole plates. On September 25th, in conjunction
name: Real College Essays

text: with attacks by the French and British, on various other parts of the Western front, we had
name: Real College Essays

text: to "demonstrate" by means of artillery, machine gun and rifle fire, and a dummy gas and smoke
name: Real College Essays

text: attack, which was to be provided by burning on the parapet of the front line trenches large
name: Real College Essays

text: quantities of damp straw, which had been carried up with much labour, and a good deal of very
name: Real College Essays

text: frank comment. Much to the relief of those intimately concerned with this bonfire, the wind
name: Real College Essays

text: on the day of the attack was unfavourable, and the straw at least did not end in smoke. The
name: Real College Essays

text: demonstration provided some amusement to our Grenadiers, who, with the assistance of a "Gamage"
name: Real College Essays

text: catapult, and two West Spring Throwers succeeded, to their immense delight in bursting the
name: Real College Essays

text: old B??thune bomb as shrapnel over the German trenches. It was only when the last bomb was thrown
name: Real College Essays

text: that Sergt. G. F. Foster, the stoutest Bomber that ever lived and fell, ended a demonstration
name: Real College Essays

text: which can hardly have caused a flutter in the dove-cotes of the German Higher Command.
name: Real College Essays

text: Here, as on many other occasions, all ranks would have worked more intelligently, and with
name: Real College Essays

text: greater personal satisfaction, if they had known something of the general plan, and the part
name: Real College Essays

text: they were being asked to play. This plan really must have been a big thing, for some one was
name: Real College Essays

text: kind enough to send us a lot of literature on such subjects as "How to guard against spies
name: Real College Essays

text: in newly captured territory," and generally how to behave there; whilst maps and other documents
name: Real College Essays

text: gave us the most intricate detail of every well, and other supply of water for at least 20
name: Real College Essays

text: miles East of where we were. Evidently the sender was an optimist!
name: Real College Essays

text: On the 30th September, the 8th Lincolns took over from us in support in the Canal dug-outs.
name: Real College Essays

text: The enemy having already given us an extremely unpleasant afternoon chose this very inconvenient
name: Real College Essays

text: occasion for "putting up" a mine under the trenches held by the 6th Battalion, on the South
name: Real College Essays

text: side of the Canal. This operation and the accompanying bombardment involved a stand-to, and
name: Real College Essays

text: caused a certain number of casualties both in the trenches and among the troops in the support
name: Real College Essays

text: dug-outs. The relief was, however, duly carried out, and the Battalion marched back to tents
name: Real College Essays

text: near Ouderdom in the early hours of October 1st, where a little later in the day General Allenby
name: Real College Essays

text: came to say goodbye and wish us luck in our new sphere of action.
name: Real College Essays

text: We had previously, on September 21st, had the honour of being inspected by General Plumer,
name: Real College Essays

text: commanding the Second Army, who expressed himself as very satisfied with the smart turnout
name: Real College Essays

text: of the Battalion. We were still very weak, though we had continued to receive small drafts
name: Real College Essays

text: of reinforcements, and had been joined by five new Officers, 2nd Lieuts. G. H. F. Payling,
name: Real College Essays

text: R. T. Skinner, R. A. Abrams, G. H. Fisher, and C. Pickerell; "Dolly" Gray also came out again
name: Real College Essays

text: and rejoined. We had, however, lost Capt. Collin, the Adjutant, who had just left to take up
name: Real College Essays

text: a Staff Captaincy, and his place after being held for a few days by Lieut. A. Hacking, was
name: Real College Essays

text: now taken by Lieut. Weetman, who had just rejoined. Capt. Piggford had gone home sick, and
name: Real College Essays

text: 2nd Lieut. P. C. Hemingway wounded; and we had also recently lost M. Lacolle, our one and only
name: Real College Essays

text: Battalion Interpreter. Henceforth we were not to be allowed this luxury.
name: Real College Essays

text: It is, perhaps, not out of place to mention here an interesting little episode which had taken
name: Real College Essays

text: place at home, namely the depositing of the Colours in Newark Parish Church. This ceremony
name: Real College Essays

text: was carried out on July 24th, and was attended by the Mayor and Corporation of Newark. Lieut.-Col.
name: Real College Essays

text: G. S. Foljambe was in charge of the parade, and Capt. R. F. B. Hodgkinson commanded the escort
name: Real College Essays

text: to the Colours, which were carried by 2nd Lieuts. R. J. Shipley and C. Pickerell.
name: Real College Essays

text: We packed up during the afternoon of October 1st, and in the evening marched to Abeele, where
name: Real College Essays

text: we entrained for a destination unknown to most of us, but presumed to be somewhere in the far
name: Real College Essays

text: South. We made ourselves as comfortable as we could for the expected long journey, only to
name: Real College Essays

text: be rudely awakened after what seemed to be a five minutes' sleep, and turned out into the cold
name: Real College Essays

text: dark night at Fouquereuil, a suburb of B??thune. The remainder of the night was spent at a somewhat
name: Real College Essays

text: elusive Orphanage in the town itself. On the following day we moved into billets at the Northern
name: Real College Essays

text: end of the town on the banks of the La Bass??e Canal, where we were joined by the Transport
name: Real College Essays

text: which had come from Ouderdom by road. October 3rd saw us once more on the move to Mont Bernenchon,
name: Real College Essays

text: a clean, attractive little village, a few miles N.W. of B??thune. Our hopes of spending a day
name: Real College Essays

text: or two in peace were soon shattered, for on the following day we made what seemed to be another
name: Real College Essays

text: emergency move to B??thune, where we embussed for regions unknown. Shortly after dark we arrived
name: Real College Essays

text: at Vermelles, and picked up guides, who led us as only guides can, to what proved to be a portion
name: Real College Essays

text: of the German front line system captured in the fighting a few days before. The trenches, which
name: Real College Essays

text: were near the "Lone Tree," and within sight of the famous "Tower Bridge" at Loos, were little
name: Real College Essays

text: damaged, and seemed to have been captured without a great deal of fighting, but the incessant
name: Real College Essays

text: rain and scarcity of habitable dug-outs made our stay as uncomfortable as the most hardened
name: Real College Essays

text: stoic could have desired. Our work consisted of reversing portions of the original German support
name: Real College Essays

text: trench to form a fire trench facing the other way. Owing to the distance to the then German
name: Real College Essays

text: line (1,000 to 1,500 yards) and the low visibility, we were able to work openly and practically
name: Real College Essays

text: unmolested. Our only casualties were the result of an unlucky shell which fell on the morning
name: Real College Essays

text: of October 5th, amongst a party of Signallers, killing L.-Sergt. C. E. Harrison, Signalling
name: Real College Essays

text: Sergeant, and three men, whilst another man died of wounds a few days later.
name: Real College Essays

text: The same evening we got orders to leave the trenches, and after a thoroughly unpleasant tramp,
name: Real College Essays

text: in heavy rain and thick darkness over the slippery chalk tracks, which were guess-work to most
name: Real College Essays

text: of us, we arrived soon after midnight at Mazingarbe, which for dirt, damp, and general cheerlessness,
name: Real College Essays

text: almost rivalled our never-to-be-forgotten billets at Bac-St. Maur. So ended a beastly, tiring,
name: Real College Essays

text: and, for all we ever learned, quite purposeless expedition.
name: Real College Essays

text: After a short meal and much needed rest we felt fit for anything, and made light of the trek
name: Real College Essays

text: on the early morning of October 6th, to our rest billets, which we found at Fouqui?res, a nice
name: Real College Essays

text: clean little village about a mile west of B??thune. Here we found ourselves, for a short time,
name: Real College Essays

text: in peace and something approaching luxury.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our move South had brought us into the First Army (General Haig) and XI Corps. (Lt.-General
name: Real College Essays

text: Haking), which had been busy in the recent fighting, and we now learned definitely for the
name: Real College Essays

text: first time that in the further fighting that was shortly to take place we were to play a prominent
name: Real College Essays

text: part. On Saturday, October 9th, preliminary orders and plans were issued, and we learned that
name: Real College Essays

text: our task was to be the capture of the "Hohenzollern Redoubt" and "Fosse 8," an admirably constructed
name: Real College Essays

text: scale model of which had been made on the ground outside Divisional Headquarters at Gosnay,
name: Real College Essays

text: where Officers and N.C.O.'s (and stray inhabitants) spent some time in a careful and interested
name: Real College Essays

text: examination of it.
name: Real College Essays

text: In addition, a somewhat hurried reconnaissance of the position itself was made by Col. Fowler
name: Real College Essays

text: and the Company Commanders from our trenches in front of Vermelles, from which the attack was
name: Real College Essays

text: to be made. In the short space of a couple of hours they endeavoured to get a working knowledge
name: Real College Essays

text: of the maze of communication trenches, and the hostile ground over which, if all went well,
name: Real College Essays

text: we should have to advance. Sunday was spent in Church Parade, and in going again through the
name: Real College Essays

text: preliminary orders and plans, and in the afternoon the Corps Commander interviewed the Officers
name: Real College Essays

text: of the Division at Divisional Headquarters. We were then told something more as to the reason
name: Real College Essays

text: and general plan of the attack, and were informed that we should be supported by the heaviest
name: Real College Essays

text: concentration of artillery yet known in the war--400 guns of all calibres,--that all contingencies
name: Real College Essays

text: had been provided for, and that in spite of the strength of the position, we should probably
name: Real College Essays

text: encounter very little opposition before reaching our objective.
name: Real College Essays

text: The object of the attack, which was to be undertaken by the XI Corps, was to establish the
name: Real College Essays

text: left flank of the First Army, and to render possible a further advance in conjunction with
name: Real College Essays

text: the French on the South. The objective included the "Quarries" and Fosse 8, the 46th Division
name: Real College Essays

text: being allotted the task of capturing the Hohenzollern Redoubt and Fosse 8, whilst the 12th
name: Real College Essays

text: Division was to attack on our right, and be responsible for the Quarries. The Fosse and surroundings
name: Real College Essays

text: had already been in our hands once, having been attacked and captured during the last week
name: Real College Essays

text: in September by the 9th Division, who unfortunately, however, had been compelled to withdraw,
name: Real College Essays

text: and a subsequent attempt by the 28th Division to recapture it had also proved a dismal failure.
name: Real College Essays

text: What, we wondered, was in store for the 46th Division?
name: Real College Essays

text: Fosse 8 is, or rather was, a typical colliery pit, with the usual winding and head gear and
name: Real College Essays

text: other plant, and pit-head pile of slag (called in this case "The Dump"), which like its neighbour,
name: Real College Essays

text: the famous Tower of Wingles, overlooked the whole position, whilst in rear there were the usual
name: Real College Essays

text: rows of miners' cottages. These cottages (called "Corons") had cellars, and were thus very
name: Real College Essays

text: easy to defend with machine guns, which could fire with great effect, and comparative safety,
name: Real College Essays

text: from ground level. In front of the Fosse and protecting it lay the Hohenzollern Redoubt, consisting
name: Real College Essays

text: of a salient trench system shaped rather like a big bean, and projecting well in front of the
name: Real College Essays

text: German main system, to which it was connected by communication trenches, and by two flank trenches
name: Real College Essays

text: known as "Big Willie" and "Little Willie." The importance of the position lay in the fact that
name: Real College Essays

text: it was on the top of a gentle rise, giving command and good observation of our position on
name: Real College Essays

text: either side. Its capture was rendered difficult by the fact that the ground in front of it
name: Real College Essays

text: was level, and almost devoid of cover, affording a very fine field of fire, which could be
name: Real College Essays

text: swept from practically every direction. From our trenches very little could be seen except
name: Real College Essays

text: the Dump, and the roof of the manager's house.
name: Real College Essays

text: The attack was to be carried out by the 137th Brigade on the right under Brigadier-General
name: Real College Essays

text: E. Feetham, C.B., and the 138th Brigade on the left under Brigadier-General G. C. Kemp, whilst
name: Real College Essays

text: the 139th Brigade were to be in Divisional Reserve under Brigadier-General C. T. Shipley. The
name: Real College Essays

text: covering Artillery consisted of three groups of heavy Artillery under the Corps Commander,
name: Real College Essays

text: and one group of Divisional Artillery (six Brigades of 18-pounders, and one Brigade of 4.5
name: Real College Essays

text: Howitzers).
name: Real College Essays

text: To his immense pleasure, 2nd Lieut. R. E. Hemingway, our Battalion Grenade Officer, was put
name: Real College Essays

text: in charge of the Grenadiers attached to the 138th Brigade, the party also including the Battalion
name: Real College Essays

text: Grenadier Sergeant, G. F. Foster. Bombing was now entering on the period of its greatest importance--always
name: Real College Essays

text: in our humble opinion greatly exaggerated. The Mills bomb was rapidly ousting all other kinds,
name: Real College Essays

text: and shortly became almost the only one in normal use. Much time was put in at throwing practice,
name: Real College Essays

text: and every kind of artifice was adopted by instructors to make it interesting, and at the same
name: Real College Essays

text: time improve the aim and distance thrown. A "platoon" of "grenadiers," as they were at first
name: Real College Essays

text: called, was formed in each Battalion, consisting of a Grenadier Officer, a sergeant and 32
name: Real College Essays

text: men, (eight from each Company), and to show how much we respected them, we put them when on
name: Real College Essays

text: the march at the head of the Battalion. There was a Brigade Grenadier Officer too, who made
name: Real College Essays

text: himself generally responsible for the training and work of Grenadiers throughout the Brigade.
name: Real College Essays

text: The first Officer appointed to this post in our Brigade was Lieut. A. Hacking, who had taken
name: Real College Essays

text: over the duties just before the Hohenzollern battle. The task allotted to the Grenadiers in
name: Real College Essays

text: this fight, was to bomb the various communication trenches leading from "West Face" to "Fosse
name: Real College Essays

text: Trench," clear dug-outs and establish blocks in "Fosse Alley."
name: Real College Essays

text: Information regarding the enemy, gained by Corps Intelligence during the attacks of September
name: Real College Essays

text: 25th, and following days from our own Officers, and from the examination of prisoners, was
name: Real College Essays

text: to the effect that the enemy trenches in the Redoubt, with the exception of "Dump Trench" and
name: Real College Essays

text: South Face, were badly damaged and not strongly wired, that previous attacks had been exposed
name: Real College Essays

text: to heavy enfilade fire from "Mad Point" or "Madagascar," that it was not thought there would
name: Real College Essays

text: be much enfilade fire from the South-East, and that it was not necessary to waste a lot of
name: Real College Essays

text: heavy shell on the Dump, as it could be made untenable by both sides. How far this was justifiable
name: Real College Essays

text: will be seen.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our few days at Fouqui?res passed very quickly in the bustle of completing equipment, going
name: Real College Essays

text: again and again with all ranks through the maps and plans of attack, detailing and organising
name: Real College Essays

text: bombing squads in the place of those detached for duty with the other Brigades, and writing
name: Real College Essays

text: last letters home "in case----" There was little or no excitement. We had most of us seen too
name: Real College Essays

text: much by this time to be either unduly pessimistic or over-confident about our own chances,
name: Real College Essays

text: so that everything seemed to go quietly and smoothly. The first steel helmets had just arrived--quaint,
name: Real College Essays

text: antique, Japanese looking things, with ingenious corrugations to catch the bullets--and were
name: Real College Essays

text: issued to the Machine Gunners, who had also received the first supply of the new Box Respirator,
name: Real College Essays

text: issued in place of the Smoke Helmet. The Machine Gun section was now commanded by Lieut. Adams.
name: Real College Essays

text: It was at 3.45 p.m. on October 12th, after making our final inspections and collecting blankets,
name: Real College Essays

text: packs and other surplus stores at a convenient barn, that we moved off from Fouqui?res on a
name: Real College Essays

text: fine Autumn afternoon, leaving behind only 2nd Lieut. Gray, and a few odd men, who were not
name: Real College Essays

text: fit to go into action. Transport marched in rear of the Battalion to temporary lines behind
name: Real College Essays

text: Noyelles, where it remained until after the battle.
name: Real College Essays

text: We had a very pleasant and easy march up to Vermelles, where a halt was made for tea. Here
name: Real College Essays

text: we were passed by one of the Stafford Battalions who were to make the assault. It was too dark
name: Real College Essays

text: to see their faces, but their voices were full of confidence and cheeriness, which it did one
name: Real College Essays

text: good to hear.
name: Real College Essays

text: A temporary Quarter-Master's Stores was fitted up at "Clarke's Keep," Vermelles, where Companies
name: Real College Essays

text: picked up their rations for the 13th, water in petrol tins, grenades, Vermorel sprayers, and
name: Real College Essays

text: other odds and ends likely to be required. An emergency ration of cold bacon and bread was
name: Real College Essays

text: also issued.
name: Real College Essays

text: Eventually after a very slow march through Vermelles, which was a seething mass of men and
name: Real College Essays

text: transport, we arrived about 11 p.m. at our assembly position in "Sussex Trench," where space
name: Real College Essays

text: was allotted to us by Lieut. C. L. Hill, Signalling Officer, who had gone on ahead with a few
name: Real College Essays

text: Signallers for that purpose. We soon settled down and made the best we could of what remained
name: Real College Essays

text: of the night. This was not long, for the carrying parties for the 138th Brigade, and others
name: Real College Essays

text: had to report for duty at Clarke's Keep at 6 a.m. on October 13th. In all we provided a total
name: Real College Essays

text: of five Officers and 300 other ranks for this duty, and they were busy most of the morning
name: Real College Essays

text: taking up to the front line such necessary articles as rations, water, grenades, and rum. His
name: Real College Essays

text: devotion to the last-named duty was too much for one bloodthirsty, but very ill-disciplined
name: Real College Essays

text: member of the Battalion, who became "non-effective" in consequence, and was reported by someone,
name: Real College Essays

text: who saw him lying in the bottom of a communication trench, as "dead--shot through the head."
name: Real College Essays

text: He was "dead" right enough, but he lived to fight--and, it is feared to "die" again--another day!
name: Real College Essays

text: Our artillery fire during the morning was normal, "so as not to arouse the suspicions of the
name: Real College Essays

text: Germans," who, as a fact, probably knew quite as much as most of us about the time and nature
name: Real College Essays

text: of our attack. But at 12.0 noon, every gun began in real earnest, and it was possible to stand
name: Real College Essays

text: on the firestep of our trench, and get an undisturbed, if rather distant, view of the shells
name: Real College Essays

text: bursting all over the German trenches. After half-an-hour of this most unusual, but very pleasing
name: Real College Essays

text: spectacle, one felt that there would be little left for us to attack.
name: Real College Essays

text: At 1 p.m. the greenish yellow clouds of smoke and chlorine gas (known for some time as "The
name: Real College Essays

text: Auxiliary") discharged from cylinders in our front line began to roll towards the enemy lines,
name: Real College Essays

text: the breeze being exactly right both in strength and direction, and we became happier still
name: Real College Essays

text: at the thought of paying the Germans back in their own coin. During the whole of our bombardment
name: Real College Essays

text: we could hear very little reply from the German guns, though from time to time we could see
name: Real College Essays

text: a few "woolly bears" and other shell-bursts, at odd points about the forward trenches. Probably
name: Real College Essays

text: they were saving most of their fire for the actual assault, and except for a stray machine
name: Real College Essays

text: gun bullet or two, we ourselves were in no kind of danger. One of those, however, which must
name: Real College Essays

text: have dropped at a steep angle, slightly wounded Regimental Sergt-Major Mounteney, who was standing
name: Real College Essays

text: in the trench with the Officers of Battalion Headquarters. He had only rejoined from England
name: Real College Essays

text: a few days before, and was our first casualty in the attack.
name: Real College Essays

text: At 1.50 p.m. the gas discharge ceased, but the smoke was continued until 2.0 p.m., when our
name: Real College Essays

text: guns "lifted" from the enemy front line, and the 137th and 138th Brigades began the assault.
name: Real College Essays

text: As the smoke cleared away, we could get a fair view of a portion of the attacking troops (Staffords)
name: Real College Essays

text: on the right as they went steadily, and apparently in excellent order over the top, but, almost
name: Real College Essays

text: at the same time we heard with surprise and dismay, the somewhat slow "tap-tap" of numbers
name: Real College Essays

text: of those enemy machine guns, which were to have been so completely silenced by our bombardment!
name: Real College Essays

text: We watched the Staffords for a few moments until they disappeared from view.
name: Real College Essays

text: Then followed a period of anxious waiting, and the only information we got was to the effect
name: Real College Essays

text: that the 138th Brigade on the left had practically gained their portion of the Redoubt.
name: Real College Essays

text: Soon after 3 o'clock, we received orders to move forward, and began to proceed by way of "Inverness
name: Real College Essays

text: Trench," "Bomb Alley" and "Left Boyau" to "Reserve Trench." Movement was very slow, owing to
name: Real College Essays

text: the congestion of the traffic, and the narrowness of the trenches, and took a long time to
name: Real College Essays

text: complete. There we were destined to remain for several hours, and suffered a few casualties
name: Real College Essays

text: from shell fire, apparently directed at the junctions of the trench with "Central" and "Right
name: Real College Essays

text: Boyaux." We were now nominally at the disposal of General Officer Commanding 137th Brigade,
name: Real College Essays

text: but never received any orders from him, and eventually drifted to the command of General Officer
name: Real College Essays

text: Commanding 138th Brigade.
name: Real College Essays

text: Traffic became more and more congested by the stream of wounded which was now pouring down
name: Real College Essays

text: Central Boyau and "Barts Alley," and by carrying parties and supports endeavouring to get along
name: Real College Essays

text: the Reserve Trench up to the Redoubt.
name: Real College Essays

text: Soon we began to gather scraps of information from those who were coming down, and to realise
name: Real College Essays

text: that things were going far from well. The usual answer was "Don't ask me, all I know is it's
name: Real College Essays

text: Hell up there!" It was now getting too dark to see, and we could only gather that at any rate
name: Real College Essays

text: we were holding the West Face and having a pretty bad time in doing so; also that our Grenadiers
name: Real College Essays

text: attached to the 138th Brigade, had suffered heavily. Sergt. G. F. Foster was carried down dying
name: Real College Essays

text: from wounds in the body, and Hemingway was reported to be dangerously wounded, if not already dead.
name: Real College Essays

text: Things had not gone well. As we learned afterwards the attack of the Staffords on the right
name: Real College Essays

text: had been held up almost immediately by machine gun fire, and very little ground had been made.
name: Real College Essays

text: On the left, the Lincolns and Leicesters at first were more fortunate, and reaching West Face
name: Real College Essays

text: with comparatively few casualties, began to make their way up to Fosse Trench. But the further
name: Real College Essays

text: they advanced, the more heavy became their losses, until eventually the advance came to a standstill,
name: Real College Essays

text: the furthest point reached being about 100 yards from Fosse Trench. From these more advanced
name: Real College Essays

text: positions they were gradually forced back, until only the West Face was in our hands. It is
name: Real College Essays

text: abundantly clear that the effect of our bombardment did not come up to expectations, and that
name: Real College Essays

text: many machine guns were untouched, and, worst of all, that the Dump, on which "heavy shell need
name: Real College Essays

text: not be wasted, as it could be made untenable by either side," proved to be a miniature Gibraltar,
name: Real College Essays

text: honeycombed with shafts and galleries leading to concealed machine gun emplacements. Small
name: Real College Essays

text: wonder that little ground could be made or held in the face of such defences.
name: Real College Essays

text: The news that things were going badly induced a Battalion Commander of another Brigade, whose
name: Real College Essays

text: Battalion had been taken from him piecemeal and scattered to the four winds of heaven, to order
name: Real College Essays

text: A Company, in the absence of Col. Fowler, to go across to the Redoubt to reinforce the troops
name: Real College Essays

text: there. Information, however, was brought by L.-Corpl. Simpson of A Company (killed a few hours
name: Real College Essays

text: later), who made a rapid and courageous journey over the open to West Face, to the effect that
name: Real College Essays

text: that trench was already overcrowded, and that the troops there required thinning, rather than
name: Real College Essays

text: reinforcing.
name: Real College Essays

text: It was now getting late and things seemed to be in a very unsatisfactory state, when orders
name: Real College Essays

text: were issued by Col. Fowler, who had met General Kemp in the trenches, and received verbal instructions
name: Real College Essays

text: to be prepared to carry out an attack at short notice on the right portion of the Redoubt,
name: Real College Essays

text: for Companies (except B who were detached for other work) to begin to move up in readiness
name: Real College Essays

text: to our front line trenches. This movement began about 9.0 p.m. very slowly along Reserve Trench
name: Real College Essays

text: and "Hayward's Heath." The difficulty of moving a Battalion at night, in single file, through
name: Real College Essays

text: a maze of unfamiliar trenches without losing touch, may be better imagined than described,
name: Real College Essays

text: and it was after midnight before we had covered the 400 or 500 yards, which was all we had to do.
name: Real College Essays

text: Whilst this was going on Col. Fowler and the Adjutant, accompanied by the Staff Captain, Major
name: Real College Essays

text: Wordsworth, made a hasty reconnaissance of the position, and found that elements of the 138th
name: Real College Essays

text: Brigade and Monmouths were holding the North-Western portion of West Face, whilst the Eastern
name: Real College Essays

text: portion of Big Willie was held by the 6th Battalion. Except for a short distance near the barricade
name: Real College Essays

text: on each flank, the trench between these points was held by the enemy.
name: Real College Essays

text: At 2.45 a.m. on October 14th, we received from General Officer Commanding 138th Brigade, written
name: Real College Essays

text: orders to attack and consolidate "as soon as possible" the South-Eastern portion of West Face,
name: Real College Essays

text: the junction of South Face and Big Willie (shewn on the map as Point 60), and if possible the
name: Real College Essays

text: Chord of the Redoubt. The order stated that the 6th Battalion in Big Willie would co-operate
name: Real College Essays

text: by a bombing attack along that trench "at the same time." Owing to the difficulty of getting
name: Real College Essays

text: messages to and fro, in the maze of unknown trenches in the dark, it was quite impossible to
name: Real College Essays

text: get in touch with the 6th Battalion so as to give them any idea when our attack would begin,
name: Real College Essays

text: so that we were not able to rely on getting much help from them. The Commanding Officer decided
name: Real College Essays

text: that two Companies would be sufficient for the attack, which was of course going to be without
name: Real College Essays

text: artillery support, and A Company (Major A. L. Ashwell), and D Company (Capt. B. W. Vann), were
name: Real College Essays

text: detailed. A hasty conference was arranged at a small dug-out at which Col. Fowler, who intended
name: Real College Essays

text: himself to lead the attack, gave the few orders that were possible in the circumstances:--"A
name: Real College Essays

text: quiet advance, no firing, and in with the bayonet."
name: Real College Essays

text: Owing to the darkness and the unfamiliar ground, it was necessary to make some arrangement
name: Real College Essays

text: for keeping direction. Major Becher was, therefore, sent across to the West Face, with instructions
name: Real College Essays

text: to stay at the extreme right flank of the 138th Brigade position, and there to show a light
name: Real College Essays

text: from a flash lamp on which the left flank of our attack would be directed.
name: Real College Essays

text: As soon as this was settled, and Company Commanders had issued their instructions, we began
name: Real College Essays

text: to deploy in front of our original front line trench, as nearly as possible opposite our objective.
name: Real College Essays

text: It was again a very slow job getting the men out of the deep and narrow support trenches, and
name: Real College Essays

text: over a single duck-board bridge across the front line into position; indeed many men of D Company
name: Real College Essays

text: never received the order at all, and remained in the support trench in ignorance of what was
name: Real College Essays

text: going on. The men were extended to about four paces, D Company on the right, A on the left.
name: Real College Essays

text: This movement was carried out very quietly, with entire absence of hesitation or confusion,
name: Real College Essays

text: and the men were then dressed as nearly as possible on the required alignment--no easy matter
name: Real College Essays

text: when one has only a map, and has never seen the objective or the ground in front of it. Rifles
name: Real College Essays

text: were loaded and bayonets fixed, Col. Fowler with characteristic unselfishness, giving his rifle
name: Real College Essays

text: to an Officer who had a bayonet, but no rifle to put it on. All these preliminaries were carried
name: Real College Essays

text: out without attracting the attention of the enemy, who were about 250 yards away. Finally at
name: Real College Essays

text: about 3.45 a.m. the order was given to advance, keeping our left flank on Becher's lamp, which
name: Real College Essays

text: we could see from time to time across the intervening ground. It was a strange experience,
name: Real College Essays

text: this slow night advance through the darkness and mist in the almost uncanny stillness which,
name: Real College Essays

text: sooner or later, always follows heavy fighting; so like what many of us had done in peace-time
name: Real College Essays

text: night-ops, that it was difficult to realise that this was war, and would end in hand-to-hand
name: Real College Essays

text: fighting; that, however quietly we went, we must eventually be discovered, and perhaps swept
name: Real College Essays

text: away by machine gun and rifle fire. The ground was for the most part level, and not badly cut
name: Real College Essays

text: up, and there was little wire. A few of our dead, one or two severely wounded still struggling
name: Real College Essays

text: painfully back to our lines, and a number of abandoned rifles were all that were left to show
name: Real College Essays

text: what had happened on the previous day. When we were about half-way across it was realised that
name: Real College Essays

text: we were getting too far to the left, and direction was changed half-right. It was not until
name: Real College Essays

text: the right of the line was close up to the old German wire, that we were discovered. Fire was
name: Real College Essays

text: opened from somewhere half-right, probably in the neighbourhood of Point 60, but it was not
name: Real College Essays

text: severe, and only a few casualties were caused. On arriving at West Face it was found to be
name: Real College Essays

text: practically empty on the right, the few Germans who had been there having probably left hurriedly
name: Real College Essays

text: as we approached. On the left we found a mixed crowd of Lincolns, Leicesters, and Monmouths,
name: Real College Essays

text: with a few Robin Hoods, all under the command of Col. Evill, of the Monmouths. Many of them
name: Real College Essays

text: were wounded, and nearly all were exhausted by their dreadful experiences of the previous day.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our arrival was, therefore, very opportune and put fresh life into them.
name: Real College Essays

text: It was now quite evident that we had come too far to the left, and although we had gained 100
name: Real College Essays

text: yards or so of the West Face, our right flank was not in touch with the 6th Battalion in Big
name: Real College Essays

text: Willie. In their eagerness to get at the Germans, and urged on by the shouts of the Lincolns
name: Real College Essays

text: and Leicesters, the left half of A Company ran through the West Face and began pushing on.
name: Real College Essays

text: The enemy, however, were waking up, and our men were met with much heavier fire, which, although
name: Real College Essays

text: unaimed, caused a number of casualties. Edge was severely wounded in the arm and chest, and
name: Real College Essays

text: Everard Handford was killed instantaneously by a bullet in the head, whilst numbers of men
name: Real College Essays

text: also fell. It was then seen that any further advance was out of the question. The only thing
name: Real College Essays

text: to be done was to consolidate what we had, and try to extend our gains laterally by bombing
name: Real College Essays

text: along the West Face. Grenadiers and grenades (English and German) were collected, parties were
name: Real College Essays

text: organised by Ashwell and Vann, and several more yards of trench were gained. Strachan leading
name: Real College Essays

text: one of these along the trench with utter fearlessness was never seen again, and was probably
name: Real College Essays

text: killed at once. Shortage of grenades soon made it clear that we must stop and build a barricade
name: Real College Essays

text: to hold up the Germans, who as usual seemed to have a never-ending supply.
name: Real College Essays

text: On the extreme right, Vann and others of D Company had come across some Boches out of the trench,
name: Real College Essays

text: apparently preparing to make an attack over the open. Most of these were slaughtered, and the
name: Real College Essays

text: rest made all possible haste back to their trench. This appears to have been part of an organised
name: Real College Essays

text: counter-attack, as the enemy tried a similar attack on the left as well, which also failed.
name: Real College Essays

text: Nothing was heard of the bombing in Big Willie by the 6th Battalion, but we learnt afterwards
name: Real College Essays

text: that they had made several attempts to progress along that trench without success.
name: Real College Essays

text: All available tools and sandbags were got together in the trench to build a barricade at the
name: Real College Essays

text: right flank. It was now getting light, and this was attended with much danger, and in the work
name: Real College Essays

text: of filling sandbags and placing them at the barricade, we had several men killed in a very
name: Real College Essays

text: short time.
name: Real College Essays

text: Vann had already been wounded by a bullet in the left forearm, and had gone down to be dressed,
name: Real College Essays

text: returning with his usual courage and tenacity, after having his wound attended to. The Commanding
name: Real College Essays

text: Officer, however, would not let him stay, and he had to go down again to hospital. Ashwell
name: Real College Essays

text: was hit by a bullet in the right shoulder a few minutes after Vann, and he, too, had to leave us.
name: Real College Essays

text: The enemy were not more than fifty yards away, and the least exposure brought a bullet with
name: Real College Essays

text: deadly aim, though in this respect they did not have things entirely their own way. We could
name: Real College Essays

text: distinctly see the tops of their helmets over the parapet, and at one time there was such a
name: Real College Essays

text: collection that we thought they were going to attack, but nothing came of it, and we settled
name: Real College Essays

text: down to work again. There was no wire or obstacle of any kind between the two trenches. We
name: Real College Essays

text: were too close to get our guns on to them, otherwise we could have done much execution. Practically
name: Real College Essays

text: all the work on the right was done by men of D Company, who eventually made a barricade, which
name: Real College Essays

text: was more or less bullet-proof, and dug a length of trench to protect that flank. Here Sergt.
name: Real College Essays

text: W. L. Green did excellent work, encouraging everyone by his fine example. For nearly 24 hours
name: Real College Essays

text: he stuck to his post in spite of bombs and rifle fire. He was ably assisted by Sergt. Turgoose
name: Real College Essays

text: and Pvtes. Keeling, Hubbard, Dickinson, Offord and Sly of D Company, also Pvte. F. Attenborough
name: Real College Essays

text: of A Company, whilst L.-Corpl. Skelton did splendid work in attending to wounded.
name: Real College Essays

text: Meanwhile Col. Fowler had made arrangements for the defence of the trench on the left, from
name: Real College Essays

text: which, much to their relief the Lincolns, Leicesters, and Monmouths, had been withdrawn during
name: Real College Essays

text: the early hours of the morning. Their place had been taken by A Company, which having lost
name: Real College Essays

text: all its Officers, was now commanded by Sergt. L. Bell. Parties were set to work to improve
name: Real College Essays

text: the trench, which was badly knocked about, and during the following night the Company dug a
name: Real College Essays

text: new trench a few yards in front, in order to get a better field of fire and for better protection.
name: Real College Essays

text: The Northern end of West Face was all this time held by the 7th Battalion.
name: Real College Essays

text: C Company (Capt. H. B. S. Handford, in place of Capt. G. S. Heathcote, who had left to do duty
name: Real College Essays

text: at the Base) who had been left behind in Hayward's Heath when A and D Companies went over to
name: Real College Essays

text: attack, stayed there until 5.0 a.m. when 2nd Lieut. R. A. Abrams and a party of 15 were detailed
name: Real College Essays

text: to carry grenades up to A Company in the Redoubt, where many of them remained. The rest of
name: Real College Essays

text: the Company moved up to a communication trench near the original front line, where they received
name: Real College Essays

text: orders from a Battalion Commander of another Brigade, to carry water and grenades over the
name: Real College Essays

text: open to the Redoubt. They started shortly after 7.30 a.m., but as it was quite light, they
name: Real College Essays

text: were seen immediately, and heavy machine gun and rifle fire was opened on them at once. Basil
name: Real College Essays

text: Handford and several others were killed instantaneously, and several were wounded. The attempt
name: Real College Essays

text: was foredoomed to failure, and the men were ordered back into the trench. For the rest of the
name: Real College Essays

text: day they helped to carry stores to the Redoubt by way of a new communication trench and to
name: Real College Essays

text: fetch in and attend to the wounded. Very gallant work was done in this operation by Comp. Sergt.-Major
name: Real College Essays

text: Haywood, Sergts. Leivers and Bexton, and Pvtes. Winterbottom, Allen, and Eyre.
name: Real College Essays

text: B Company (Capt. Turner) had been detached about 5.0 p.m. on October 13th, and ordered to proceed
name: Real College Essays

text: over the open to reinforce the garrison of our original front line. They remained for some
name: Real College Essays

text: time in the old support line, from which all the Company Grenadiers were sent up to reinforce
name: Real College Essays

text: the men in the Redoubt. One of these, L.-Corpl. G. W. Moore, did very gallant work in remaining
name: Real College Essays

text: alone for three-quarters-of-an-hour on the enemy's side of a barricade, which was being built
name: Real College Essays

text: up behind him, and then continued to bomb the enemy for eight hours. The Company was later
name: Real College Essays

text: ordered to dig a communication trench to link up the Redoubt with our old front line. They
name: Real College Essays

text: started about 9.0 p.m., and worked continuously on it throughout the night, much of the time
name: Real College Essays

text: under heavy rifle fire, and by dawn a serviceable trench had been dug, and a very important
name: Real College Essays

text: communication established. Capt. Turner was congratulated by the Officer Commanding the 7th
name: Real College Essays

text: Battalion on the very good work of his Company, in the supervision of which he had been most
name: Real College Essays

text: ably assisted by Sergt. Rawding.
name: Real College Essays

text: October 14th seemed a never-ending day for those in the Redoubt. Fortunately in a way, the
name: Real College Essays

text: lines were too close together for us to be shelled, but bombing went on almost uninterruptedly,
name: Real College Essays

text: and our casualties mounted rapidly. Grenadier reinforcements were sent along from time to time
name: Real College Essays

text: from every Company in the Battalion, also from the 5th Battalion, whilst 2nd Lieut. G. H. Fisher,
name: Real College Essays

text: who was acting as Grenade Officer in the absence of Hemingway, came up during the morning,
name: Real College Essays

text: and at the right barricade displayed the greatest courage until he was badly wounded and had
name: Real College Essays

text: to leave, dying a few days later. Bombing was also going on at the left barricade, and throughout
name: Real College Essays

text: the day from one flank or the other, the cry was ever "more bombs" or "more Bombers." We had
name: Real College Essays

text: fortunately been able to get a signal line up to the Redoubt, and a station established there,
name: Real College Essays

text: in a fairly deep dug-out, so that most of the time we were in telephonic communication with
name: Real College Essays

text: those behind.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our relief promised for the night of October 14th, never came, and we were compelled, alas,
name: Real College Essays

text: to remain in the Redoubt. Everyone was tired out, having had little or no sleep, and very little
name: Real College Essays

text: food, for 48 hours. As soon as it was dark the Sappers put out some wire in front of West Face,
name: Real College Essays

text: which encouraged us considerably, and we got through the night without any untoward incident.
name: Real College Essays

text: About 6.30 a.m., on the morning of October 15th, we were relieved in West Face by portions
name: Real College Essays

text: of the 5th and 6th Battalions, and by Grenadiers of the Irish Guards, and withdrawn to "Railway
name: Real College Essays

text: Reserve Trench," where we joined up with the remainder of B and C Companies. By the tragic
name: Real College Essays

text: irony of fate, as the Guards were actually filing into West Face and the relief was nearly
name: Real College Essays

text: complete, Col. Fowler, who was taking a last glance over the top to see if he could find any
name: Real College Essays

text: trace of Major Becher, the last signs of whom had been the flashes of his lamp, to guide us
name: Real College Essays

text: across to the Redoubt--was killed instantaneously by a sniper's bullet. So determined had he
name: Real College Essays

text: been to find Becher, that he had himself gone out during the night with Sergt. Stokes in a
name: Real College Essays

text: gallant but unsuccessful endeavour to find him.
name: Real College Essays

text: Major J. E. Blackwall of the 6th Battalion took over the remnants of the Battalion the same
name: Real College Essays

text: evening, and shortly before midnight we were devoutly thankful to be relieved by the Irish
name: Real College Essays

text: Guards. As the relief was taking place, the enemy attempted an attack against the garrison
name: Real College Essays

text: of West Face, but as this was now swelled by the relieving troops, they got rather more than
name: Real College Essays

text: they bargained for, and were beaten off with heavy loss. At the same time they put down quite
name: Real College Essays

text: a barrage on the reserve trenches, and made our relief distinctly unpleasant, but eventually
name: Real College Essays

text: we got it completed without further casualty.
name: Real College Essays

text: Much to our delight, just before leaving, we heard that Becher had been found. It appears that
name: Real College Essays

text: whilst we were going over to the attack, he had been bombed by the Boches, and badly wounded,
name: Real College Essays

text: as also had Daniels, his batman, who was with him. They got separated, but both managed to
name: Real College Essays

text: crawl away, though Becher eventually had to lie by in an old bit of trench near the German
name: Real College Essays

text: lines. It was from here that, after having been discovered by an Officer of the Leicesters,
name: Real College Essays

text: he was eventually rescued on October 15th, by Comp. Sergt.-Major Haywood, and L.-Sergt. T.
name: Real College Essays

text: Martin, who carried him a distance of 200 yards under more or less continuous rifle fire. Alas,
name: Real College Essays

text: however, he was not to recover, and after lingering on for ten weeks, he died in hospital on
name: Real College Essays

text: January 1st, 1916. In John Becher the Battalion lost one who was beloved by all, who had throughout
name: Real College Essays

text: ever had at heart the welfare of his men, whether in or out of the trenches, at work or at
name: Real College Essays

text: play. What he did in the early trench days at Kemmel, was known to few. Often and often he
name: Real College Essays

text: was out on patrol at night in "No Man's Land," mainly for the sake of example, for it was part
name: Real College Essays

text: of his creed never to tell a man to do anything that he would not dare to do himself. He lies
name: Real College Essays

text: buried in the British cemetery at Abbeville. It was a hard fate that struck down John Becher
name: Real College Essays

text: and his two brothers-in-law, Basil and Everard Handford--two of the most promising young Officers
name: Real College Essays

text: in the Battalion--within a few hours of each other.
name: Real College Essays

text: Much untiring energy and devotion were shewn by many during these strenuous three days, not
name: Real College Essays

text: by any means the least by our Medical Officer, Capt. C. B. Johnstone, and his stretcher bearers.
name: Real College Essays

text: Johnstone himself worked almost incessantly for over 48 hours in attending the wounded, and
name: Real College Essays
