text: On December 2nd, a Brigade Ceremonial Parade was held at Sus-St. Leger, where we were inspected
name: Real College Essays

text: by Major-General Thwaites. It was a bitterly cold day, but on the whole the show passed off
name: Real College Essays

text: well. It was perhaps aided a little by the fog, which covered one or two of our more intricate
name: Real College Essays

text: and unconventional movements rather successfully.
name: Real College Essays

text: On the following day we took part in what was probably one of the most interesting football
name: Real College Essays

text: matches in the Battalion's history, when a team of Officers played one from the 7th Battalion,
name: Real College Essays

text: and beat them one-nil after a great tussle.
name: Real College Essays

text: It was at Humbercourt that Sergt. "Sammy" Foster played an important part in trying to make
name: Real College Essays

text: us all "gas proof." With much success he made up a gas chamber in the village out of the shed
name: Real College Essays

text: for the "Pompe ? incendie," where all ranks of the Battalion were fitted with the new small
name: Real College Essays

text: box respirator, which had just arrived. This proved to be much the most satisfactory form of
name: Real College Essays

text: gas mask we ever had, and continued in general use up to the end of the war.
name: Real College Essays

text: We left Humbercourt on December 6th, and the same day went into Brigade Reserve, in the Foncquevillers
name: Real College Essays

text: sector, the 46th Division having taken over this portion of the line from the 49th Division.
name: Real College Essays

text: The sector was now fairly quiet, everyone having more or less gone into winter quarters. Our
name: Real College Essays

text: rest billets and Transport Lines were at Souastre, where, considering all things, we were fairly
name: Real College Essays

text: comfortable. There were good baths under the control of one of those celebrated Town Majors,
name: Real College Essays

text: of whom so much has been heard, a Y.M.C.A. hut, and a new form of entertainment in the shape
name: Real College Essays

text: of a Cinema, which our Division had recently added to its institutions. The Divisional "Whizz-bangs"
name: Real College Essays

text: were still showing, but were rather under a cloud, although that great actor subaltern from
name: Real College Essays

text: the Battalion, Moffat Johnston, gave them a helping hand for a short time. Being "out to soldier,"
name: Real College Essays

text: however, he preferred the front line, and very soon came back to us.
name: Real College Essays

text: When in Divisional Reserve all companies were back at Souastre, and carried out a little training
name: Real College Essays

text: in addition to the usual refitting and cleaning. Parties were also generally provided for Town
name: Real College Essays

text: Major's fatigues. When in Brigade Reserve two companies were at Souastre, and two at Foncquevillers,
name: Real College Essays

text: the latter finding garrisons for posts on the Eastern edge of the village, and at "Fort Dick,"
name: Real College Essays

text: between Foncquevillers and H??buterne.
name: Real College Essays

text: When in the line we held the left sub-sector, relieving with the 7th Battalion, the right company
name: Real College Essays

text: front having its right on the Foncquevillers-Gommecourt Road, the centre company being disposed
name: Real College Essays

text: about "Lincoln Lane," and the left company front running from "Roberts Avenue" to the Brayelle
name: Real College Essays

text: Road. Companies holding the line, had two or three platoons in the front line, and the remainder
name: Real College Essays

text: in support. The support Company occupied the dug-outs in "Sniper's Square."
name: Real College Essays

text: The trenches throughout this period were in an appalling state, though efforts had been made
name: Real College Essays

text: to improve them by the 49th Division, who certainly left Roberts Avenue well revetted, and
name: Real College Essays

text: with a good floor of trench grids. For the most part, however, they were deep in mud, and in
name: Real College Essays

text: a deplorable condition, and "gumboots thigh" were in great demand. Dug-outs were of the poorest,
name: Real College Essays

text: and life in the trenches was not pleasant. Efforts were made to improve matters during our
name: Real College Essays

text: stay and the Royal Engineers and Monmouths did a great deal of work, helped by large parties
name: Real College Essays

text: from all Battalions, but improvement was very slow.
name: Real College Essays

text: Fortunately the trenches were no great distance from the village, where Company cooks had their
name: Real College Essays

text: cookers, whilst the Battalion was in the line, so that hot meals were sent up regularly, and
name: Real College Essays

text: included a hot supper issued generally about midnight, the meals being mostly carried up by
name: Real College Essays

text: the Support Company. During the latter part of January and beginning of February, we had very
name: Real College Essays

text: hard frosts and much snow, and the carrying parties had a difficult task in walking on the
name: Real College Essays

text: slippery roads and trench grids, but this was overcome to a great extent by the use of sandbags
name: Real College Essays

text: tied over the boots. It was perhaps a somewhat expensive method to employ with sandbags costing
name: Real College Essays

text: something like a shilling each, but they served the purpose very well, and were in great demand
name: Real College Essays

text: in consequence. A drying-room was established at Battalion Headquarters in the village, in
name: Real College Essays

text: a large cellar, fitted with double-tier wire beds, stoves, and braziers. A supply of blankets
name: Real College Essays

text: was also available, so that the men who had been on patrol, or had got wet through, could come
name: Real College Essays

text: down from the line and get their wet clothes dried and a good rest and sleep in comfort. Inter-Battalion
name: Real College Essays

text: reliefs were carried out every four days, whilst Companies were able to relieve their men in
name: Real College Essays

text: the front line every 48 hours, or, when the weather was extremely bad, every 24 hours, by taking
name: Real College Essays

text: up the men from the support line. By this means, the time any particular man was actually in
name: Real College Essays

text: the front line was reduced to the lowest possible limit. During December and January, reliefs
name: Real College Essays

text: were carried out by daylight, usually beginning immediately after breakfast, and being completed
name: Real College Essays

text: by about noon. This system not only enabled the incomers to settle down in the trenches before
name: Real College Essays

text: night, but also gave the relieved Battalion four complete nights out, a system which was very
name: Real College Essays

text: much appreciated. At the end of January we changed to night reliefs. The main artery for traffic
name: Real College Essays

text: was the Foncquevillers-Souastre Road, and although it was usually fairly quiet, we sometimes
name: Real College Essays

text: astonished ourselves at the pace we made along it on relief nights, and most of us were glad
name: Real College Essays

text: when we got over the crest into Souastre.
name: Real College Essays

text: Martelli and his Scouts and many others did some very good patrols, but on some nights when
name: Real College Essays

text: the moon was bright, and the ground covered with snow, this work was not easy. Long white nightshirts
name: Real College Essays

text: complete with hoods were tried, but not considered very suitable, as they looked quite dark
name: Real College Essays

text: against the white snow, and on the whole were not a success.
name: Real College Essays

text: Though normally quiet the sector was occasionally trench mortared and shelled fairly heavily,
name: Real College Essays

text: most attention being paid to the front line about Roberts Avenue and Lincoln Lane, the Gommecourt
name: Real College Essays

text: Road, the Orchard in front of the village, where our heavy trench mortars, familiarly known
name: Real College Essays

text: as "Flying Pigs", had their quarters, and the village itself. It was in connection with one
name: Real College Essays

text: of these bombardments that the I-Tok machine professed to have some success. By some means
name: Real College Essays

text: a Boche map had been secured shewing the areas into which our front was divided for the purpose
name: Real College Essays

text: of "shoots", and if the I-Tok picked up messages from which it was inferred that a shoot over
name: Real College Essays

text: a particular area was likely to take place, the information was at once passed on to the Battalion
name: Real College Essays

text: concerned. On one occasion when such information was received, no sooner were the men cleared
name: Real College Essays

text: of the area than it was indeed shelled! It may have been an accident of course, but the I-Tok
name: Real College Essays

text: personnel took the credit, which we hope was deserved.
name: Real College Essays

text: One night, when the 7th Battalion were in the line, they were raided after a very heavy bombardment,
name: Real College Essays

text: in which they suffered several casualties. The following day the Officer Commanding that Battalion
name: Real College Essays

text: sent us a kind message of appreciation of the prompt way in which Capt. Turner and B Company,
name: Real College Essays

text: who were in support in Foncquevillers, had turned out and stood by ready to help. Fortunately
name: Real College Essays

text: their services were not required.
name: Real College Essays

text: The most unpleasant experience we ourselves had was on February 16th, when we relieved the
name: Real College Essays

text: 7th Battalion for the last time in this sector. The relief itself was carried out under difficulties,
name: Real College Essays

text: owing to a certain amount of gas shelling, but later on the Hun sent over perfect showers of
name: Real College Essays

text: gas bombs, and absolutely deluged the front and support lines, whilst he also fired a considerable
name: Real College Essays

text: number of gas shells into the village. It is estimated that in all between 500 and 600 were
name: Real College Essays

text: put over, mostly filled with phosgene. It was our first experience of any real gas shell bombardment,
name: Real College Essays

text: and partly owing to this and partly to the high concentration of the gas used we suffered heavy
name: Real College Essays

text: casualties, four men being killed and 24 wounded.
name: Real College Essays

text: Christmas Day, 1916, was spent in the line, and passed off very peacefully without anything
name: Real College Essays

text: untoward happening. We were not able to get our Christmas dinners until early in the New Year,
name: Real College Essays

text: when we were back at Souastre, and made the most of all the good things that had been sent
name: Real College Essays

text: out by kind friends at home. Each Company enjoyed a most sumptuous dinner, followed by a splendid
name: Real College Essays

text: entertainment provided by local talent, speeches, and so on.
name: Real College Essays

text: The Battalion front remained unchanged until early in February, when we extended Northwards
name: Real College Essays

text: to include the "Crawlboys Lane" area, then held by the 138th Brigade.
name: Real College Essays

text: About the same time we had Companies of the 2/5th, 2/8th, and 2/11th Battalions London Regiment
name: Real College Essays

text: with us for instruction, and a fine lot of men they were. Our difficulty was in knowing where
name: Real College Essays

text: to put them, for whereas we were about 80 per Company, they came out with their full complement
name: Real College Essays

text: of 250. One dreaded on occasions what might happen if the enemy suddenly decided to shell the
name: Real College Essays

text: trenches they held, for in some parts they were almost like the proverbial sardines. They came
name: Real College Essays

text: out fully equipped, with mobilisation stores made up to completion. Rumour says that when they
name: Real College Essays

text: had finished their instruction with us they were wiser not only in trench routine, but also
name: Real College Essays

text: in their Quarter-Master's Department!
name: Real College Essays

text: This period saw several important changes in personnel. With great regret we had to part with
name: Real College Essays

text: Major Ashwell, who left to take up the duties of Commandant of the Divisional School. This
name: Real College Essays

text: post, however, he only held for a brief space, as his excellent services throughout the war
name: Real College Essays

text: were very soon rewarded by his appointment to command first the 5th, and shortly afterwards
name: Real College Essays

text: the 6th Battalion. He was succeeded as Second-in-Command by Major Lane. Capt. E. M. Hacking,
name: Real College Essays

text: who commanded A Company for a time, was appointed Railhead Disbursing Officer, and handed over
name: Real College Essays

text: his duties to Lieut. Andrews. Capt. Turner stuck to B Company, but during periods of absence
name: Real College Essays

text: of the Commanding Officer and Major Lane, acted as Second-in-Command, leaving Lieut. G. Wright
name: Real College Essays

text: to look after his Company. Capt. Piggford, after struggling on for some time, although very
name: Real College Essays

text: unfit, eventually had to go down sick, and shortly afterwards was appointed Divisional Claims
name: Real College Essays

text: Officer, to which he later added the duties of Divisional Burials Officer. When he left, C
name: Real College Essays

text: Company was handed over to Lieut. Abrams. Capt. Hill, after a long and successful period in
name: Real College Essays

text: command of D Company, also had to leave owing to sickness, and was succeeded by Lieut. Simonet.
name: Real College Essays

text: In 2nd Lieut. King-Stephens we lost a very gallant Officer, and a great favourite. He was killed
name: Real College Essays

text: one morning when returning from wiring. The fog which had been so helpful for the purpose,
name: Real College Essays

text: cleared rather suddenly and a Boche sniper picked him off just as he was getting back to the
name: Real College Essays

text: trench. Reinforcement Officers who joined during the period were 2nd Lieuts. C. H. S. Stephenson,
name: Real College Essays

text: A. E. Geary, and J. E. Mitchell. So far as other ranks were concerned there were now no discharges
name: Real College Essays

text: as the Military Service Act, which was in force, gave to very few the opportunity of getting
name: Real College Essays

text: home. We lost, however, two excellent Comp. Sergt.-Majors, G. Powell and Hotson, who went to
name: Real College Essays

text: England to train for commissions, and were shortly followed by Comp. Sergt.-Major T. Powell.
name: Real College Essays

text: George Powell was destined one day to be awarded the D.S.O., whilst Hotson unfortunately met
name: Real College Essays

text: his fate in Italy. Sergts. Slater and Rawding, and Comp. Quarter-Master Sergt. Deverall, then
name: Real College Essays

text: became Comp. Sergt.-Majors of A, B, and D Companies respectively. Our casualties in the line
name: Real College Essays

text: during this period were not heavy, amounting to seven killed and 47 wounded. Reinforcements
name: Real College Essays

text: who joined totalled 243, and included several men from the Sherwood Rangers Yeomanry.
name: Real College Essays

text: On February 19th, after handing over our portion of the front line to Battalions of the 138th
name: Real College Essays

text: Brigade, we marched back to St. Amand.
name: Real College Essays

text: The following pages contain a Treatise on the Art of Riding on Horseback, for Ladies, which
name: Real College Essays

text: originally appeared in the Publishers' well-known Manual of elegant feminine Recreations, Exercises,
name: Real College Essays

text: and Pursuits, THE YOUNG LADY'S BOOK; with, however, various additions to the Text, and a number
name: Real College Essays

text: of new Illustrations and Embellishments.
name: Real College Essays

text: In offering the Treatise, thus improved and adorned, in a separate form, the Publishers, it
name: Real College Essays

text: need scarcely be said, have been influenced, materially, by that high and most extensive patronage,
name: Real College Essays

text: which, under Royal auspices, has been conferred by the ladies of this country, since the commencement
name: Real College Essays

text: of the present reign, on the Art of which it is the subject.
name: Real College Essays

text: Riding on Horseback is, confessedly, one of the most graceful, agreeable, and salutary of feminine
name: Real College Essays

text: recreations. No attitude, perhaps, can be regarded as more elegant than that of a lady in the
name: Real College Essays

text: modern side-saddle; nor can any exercise be deemed capable of affording more rational and innocent
name: Real College Essays

text: delight, than that of the female equestrian. Pursued in the open air, it affords a most rapid,
name: Real College Essays

text: and, at the same time, exhilarating succession of scenic changes, at a degree of personal exertion,
name: Real College Essays

text: sufficient to produce immediate pleasure, without inducing the subsequent languor of fatigue.
name: Real College Essays

text: Nor is riding on horseback attended with that danger to ladies, attributed to it by the indolent,
name: Real College Essays

text: the melancholy, and the timid. Accidents, indeed, in the side-saddle, are of extremely rare
name: Real College Essays

text: occurrence. Strange as it may seem, it is, however, an incontrovertible fact, that horses,
name: Real College Essays

text: in general, are much more docile and temperate, with riders of the fair sex, than when mounted
name: Real College Essays

text: by men. This may be attributed, partially, to the more backward position, in the saddle, of
name: Real College Essays

text: the former than the latter; but, principally, perhaps, to their superior delicacy of hand in
name: Real College Essays

text: managing the reins.
name: Real College Essays

text: As an active recreation, and a mode of conveyance, riding on horseback appears to have been
name: Real College Essays

text: of very remote usage among our fair countrywomen. During a long period, indeed, it was the
name: Real College Essays

text: only one known to, or, adopted by them, for the performance of journies. Such, too, appears
name: Real College Essays

text: to have been the case (with some modifications) in other European countries. The only voiture
name: Real College Essays

text: of the French, says Garsault, until the reign of Charles the Sixth, was the back of the horse
name: Real College Essays

text: or mule: neither Kings, Queens, Princes, nor subjects were acquainted with any other. In the
name: Real College Essays

text: time of that monarch, litters, borne by two horses, first appeared; but these were uncovered,
name: Real College Essays

text: and used, only, by ladies of the court. Froissart describes Isabel, the second wife of Richard
name: Real College Essays

text: the Second of England, as having been borne "en une liti?re moult riche, qui etoit ordonn?e
name: Real College Essays

text: pour elle;" and this kind of vehicle, during the reigns of several succeeding Monarchs, appears
name: Real College Essays

text: to have been used by women of distinction in this country, but, only, it is to be observed,
name: Real College Essays

text: in cases of illness, or on occasions of ceremony. For example,--when Margaret, daughter of
name: Real College Essays

text: Henry the Seventh, went into Scotland, she generally rode "a faire palfrey;" while, after her,
name: Real College Essays

text: was conveyed "one vary riche litere, borne by two faire coursers, vary nobly drest; in the
name: Real College Essays

text: which litere the sayd Queene was borne in the intrying of the good townes, or otherwise, to
name: Real College Essays

text: her good playsher."
name: Real College Essays

text: Towards the end of the thirteenth century, vehicles with wheels, for the use of ladies, were
name: Real College Essays

text: first introduced. They appear to have been of Italian origin, as the first notice of them is
name: Real College Essays

text: found in an account of the entry of Charles of Anjou into Naples; on which occasion, we are
name: Real College Essays

text: told, his queen rode in a careta, the outside and inside of which were covered with sky-blue
name: Real College Essays

text: velvet, interspersed with golden lilies. Under the Gallicised denomination of char, the Italian
name: Real College Essays

text: careta, shortly afterwards became known in France; where, so early as the year 1294, an ordinance
name: Real College Essays

text: was issued by Philip the Fair, forbidding its use to citizens' wives. Nor was England far behind
name: Real College Essays

text: in the adoption of the vehicle; for, in "The Squyr of Low Degree," a poem supposed to have
name: Real College Essays

text: been written anterior to the time of Chaucer, we find the father of a royal lady promising
name: Real College Essays

text: that she shall hunt with him, on the morrow, in "a chare," drawn by
name: Real College Essays

text: "Jennettes of Spain that ben so white,
name: Real College Essays

text: Trapped to the ground with velvet bright."
name: Real College Essays

text: "It shall be covered with velvet red,
name: Real College Essays

text: And clothes of fine gold all about your head;
name: Real College Essays

text: With damask white and azure blue,
name: Real College Essays

text: Well diapered with lilies blue."
name: Real College Essays

text: However richly ornamented, the careta, char, or chare--and there is little, if any, doubt,
name: Real College Essays

text: to be entertained as to their identity--may have been, it was, probably, a clumsy, inelegant,
name: Real College Essays

text: and inconvenient structure; for its employment appears to have been far from general among
name: Real College Essays

text: high-born ladies, even on occasions of ceremony and pomp. During the fourteenth, fifteenth,
name: Real College Essays

text: and sixteenth centuries, the French Princesses usually rode on donkies; and so late as the
name: Real College Essays

text: year 1534, a sacred festival was attended by Queen Eleonora, and the females of the blood royal
name: Real College Essays

text: of France, on horseback. Nor did the superior and more recent invention of coaches, for a long
name: Real College Essays

text: period, tend materially to supersede, among ladies, the use of the saddle. These vehicles,
name: Real College Essays

text: according to Stow, became known, in England, in 1580; but, many years after, Queen Elizabeth
name: Real College Essays

text: herself is described as having appeared, almost daily, on her palfrey. In the time of Charles
name: Real College Essays

text: the Second, the fashion, among ladies, of riding on horseback, declined; during subsequent
name: Real College Essays

text: reigns, it gradually revived; and the exercise may now be regarded as firmly established, among
name: Real College Essays

text: our fair countrywomen, by the august example of their illustrious Queen.
name: Real College Essays

text: The present graceful, secure, and appropriate style of female equestrianism is, however, materially
name: Real College Essays

text: different from that of the olden time. In by-gone days, the dame or damosel rode precisely
name: Real College Essays

text: as the knight or page. Of this, several illustrations occur in an illuminated manuscript of
name: Real College Essays

text: the fourteenth century, preserved in the Royal Library. In one of these, a lady of that period
name: Real College Essays

text: is depicted on horseback, enjoying the pastime of the chase. In another, are represented two
name: Real College Essays

text: gentlewomen of the same period, on horseback, with an individual of the other sex, engaged
name: Real College Essays

text: (as is shewn by some parts of the design, which it would be needless, for our present purpose,
name: Real College Essays

text: to copy) in the once much-favoured diversion of Hawking.
name: Real College Essays

text: Queen Elizabeth, says a writer in the Encyclop?dia Londinensis, "seems to have been the first
name: Real College Essays

text: who set the ladies the more modest fashion of riding sideways. Considerable opposition was,
name: Real College Essays

text: at first, made to it, as inconvenient and dangerous: but, practice, in time, brought it into
name: Real College Essays

text: general use; particularly when ladies found they could ride a-hunting, take flying leaps, and
name: Real College Essays

text: gallop over cross roads and ploughed fields, without meeting with more accidents than the men:
name: Real College Essays

text: besides, it was not only allowed to be more decorous, but, in many respects, more congenial
name: Real College Essays

text: to the ease and comfort of a female rider."
name: Real College Essays

text: Our author is, however, wrong in ascribing the fashion of riding sideways, by women in this
name: Real College Essays

text: country, to Elizabeth; by whom it could only have been confirmed, or, at the most, revived;--the
name: Real College Essays

text: honour of its introduction being clearly attributable to another Queen of England, who lived
name: Real College Essays

text: at a much more early period of our history.
name: Real College Essays

text: Ann of Bohemia, consort of Richard the Second, is the illustrious personage to whom we allude.
name: Real College Essays

text: She, it was, according to Stow (whom Beckman follows on this point), that originally shewed
name: Real College Essays

text: the women of this country how gracefully and conveniently they might ride on horseback sideways.
name: Real College Essays

text: Another old historian, enumerating the new fashions of Richard the Second's reign, observes,
name: Real College Essays

text: Likewise, noble ladies then used high heads and cornets, and robes with long trains, and seats,
name: Real College Essays

text: or side-saddles, on their horses, by the example of the respectable Queen, Ann, daughter of
name: Real College Essays

text: the King of Bohemia; who first introduced the custom into this kingdom: for, before, women
name: Real College Essays

text: of every rank rode as men do" (T. ROSSII, Hist. Re. Ang. p. 205). In his beautiful illustrative
name: Real College Essays

text: picture of Chaucer's Canterbury Pilgrims, Stothard appears to have committed an anachronism,
name: Real College Essays

text: in placing the most conspicuous female character of his fine composition sideways on her steed.
name: Real College Essays

text: That the lady should have been depicted riding in the male fashion, might, it strikes us, have
name: Real College Essays

text: been inferred, without any historical research on the subject, from the poet's describing her
name: Real College Essays

text: as having, on her feet,
name: Real College Essays

text: "a paire of spurr??s sharpe."
name: Real College Essays

text: Neither the original example of Ann of Bohemia, nor that, in later days, of Elizabeth, as female
name: Real College Essays

text: equestrians, however extensively followed, had sufficient force, entirely to abolish, among
name: Real College Essays

text: our countrywomen, the mode of riding like the other sex. In the time of Charles the Second,
name: Real College Essays

text: it appears, from a passage in the Duke of Newcastle's great work on Horsemanship, to have still,
name: Real College Essays

text: at least partially, subsisted. Another writer of the seventeenth century, whose manuscripts
name: Real College Essays

text: are preserved in the Harleian collection, speaks of it, as having been practised, in his time,
name: Real College Essays

text: by the ladies of Bury, in Suffolk, when hunting or hawking; and our venerable contemporary,
name: Real College Essays

text: Lawrence (a voluminous writer on the horse), it is worthy of remark, states, that at an early
name: Real College Essays

text: period of his own life, two young ladies of good family, then residing near Ipswich, in the
name: Real College Essays

text: same county, "were in the constant habit of riding about the country, in their smart doe-skins,
name: Real College Essays

text: great coats, and flapped beaver hats."
name: Real College Essays

text: Although entirely relinquished, at present, perhaps in this country, the mode of female equestrianism
name: Real College Essays

text: under notice continues to prevail in various other localities. In the following sketch, taken
name: Real College Essays

text: from Charles Audry's magnificent "Ecole d' Equitation," a Persian lady is delineated as just
name: Real College Essays

text: about to start on a journey, in the saddle; and, in the next, which is engraved from an original
name: Real College Essays

text: drawing, "done from the life," a lady and gentleman of Lima are represented on horseback. "I
name: Real College Essays

text: have endeavoured," the artist says, in manuscript, on the reverse of his sketch, "to depict
name: Real College Essays

text: the horses 'pacing;' as they are almost universally taught to do, in Peru: that is, to move
name: Real College Essays

text: both the legs, of one side, forward together. It resembles an English butcher's trot in appearance;
name: Real College Essays

text: but, it is so easy, that one might go to sleep on the horse: and, after riding 'a pacer,' it
name: Real College Essays

text: is difficult to sit a trotter at first. It is, also, excessively rapid;--good pacers beating
name: Real College Essays

text: other horses at a gallop. The ladies of Lima do not always ride with the face covered: but,
name: Real College Essays

text: only, when the sun is powerful. They, sometimes, ride in ponchos, like the men: in fact, it
name: Real College Essays

text: is excessively difficult, at first sight, to determine whether a person on horseback be male
name: Real College Essays

text: or female."
name: Real College Essays

text: The side-saddle introduced to this country by Ann of Bohemia, differed, materially, from that
name: Real College Essays

text: now used by British ladies; having, no doubt, been a mere pillion, on which the rider sate,
name: Real College Essays

text: as in a chair.
name: Real College Essays

text: At what period our fair countrywomen first began to ride with the knee over the pommel, we
name: Real College Essays

text: are not enabled to state: it is, however, clear, according to the original of the above sketch,
name: Real College Essays

text: which occurs in one of the historical illustrations of equestrianism, given by Audry, that
name: Real College Essays

text: the courtly dames of England did so, about the middle of the seventeenth century. Our author
name: Real College Essays

text: describes the figure, as being that of the Countess of Newcastle.
name: Real College Essays

text: It may be conjectured, that a single crutch, only, for the advanced leg, was at first used;
name: Real College Essays

text: and this, it is not improbable, was fixed on the centre of the pommel, as in the lady's saddle,
name: Real College Essays

text: now, or at least very lately, common in some parts of Mexico; where the women, it would seem,
name: Real College Essays

text: ride with the left hand towards the animal's head. But, even so recently as Garsault's time,
name: Real College Essays

text: the saddle in ordinary use, by French women, was, we learn from his work on equitation, still,
name: Real College Essays

text: a kind of pillion, on which the rider sate, diagonally, with both feet resting on a broad suspended
name: Real College Essays

text: ledge or stirrup. The pillion in this country has not yet become obsolete; being still, frequently,
name: Real College Essays

text: to be seen, on the backs of donkies and hack ponies, at watering places. During the early part
name: Real College Essays

text: of the present century, its employment continued to be general. It was fixed behind a man's
name: Real College Essays

text: saddle, on the croup of a steady horse, trained to go at an easy though shuffling pace between
name: Real College Essays

text: a walk and a trot. The groom, or gentleman, equipped with a broad leathern belt buckled about
name: Real College Essays

text: his waist--by which the lady secured her position, in case of need--first mounted; and his
name: Real College Essays

text: fair companion was then lifted, backwards, and behind him, into her seat. In an old work on
name: Real College Essays

text: horsemanship, written by one William Stokes, and published at Oxford, it is not, perhaps, unworthy
name: Real College Essays

text: of notice, directions are given for vaulting into the saddle, after the lady has been placed
name: Real College Essays

text: on the croup; together with a plate illustrative of so exquisitely nice and marvellously absurd
name: Real College Essays

text: an operation. In Mexico "they manage these things," if not "better," at all events, with more
name: Real College Essays

text: gallantry, than our forefathers did, for with them, "the pisana, or country lady," we are told,
name: Real College Essays

text: is often seen mounted before her cavaliero; who, seated behind his fair one, supports her
name: Real College Essays

text: with his arm thrown around her waist." Our illustrative sketch of this custom (in the preceding
name: Real College Essays

text: page) is taken from a beautiful model,--the work of a native Mexican artist.
name: Real College Essays

text: Having, now, offered our fair readers a slight and unpretending historical sketch of female
name: Real College Essays

text: equestrianism, we shall proceed, after a few preliminary remarks, to the practical details
name: Real College Essays

text: of the art.
name: Real College Essays

text: Its various advantages, inducements, and attractions, as an exercise, have, already, been noticed.
name: Real College Essays

text: Much, however, as we wish to interest our fair countrywomen, in its favour, it is proper, on
name: Real College Essays

text: our part, to tell them, frankly, that equestrianism is far from being an intuitive art:--there
name: Real College Essays

text: is no "royal road" to it. To be enjoyed and appreciated, it must be learnt. That ease and elegance,--that
name: Real College Essays

text: comparative safety in the side-saddle, of which we have spoken,--it is impossible to achieve,
name: Real College Essays

text: without considerable practice, based upon proper principles. Many young ladies, however, feel
name: Real College Essays

text: a delicate repugnance to passing through the ordeal of a riding-school; some, again, do not
name: Real College Essays

text: reside in situations, where the benefit of a teacher's directions can be procured; while others,
name: Real College Essays

text: erroneously flatter themselves, that they are in possession of every needful acquirement, as
name: Real College Essays

text: regards equestrianism, when they have discovered how to retain a seat on the saddle, and guide
name: Real College Essays

text: a horse by means of the bridle. To such of our readers as happen to be comprised within either
name: Real College Essays

text: of these classes,--and to those, also, who, after having received a professor's initiative
name: Real College Essays

text: instructions, are desirous of further improvement, the following pages, if carefully perused,
name: Real College Essays

text: will, the writer most zealously hopes, prove beneficial.
name: Real College Essays

text: Since writing the above, we have been assured by a friend, that, within a few weeks
name: Real College Essays

text: past, he has seen several ladies, at Brighton, seated on the wrong side of the horse. Side-saddles,
name: Real College Essays

text: with moveable crutches, indeed, are now far from uncommon (to our own knowledge), in saddlers'
name: Real College Essays

text: shops.
name: Real College Essays

text: A few, among the most generally adopted, of these, it will be expedient, in the first place,
name: Real College Essays

text: to notice and explain.
name: Real College Essays

text: Most parts in the external structure of the horse are known by names of obvious signification:
name: Real College Essays

text: but such is not, exactly, the case with all.
name: Real College Essays

text: To commence with the anterior limb:--a is the fore pastern; b, the fetlock; c, the leg; and
name: Real College Essays

text: d, the arm.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the hind limb, e is the hind pastern; f, the hock; g, the stifle; and h, the haunch.
name: Real College Essays

text: The upper surface of the neck, i, is denominated the crest; k, the withers, and l, the croup.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the bridle, supposing it to be double-reined, a is the double head-stall; b, the front;
name: Real College Essays

text: c, the nose-band; d, the throat-lash; e, e, the snaffle rein; and f, f, the curb rein. At g,
name: Real College Essays

text: g, is the martingale.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the saddle, a, is the near crutch; b, the off crutch; c, the cantle; d, the crupper; e,
name: Real College Essays

text: the safe; f, the skirt; g, the stirrup; h, the near side half of the surcingle; and i, i, the
name: Real College Essays

text: girths.
name: Real College Essays

text: A lady's right hand is termed the whip-hand, and her left, the bridle-hand.
name: Real College Essays

text: The near side of a horse is that which is on the left of the rider; and the off side that which
name: Real College Essays

text: is on her right.
name: Real College Essays

text: The height of a horse is always estimated in hands, of four inches each: it is always measured
name: Real College Essays

text: at the tip of the shoulder. A horse is never spoken of as being so many hands tall, but so
name: Real College Essays

text: many hands high.
name: Real College Essays

text: Although the lady usually has a horse selected for her, by some gentleman, either of her own
name: Real College Essays

text: family or her acquaintance, it may not be inexpedient to inform the fair reader of those qualities
name: Real College Essays

text: which, combined in the same animal, may be said to constitute a complete lady's horse. Such
name: Real College Essays

text: a creature, however, we must observe, is exceedingly difficult to be procured, even by those
name: Real College Essays

text: possessed of the nicest judgment on the subject; and, to whom, the usually important question
name: Real College Essays

text: of price is not an object of consideration.
name: Real College Essays

text: The beau ideal of this kind of horse is superlatively elegant in form, exquisitely fine in
name: Real College Essays

text: coat, and unexceptionably beautiful in colour; of a height, in the nicest degree appropriate
name: Real College Essays

text: to the figure of the rider; graceful, accurate, well-united, and thoroughly safe in every pace;
name: Real College Essays

text: light as a feather in the hand, though not at all painfully sensitive to a proper action
name: Real College Essays

text: of the bit; bold in the extreme, yet superlatively docile; free, in every respect, from what
name: Real College Essays

text: is technically denominated "vice;" excellent in temper, but still "though gentle, yet not dull;"
name: Real College Essays

text: rarely, if ever, requiring the stimulus of the whip, yet submitting temperately to its occasional
name: Real College Essays

text: suggestions.
name: Real College Essays

text: In some, though not in all respects, the form should approach closely to that of a thorough-bred
name: Real College Essays

text: animal. The head should be small, neat, "well-set" on the neck, and gracefully "carried." The
name: Real College Essays

text: nostrils should be wide; the eyes large, rather protruding, dark, yet brilliant; the ears erect,
name: Real College Essays

text: and delicately tapering towards their tips. The expression of the countenance should be lively,
name: Real College Essays

text: animated, noble, and most highly intelligent; the neck rather arched and muscular; the ridge
name: Real College Essays

text: of the shoulders narrow and elevated; the chest full and fleshy; the back broad; the body,
name: Real College Essays

text: round or barrel-like; the space between the hips and tail, long, and very gradually depressed
name: Real College Essays

text: towards the latter organ, which, it is essential, should be based high on the croup. The fore
name: Real College Essays

text: and hind limbs should be distant, the one pair from the other; the "arms" muscular; the knees
name: Real College Essays

text: broad, the hocks (laterally) wide; the legs flat and sinewy; the pasterns rather long; and
name: Real College Essays

text: the hoofs large, and nearly round.
name: Real College Essays

text: A rough, or, what is technically termed, a "staring" coat, considerably deteriorates the appearance
name: Real College Essays

text: of a horse, however perfect in other conditions. Its surface, on a well-bred, healthy, and
name: Real College Essays

text: properly groomed animal, is not only smooth, but brilliantly polished. The mane, if too long
name: Real College Essays

text: and thick, will interfere with that delicate management of the reins so desirable to a lady
name: Real College Essays

text: on horseback; and the tail, if of immoderate length, will, by the animal's whisking it towards
name: Real College Essays

text: his sides, prove inconvenient, to the fair rider, at all times; but, especially so, in dirty
name: Real College Essays

text: weather. Neither of these appendages, however, on the other hand, should be ungracefully brief
name: Real College Essays

text: or scanty.
name: Real College Essays

text: Of all colours presented by the horse, none is so rich, and, at the same time, so elegant and
name: Real College Essays

text: chaste, as a bright bay; provided the mane, tail, and lower parts of the legs, be black. A
name: Real College Essays

text: small white star on the forehead, and a white speck on one of the heels, are to be considered,
name: Real College Essays

text: rather, as beauties, than defects: but much white, either on the face or legs, whatever be
name: Real College Essays

text: the general hue, is quite the reverse of desirable. After bright bay, chestnut, perhaps, deserves
name: Real College Essays

text: to rank next in the scale of taste; provided it be not, as is very frequently the case, accompanied
name: Real College Essays

text: with white legs. Some of the various shades of grey, however, are, in the opinion of many,
name: Real College Essays

text: entitled to be placed above it: of these, the silver grey, with black mane and tail, claims
name: Real College Essays

text: the highest place. Brown is rather exceptionable, on account of its dulness. Black is not much
name: Real College Essays

text: admired; though, as we think, when of a deep jet, remarkably elegant. Roan, sorrel, dun, piebald,
name: Real College Essays

text: mouse, and even cream colour (however appropriate the latter may be for a state-carriage-horse)
name: Real College Essays

text: are all to be eschewed.
name: Real College Essays

text: The height of her horse should be in harmonious proportion with that of the rider. A very young
name: Real College Essays

text: or short lady is in no less false a position, as regards grace, on a lofty steed, than a tall,
name: Real College Essays

text: full-grown woman, on a diminutive pony. For ladies of the general stature, a horse measuring
name: Real College Essays

text: from fifteen to fifteen and a half hands, at the point of the shoulder, is usually considered,
name: Real College Essays

text: as regards height, more desirable than any other.
name: Real College Essays

text: In paces, the lady's horse should be perfect; or, at all events, so far as regards the walk
name: Real College Essays

text: and canter. The former should be fast, bold, firm, and lively, without being unsteady; and,
name: Real College Essays

text: the latter, light, easy, well-combined, and graceful: so, too, should the hand-gallop; although,
name: Real College Essays

text: it is true, a lady's horse is rarely put to this pace, unless used for the field. The trot,
name: Real College Essays

text: again, is but little practised: still the complete lady's horse is expected to be capable of
name: Real College Essays

text: performing it with great precision of step, and but little concussion to the rider:--many ladies
name: Real College Essays

text: regarding it,--however discountenanced by the majority, perhaps,--as preferable, from its vigour,
name: Real College Essays

text: liveliness, and dash, to any other pace.
name: Real College Essays

text: To expatiate on the absolute necessity of the lady's horse being safe on his limbs, would be
name: Real College Essays

text: needless.
name: Real College Essays

text: The mouth should be sensible of the most delicate hint of the rider's will, communicated to
name: Real College Essays

text: it by means of the bit. A horse that pulls hard, or hangs heavily upon the reins, is very unsuitable
name: Real College Essays

text: for a lady's use: so, again, is one having the mouth so tender as to suffer from moderate pressure,
name: Real College Essays

text: either by the snaffle or the curb. The former is no less fatiguing to, than the latter is distressed
name: Real College Essays

text: by, the bridle hand.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the selection of these, a lady has a fair opportunity for the proper display of a refined
name: Real College Essays

text: and judicious taste. All that is gaudy, needless, or even elaborate, is vulgar. Perfect simplicity,
name: Real College Essays

text: indeed, as regards, not only her own costume, but "the trappings of her palfrey," is expected,
name: Real College Essays

text: at the present day, on the part of every well-bred female equestrian.
name: Real College Essays

text: The habit should fit the bust, without a crease: but, beneath the waist, it ought to be, not
name: Real College Essays

text: only long, but, somewhat full and flowing. Its colour should be dark as possible, without being
name: Real College Essays

text: positively black.
name: Real College Essays

text: The hair should be plaited; or, if otherwise dressed, so arranged and secured, that it may
name: Real College Essays

text: not be blown into the rider's eyes; nor, from exercise, or the effect of humid weather, be
name: Real College Essays

text: liable to be so discomposed, as to become embarrassing.
name: Real College Essays

text: To ride in a bonnet is far from judicious. A hat, or neat undress military cap, is indispensable
name: Real College Essays

text: to the female equestrian. It should be secured most carefully to the head: for, the loss of
name: Real College Essays

text: it would not merely be inconvenient, but, perhaps, dangerous, from the startling effect which
name: Real College Essays

text: its fall might produce on the sensitive temperament of the horse.
name: Real College Essays

text: A veil is the reverse of objectionable, provided it be of moderate length, and safely tied
name: Real College Essays

text: to the hat or cap; which, it is proper to state, should have no other ornament or appendage.
name: Real College Essays

text: The whip should be exquisitely neat and highly finished; but with little, if any, decoration.
name: Real College Essays

text: ACCOUTREMENTS FOR THE HORSE.
name: Real College Essays

text: Every accoutrement for the horse, however ornamental and pictorial, beyond the mere saddle
name: Real College Essays

text: and bridle, is to be rejected, as being in bad taste. The crupper and breast-band are now almost
name: Real College Essays

text: obsolete; the saddle-cloth has nearly disappeared; nettings are, generally speaking, abandoned;
name: Real College Essays

text: and the martingale itself, valuable as it may be for horses of a certain character, is rarely
name: Real College Essays

text: to be seen. Simplicity, indeed, as regards female equestrianism, is now imperatively (and,
name: Real College Essays

text: strange to say, most judiciously) enjoined, by "that same fickle goddess, Fashion," in obedience
name: Real College Essays

text: to whose sovereign behest, a lady's horse, in the olden time, was disguised, as it were, "in
name: Real College Essays

text: cloth of gold most curiously wrought."
name: Real College Essays

text: RULES OF THE ROAD.
name: Real College Essays

text: Without a knowledge of these, the fair equestrian, when riding in public, would be exposed
name: Real College Essays

text: to considerable inconvenience, and, often, to no slight degree of danger. In other words, when
name: Real College Essays

text: the former is the case, the right hands of the parties meeting, are towards each other; and,
name: Real College Essays

text: in the latter, the left hand of the faster, is towards the right hand of the slower. It follows,
name: Real College Essays

text: therefore, that when the rider is about to meet horses or carriages, she should take her ground
name: Real College Essays

text: on her near, or left, side of the road; and, when about to pass those travelling in the same
name: Real College Essays

text: direction with, though at a less speedy pace than, herself, on her right, or off. In meeting
name: Real College Essays

text: one rider, or vehicle, and, at the same time, passing, by superior speed, another, she must
name: Real College Essays

text: leave the first, on her right, and the second, on her left.
name: Real College Essays

text: It will not be inexpedient, under the present head, to make some observations as to which side
name: Real College Essays

text: the lady should take, when riding in company with a gentleman. Adams, a teacher of equitation,
name: Real College Essays

text: and the author of a work on the subject, remarks, that the only inducements for a gentleman
name: Real College Essays

text: to ride on the left of a lady, would be, that, by having his right hand towards her, in case
name: Real College Essays

text: of her needing assistance, he might, the more readily and efficiently, be enabled to afford
name: Real College Essays

text: it, than if he were on the opposite side; and, should any disarrangement occur in the skirt
name: Real College Essays

text: of her habit, he might screen it until remedied. On the other hand, our author observes, with
name: Real College Essays

text: great good sense, though in terms somewhat homely,--addressing, it is to be noticed, his remarks
name: Real College Essays

text: to gentlemen,--"the inconvenience of riding on the left of the lady, is, that if you ride near,
name: Real College Essays

text: to give her any assistance, you are liable to rub, or incommode, the lady's legs, and alarm
name: Real College Essays

text: her; and the spur is liable to catch, or tear, the lady's habit: if the roads are dirty, your
name: Real College Essays

text: horse, likewise, bespatters the lady's habit. On the right hand of the lady, these inconveniences
name: Real College Essays

text: do not occur, if you ride ever so close; and you are situated next the carriages, and the various
name: Real College Essays

text: objects you meet, which, in narrow roads, or, passing near, might intimidate a lady. For these
name: Real College Essays

text: reasons, I think it most proper to take the right hand of a lady."
name: Real College Essays

text: MOUNTING.
name: Real College Essays

text: On approaching a horse, the skirt of the habit should be gracefully gathered up, and the whip
name: Real College Essays

text: be carried in the right hand.
name: Real College Essays

text: It is the groom's duty, when the rider approaches, to gather up the reins with his left hand,
name: Real College Essays

text: smoothly and evenly, the curb rein between, and somewhat tighter than the bridoon, properly
name: Real College Essays

text: dividing them with his fore-finger. The lady advancing, on the near side of the horse, to the
name: Real College Essays

text: saddle, receives them a little more forward than the point of the horse's shoulder, with her
name: Real College Essays

text: right hand, which still retains and passes the whip over the saddle to the off or right side.
name: Real College Essays

text: On taking the bridle in this manner, her fore-finger is placed between the reins: the groom
name: Real College Essays

text: then removes his hand, and the lady draws her own back, suffering the reins to glide gently
name: Real College Essays

text: and evenly through her fingers, until she reaches the near crutch of the saddle, which she
name: Real College Essays

text: takes with her right hand, still holding the whip and reins, and places herself close to the
name: Real College Essays

text: near side of the horse, with her back almost turned towards him. The groom now quits his former
name: Real College Essays

text: post, and prepares to assist her to mount. The horse being thus left to the lady's government,
name: Real College Essays

text: it is proper, that, in passing her hand through the reins she should not have suffered them
name: Real College Essays

text: to become so loose as to prevent her, when her hand is on the crutch, from having a light,
name: Real College Essays

text: but steady bearing on the bit, and thus keeping the horse to his position during the process
name: Real College Essays

text: of mounting. She next places her left foot firmly in the right hand of the groom, or gentleman,
name: Real College Essays

text: in attendance, who stoops to receive it. The lady then puts her left hand on his right shoulder;
name: Real College Essays

text: and, straightening her left knee, bears her weight on the assistant's hand; which he gradually
name: Real College Essays

text: raises (rising, himself, at the same time) until she is seated on the saddle. During her elevation,
name: Real College Essays

text: she steadies, and even, if necessary, partly assists herself towards the saddle by her hands;
name: Real College Essays

text: one of which, it will be recollected, is placed on the crutch, and the other on her assistant's
name: Real College Essays

text: shoulder. It is important that she should keep her foot firm and her knee straight.
name: Real College Essays

text: If these directions be well attended to, she will find herself raised to her saddle with but
name: Real College Essays

text: a trifling exertion, either, on her own part, or that of the assistant. Should the latter be
name: Real College Essays

text: a lad only, or a groom not much accustomed to this part of his business, he should use both
name: Real College Essays

text: hands instead of one;--joining them by the fingers: indeed, this, generally speaking, is the
name: Real College Essays

text: safer mode. The lady, in all cases, should take care that her weight be well balanced on her
name: Real College Essays

text: left foot, from which she should rise as perpendicularly as possible; above all things taking
name: Real College Essays

text: care not to put her foot forward, but keeping it directly under her. The assistant should not
name: Real College Essays

text: begin to raise her until she has removed her right foot from the ground, and, by strengthening
name: Real College Essays

text: her knee, thrown her weight completely into his hand.
name: Real College Essays

text: Having reached the saddle, while her face is still turned to the near side of the horse, and
name: Real College Essays

text: before she places her knee on the pommel, the assistant puts the lady's left foot in the stirrup,
name: Real College Essays

text: while she removes her hand from the near to the off crutch of the saddle, holding the whip
name: Real College Essays

text: and reins as before directed. She now raises herself on the stirrup by the aid of her right
name: Real College Essays

text: hand, while the assistant, or the lady herself, with her left hand, draws the habit forward
name: Real College Essays

text: in its place. She then places her right knee between the crutches, and her seat is taken.
name: Real College Essays

text: Should the back part of the habit at this time, or afterwards, in the course of the ride, require
name: Real College Essays

text: any arrangement, the lady raises herself in the stirrup, by strengthening her knee, and, with
name: Real College Essays

text: her left hand, disposes her habit to her satisfaction.
name: Real College Essays

text: THE REINS.
name: Real College Essays

text: Pupils, during their first lessons, may arrange the reins in the following manner:--The right
name: Real College Essays

text: hand is removed from the crutch of the saddle; the reins are separated, and one is held in
name: Real College Essays

text: each hand, passing up between the third and fourth fingers, the ends being brought over the
name: Real College Essays

text: fore-fingers, and held in their places by closing the thumbs upon them, and shutting the hands:
name: Real College Essays

text: these should be on a level with each other, at a little distance apart, three inches from the
name: Real College Essays

text: body, or thereabouts, with the knuckles of the little fingers in a line with the elbow. By
name: Real College Essays

text: slightly advancing the hands, or even relaxing the hold of the reins, the horse, if well trained,
name: Real College Essays

text: will go forward. The left hand is raised to turn to the near or left side, and the right hand
name: Real College Essays

text: to turn in an opposite direction. By slightly raising and approaching both hands toward the
name: Real College Essays

text: body, the horse may be made to stop. When either rein is acted on, to turn the horse, the other
name: Real College Essays

text: should be a little slackened, or the hand which holds it relaxed.
name: Real College Essays

text: As soon as the pupil has passed her noviciate in the art, she holds both reins in the left
name: Real College Essays

text: hand. Some ladies separate them by the third and fourth fingers; others, by one of these fingers
name: Real College Essays

text: only; and many, by the fourth and little finger: but the greater number use the latter alone
name: Real College Essays

text: for this purpose, passing the off or right rein over it, and bringing the near or left rein
name: Real College Essays

text: up beneath it. The reins are carried flat upon each other up through the hand, near the middle
name: Real College Essays

text: joint of the fore-finger, and the thumb is placed upon them so that their ends fall down in
name: Real College Essays

text: front of the knuckles. The elbow should neither be squeezed close to the side, nor thrust out
name: Real College Essays

text: into an awkward and unnatural position; but be carried easily and gracefully, at a moderate
name: Real College Essays

text: distance from the body. The thumb should be uppermost, and the hand so placed that the lower
name: Real College Essays

text: part of it be nearer the waist than the upper; the wrist should be slightly rounded, the little
name: Real College Essays

text: finger in a line with the elbow, and the nails turned towards the rider.
name: Real College Essays

text: With the reins in this position, the lady, if she wish her horse to advance, brings her thumb
name: Real College Essays

text: towards her, until the knuckles are uppermost, and the nails over the horse's shoulder: the
name: Real College Essays

text: reins, by this simple motion, are slackened sufficiently to permit him to move forward. After
name: Real College Essays

text: he is put in motion, the rider's hand should return to the first position, gradually; or it
name: Real College Essays

text: may be slightly advanced, and the thumb turned upwards immediately.
name: Real College Essays

text: To direct a horse to the left, let the thumb, which in the first position is uppermost, be
name: Real College Essays

text: turned to the right, the little finger to the left, and the back of the hand brought upwards.
name: Real College Essays

text: This movement is performed in a moment, and it will cause the left rein to hang slack, while
name: Real College Essays

text: the right is tightened so as to press against the horse's neck.
name: Real College Essays

text: To direct the horse to the right, the hand should quit the first position, the nails be turned
name: Real College Essays

text: upwards, the little finger brought in towards the right, and the thumb moved to the left: the
name: Real College Essays

text: left rein will thus press the neck, while the right one is slackened.
name: Real College Essays

text: To stop the horse, or make him back, the nails should be turned, from the first position, upwards,
name: Real College Essays

text: the knuckles be reversed, and the wrist be rounded as much as possible.
name: Real College Essays

text: THE SEAT AND BALANCE.
name: Real College Essays

text: The body should always be in a situation, as well to preserve the balance, as to maintain the seat.
name: Real College Essays

text: One of the most common errors committed by ladies on horseback, who have not been properly
name: Real College Essays

text: taught to ride is hanging by the near crutch, so that, instead of being gracefully seated in
name: Real College Essays

text: the centre of the saddle, with the head in its proper situation, and the shoulders even, the
name: Real College Essays

text: body is inclined to the left, the head is brought to the right by an inelegant bend of the
name: Real College Essays

text: neck, the right shoulder is elevated, and the left depressed.
name: Real College Essays

text: To correct or avoid these and similar faults, is important. All the rider's movements should
name: Real College Essays

text: harmonize with the paces of the animal: her position should be at once easy to herself and
name: Real College Essays

text: to her horse; and alike calculated to ensure her own safety and give her a perfect command
name: Real College Essays

text: over the animal. If she sit in a careless, ungraceful manner, the action of her horse will
name: Real College Essays

text: be the reverse of elegant. A lady seldom appears to greater advantage than when mounted on
name: Real College Essays

text: a fine horse, if her deportment be graceful, and her positions correspond with his paces and
name: Real College Essays

text: attitudes; but the reverse is the case, if, instead of acting with, and influencing the movements
name: Real College Essays

text: of the horse, she appear to be tossed to and fro, and overcome by them. She should rise, descend,
name: Real College Essays

text: advance, and stop with, and not after the animal. From this harmony of motion result ease,
name: Real College Essays

text: elegance, and the most brilliant effect. The lady should sit in such a position, that the weight
name: Real College Essays

text: of the body may rest on the centre of the saddle. One shoulder should not be advanced more
name: Real College Essays

text: than the other. Neither must she bear any weight on the stirrup, nor hang by the crutch towards
name: Real College Essays

text: the near side. She ought not to suffer herself to incline forward, but partially backward.
name: Real College Essays

text: If she bend forward, her shoulders will, most probably, be rounded, and her weight thrown too
name: Real College Essays

text: much upon the horse's withers: in addition to these disadvantages, the position will give her
name: Real College Essays

text: an air of timid gaucherie. Leaning a little backward, on the contrary, tends to bring the shoulders
name: Real College Essays

text: in, keeps the weight in its proper bearing, and produces an appearance of graceful confidence.
name: Real College Essays

text: The head should be in an easy, natural position: that is, neither drooping forward nor thrown
name: Real College Essays

text: back; neither leaning to the right nor to the left. The bust should be elegantly developed,
name: Real College Essays

text: by throwing back the shoulders, advancing the chest, and bending the back part of the waist
name: Real College Essays

text: inward. The elbows should be steady, and kept in an easy, and apparently unconstrained position,
name: Real College Essays

text: near the sides. The lower part of the arm should form a right angle with the upper part, which
name: Real College Essays

text: ought to descend almost perpendicularly from the shoulder. The position of the hands, when
name: Real College Essays

text: both are occupied with the reins, or when the reins are held in one only, we have already noticed:
name: Real College Essays

text: the right arm and hand, in the latter case, may depend, easily, from the shoulder, and the
name: Real College Essays

text: whip be held in the fingers, with the lash downward, between two fingers and the thumb. The
name: Real College Essays

text: whip may also be carried in the right hand, in the manner adopted by gentlemen: the lady is
name: Real College Essays

text: not restricted to any precise rules in this respect, but may vary the position of her whip
name: Real College Essays

text: arm as she may think fit, so that she do not permit it to appear ungraceful. She must, however,
name: Real College Essays

text: take care that the whip be so carried, that its point do not tickle or irritate the flank of
name: Real College Essays

text: the horse.
name: Real College Essays

text: The stirrup is of very little use except to support the left foot and leg, and to assist the
name: Real College Essays

text: rider to rise in the trot: generally speaking, therefore, as we have already remarked, none
name: Real College Essays

text: of the weight of the body should be thrown upon the stirrup. The left leg must not be cramped
name: Real College Essays

text: up, but assume an easy and comfortable position: it should neither be forced out, so as to
name: Real College Essays

text: render the general appearance ungraceful, and the leg itself fatigued; nor, should it be pressed
name: Real College Essays

text: close to the horse, except when used as an aid; but descend gracefully by his side, without
name: Real College Essays

text: bearing against it.
name: Real College Essays

text: Although hanging by the left crutch of the saddle, over the near side, is not only inelegant,
name: Real College Essays

text: but objectionable in many important respects, the near crutch, properly used, is a lady's principal
name: Real College Essays

text: dependence on horseback. The right knee being passed over the near crutch, the toes being slightly
name: Real College Essays

text: depressed, and the leg pressed against the fore part of the saddle, the pommel is grasped,
name: Real College Essays

text: and the rider well secured in the possession of her seat. It is said, that when a lady, while
name: Real College Essays

text: her horse is going at a smart trot, can lean over, on the right side, far enough to see the
name: Real College Essays

text: horse's shoe, she may be supposed to have established a correct seat; which, we repeat, she
name: Real College Essays

text: should spare no pains to acquire. In some of the schools, a pupil is often directed to ride
name: Real College Essays

text: without the stirrup, and, with her arms placed behind her, while the master holds the long
name: Real College Essays

text: rein, and urges the horse to various degrees of speed, and in different directions, in order
name: Real College Essays

text: to settle her firmly and gracefully on the saddle,--to convince her that there is security
name: Real College Essays

text: without the stirrup,--and to teach her to accompany, with precision and ease, the various movements
name: Real College Essays

text: of the horse.
name: Real College Essays

text: Nothing can be more detrimental to the grace of a lady's appearance on horseback, than a bad
name: Real College Essays

text: position: a recent author says, it is a sight that would spoil the finest landscape in the
name: Real College Essays

text: world. What can be much more ridiculous, than the appearance of a female, whose whole frame,
name: Real College Essays

text: through mal-position, seems to be the sport of every movement of the horse? If the lady be
name: Real College Essays

text: not mistress of her seat, and be unable to maintain a proper position of her limbs and body,
name: Real College Essays

text: so soon as her horse starts into a trot, she runs the risk of being tossed about on the saddle,
name: Real College Essays

text: like the Halcyon of the poets in her frail nest,--
name: Real College Essays

text: "Floating upon the boisterous rude sea."
name: Real College Essays

text: If the animal should canter, his fair rider's head will be jerked to and fro as "a vexed weathercock;"
name: Real College Essays

text: her drapery will be blown about, instead of falling gracefully around her; and her elbows rise
name: Real College Essays

text: and fall, or, as it were, flap up and down like the pinions of an awkward nestling endeavouring
name: Real College Essays

text: to fly. To avoid such disagreeable similes being applied to her, the young lady, who aspires
name: Real College Essays

text: to be a good rider, should, even from her first lesson in the art, strive to obtain a proper
name: Real College Essays

text: deportment on the saddle. She ought to be correct, without seeming stiff or formal: and easy,
name: Real College Essays

text: without appearing slovenly. The position we have described, subject to occasional variations,
name: Real College Essays

text: will be found, by experience, to be the most natural and graceful mode of sitting a horse:--it
name: Real College Essays

text: is easy to the rider and her steed; and enables the former to govern the actions of the latter
name: Real College Essays

text: so effectually, in all ordinary cases, as to produce that harmony of motion, which is so much
name: Real College Essays

text: and so deservedly admired.
name: Real College Essays

text: The balance is conducive to the ease, elegance, and security of the rider:--it consists in
name: Real College Essays

text: a foreknowledge of the direction which any given motion of the horse will impart to the body,
name: Real College Essays

text: and a ready adaptation of the whole frame to the proper position, before the animal has completed
name: Real College Essays

text: his change of attitude or action;--it is that disposition of the person, in accordance with
name: Real College Essays

text: the movements of the horse, which prevents it from an undue inclination, forward or backward,
name: Real College Essays

text: to the right or to the left.
name: Real College Essays

text: By the direction and motion of the horse's legs the balance is governed. If the animal be either
name: Real College Essays

text: standing still, or merely walking straight-forward, the body should be preserved in the simple
name: Real College Essays

text: position which we have directed the lady to assume on taking her seat. Should it be necessary
name: Real College Essays

text: to apply the whip, so as to make the animal quicken his pace, or to pull him in suddenly, the
name: Real College Essays

text: body must be prepared to accommodate itself to the animal's change of action. When going round
name: Real College Essays

text: a corner at a brisk pace, or riding in a circle, the body should lean back rather more than
name: Real College Essays

text: in the walking position: to the same extent that the horse bends inward, must the body lean
name: Real College Essays

text: in that direction. If a horse shy at any object, and either turn completely and suddenly round,
name: Real College Essays

text: or run on one side only, the body should, if possible, keep time with his movements, and adapt
name: Real College Essays

text: itself so as to turn or swerve with him; otherwise, the balance will be lost, and the rider
name: Real College Essays

text: be in danger of falling, on the side from which the animal starts. In no case, let it be remembered,
name: Real College Essays

text: should the rider endeavour to assist herself in preserving her balance, by pulling at the reins.
name: Real College Essays

text: AIDS AND DEFENCES.
name: Real College Essays

text: All such motions of the body, the hands, the legs, and the whip, as either indicate the rider's
name: Real College Essays

text: wishes, or, in some degree, assist the horse to fulfil them, are, in the art of riding, denominated
name: Real College Essays

text: aids; and those movements of the rider which tend to save the animal from disuniting himself,
name: Real College Essays

text: or running into danger, may, properly enough, be classed under the same title: while such as
name: Real College Essays

text: act for the preservation of the rider, against the attempts of the horse, when headstrong or
name: Real College Essays

text: vicious, are termed defences.
name: Real College Essays

text: The aids of the hand are considered the most important: all the other actions of the rider
name: Real College Essays

text: tending, principally, to assist the bridle-hand and carry its operations into complete effect.
name: Real College Essays

text: There should be a perfect harmony in the aids; and all of them ought to be governed by those
name: Real College Essays

text: of the rein. In many instances, the power of a movement performed by the hand may be destroyed
name: Real College Essays

text: by the omission of a correct accompanying aid or defence, with the body, or the leg. Thus:--if
name: Real College Essays

text: a horse rear, it is useless for the rider to afford him a slack rein, if she do not also lean
name: Real College Essays

text: forward, in order, by throwing her weight on his fore-parts, to bring him down, and also to
name: Real College Essays

text: save herself from falling backward over his haunches. Should the rider, when her horse rises,
name: Real College Essays

text: slacken the reins, but retain her usual position on the saddle, if he rear high, she must necessarily
name: Real College Essays

text: be thrown off her balance; and then, if she hang on the bit, in order to save herself from
name: Real College Essays

text: falling, there is great danger of her pulling the horse backward.
name: Real College Essays

text: The aids and defences of the body are numerous: we shall attempt to describe a few of them;
name: Real College Essays

text: the residue must be acquired by practice, and the lady's own observation. When the rider indicates
name: Real College Essays

text: by her hand that she wishes the horse to advance, the body should be inclined forward in a
name: Real College Essays

text: slight degree; and the left leg (with the whip, also, if the animal be sluggish, or not well
name: Real College Essays

text: trained) pressed to his side. Should she, by pulling the rein towards her, or turning the wrist
name: Real College Essays

text: in the manner we have before directed, communicate her desire to stop, her body ought, at the
name: Real College Essays

text: same time, to be thrown back, with gentleness, or otherwise, in proportion to the severity
name: Real College Essays

text: of the action of the hand against the horse's inclination to increase his speed contrary to
name: Real College Essays

text: the will of his rider, or when he leaps, kicks, or plunges. If a horse rear, the rider should
name: Real College Essays

text: lean forward more than in the aid for the advance: but care must be taken, in this case, to
name: Real College Essays

text: perform the defence with discretion, especially with a pony, or galloway; for, should the animal
name: Real College Essays

text: rise suddenly, and the rider throw herself abruptly forward, it is not improbable that he might
name: Real College Essays

text: give her a violent blow on the face with the top of his head.
name: Real College Essays

text: We have already mentioned, in a previous part of our treatise, the direction which the body
name: Real College Essays

text: should take when riding in a circle, turning a corner, or acting as a defence against the danger
name: Real College Essays

text: attendant upon a horse's shying. In the first case, the aid of the body, if properly performed,
name: Real College Essays

text: will carry with it the aid of the hand, the leg, and even the whip, if it be held near the
name: Real College Essays

text: horse's side. We will explain this by an example:--Suppose the rider wishes to turn a corner
name: Real College Essays

text: on her left; she inclines a little towards it, drawing her left shoulder in, and thrusting
name: Real College Essays

text: her right shoulder rather forward: the bridle-hand will thus be drawn back on the near side,
name: Real College Essays

text: the off rein will consequently act on the horse's neck, and the left leg be pressed close against
name: Real College Essays

text: the near side; so that all the necessary aids for effecting her object, are performed by one
name: Real College Essays

text: natural and easy movement.
name: Real College Essays

text: The aids of the whip, on one side, correspond with those of the leg, on the other: they are
name: Real College Essays

text: not only used in the manner we have already mentioned, when the rider wishes her horse to advance,
name: Real College Essays

text: or increase his pace, but also in clearing a corner, &c. If the lady be desirous of turning
name: Real College Essays

text: to the left, she may materially aid the operation of the hand, which directs the fore-parts
name: Real College Essays

text: of the horse to the near side, by pressing him with her stirrup leg, so as to throw his croup
name: Real College Essays

text: in some degree to the right, and thereby place it in a more proper position to follow the direction
name: Real College Essays

text: of his shoulders. In turning to the right, the whip may be made equally useful by driving out
name: Real College Essays

text: his croup to the left. The power of these aids, especially that of the whip, should be increased
name: Real College Essays

text: as circumstances require. The aid which is sufficient for some horses, may not be powerful
name: Real College Essays
