text: enough by half for others: and even with, the same animal, while the slightest pressure will
name: Real College Essays

text: produce the desired effect in some cases, a moderate, or, even, a rather severe, lash with
name: Real College Essays

text: the whip is necessary in others.
name: Real College Essays

text: SOOTHINGS, ANIMATIONS, &c.
name: Real College Essays

text: The voice and the hand, the leg, and the whole body, may be employed to soothe and encourage.
name: Real College Essays

text: High-mettled or fretful horses, it is often necessary to soothe, and timid ones to encourage.
name: Real College Essays

text: A spirited animal is frequently impatient when first mounted, or, if a horse or a carriage
name: Real College Essays

text: pass him at a quick rate; and some horses are even so ardent and animated, as to be unpleasant
name: Real College Essays

text: to ride when with others. In either of these cases, the rider should endeavour to soothe her
name: Real College Essays

text: horse, by speaking to him in a calm, gentle tone. She should suffer the whip to be as motionless
name: Real College Essays

text: as possible, and take even more than usual care that its lash do not touch the flank. Her seat
name: Real College Essays

text: should be easy, her leg still, and her bridle-hand steady. The bit should not be made to press
name: Real College Essays

text: on the horse's mouth with greater severity than is necessary to maintain the rider's command;
name: Real College Essays

text: and, as the horse gradually subsides from his animation, its bearing should be proportionately
name: Real College Essays

text: relaxed. The perfection of soothing consists in the rider's sitting so entirely still and easy,
name: Real College Essays

text: as not to add in the least to the horse's animation;--at the same time being on her guard,
name: Real College Essays

text: so as to be able to effect any of her defences in an instant, should occasion render them needful.
name: Real College Essays

text: There is scarcely any difference between soothings and encouragements; except that, in the
name: Real College Essays

text: latter, it is advisable to pat, and, as it were, caress the horse with the right hand, holding
name: Real College Essays

text: the whip in the left. A shy or timid horse may often be encouraged to pass an object that alarms
name: Real College Essays

text: him, to cross a bridge, enter a gateway, or take a leap, when force and correction would only
name: Real College Essays

text: add to his fear, and, perhaps, render him incorrigibly obstinate.
name: Real College Essays

text: Animations are intended to produce greater speed, or, to render the horse more lively and on
name: Real College Essays

text: the alert, without increasing his pace. Some animals scarcely ever require animations; while
name: Real College Essays

text: others are so dull and deficient in mettle as to call them frequently into use. The slightest
name: Real College Essays

text: movement of the body, the hand, or the leg, is enough to rouse the well-bred and thoroughly-trained
name: Real College Essays

text: animal; but it is necessary for the animations to be so spirited and united, with sluggish
name: Real College Essays

text: horses, as almost to become corrections: in fact, what is a mere animation to one horse, would
name: Real College Essays

text: be a positive correction to another.
name: Real College Essays

text: The aids of the hand, the whip, the leg, and the body, which we have before described, are
name: Real College Essays

text: animations; so, also, are pattings with the hand, the tones of the voice, &c. Animations should
name: Real College Essays

text: be used in all cases, when the horse, contrary to the rider's inclination, either decreases
name: Real College Essays

text: his speed, droops his head, bears heavily and languidly on the bit, or, begins to be lazy or
name: Real College Essays

text: slovenly in the performance of his paces. A good rider foresees the necessity of an animation
name: Real College Essays

text: before the horse actually abates his speed, or loses the ensemble of his action, and the grace
name: Real College Essays

text: and spirit of his deportment. It is much easier to keep up, than to restore, a horse's animation:
name: Real College Essays

text: therefore, the whip, the leg, the hand, or the tongue, should do its office a few moments before,
name: Real College Essays

text: rather than at, the moment when its movements are indispensable.
name: Real College Essays

text: A slight motion of the fingers of the bridle-hand serves as an excellent animation: it reminds
name: Real College Essays

text: the horse of his duty, awakens the sensibility of his mouth, and preserves a proper correspondence
name: Real College Essays

text: between that and the hand.
name: Real College Essays

text: CORRECTIONS.
name: Real College Essays

text: Ladies certainly ought not to ride horses which require extraordinary correction. For numerous
name: Real College Essays

text: reasons, which must occur to our readers, a lady should never be seen in the act of positively
name: Real College Essays

text: flogging her steed: such a sight would destroy every previous idea that had been formed of
name: Real College Essays

text: her grace or gentleness. Moderate corrections are, however, sometimes necessary; and the fair
name: Real College Essays

text: rider should make no scruple of having recourse to them when absolutely needful, but not otherwise.
name: Real College Essays

text: Astley, in his work on the management of the horse, after very properly recommending all quarrels
name: Real College Essays

text: between the steed and his rider to be avoided, observes, that too much indulgence may induce
name: Real College Essays

text: the horse to consider "that you are afraid of him;" and, our author adds, "if he should once
name: Real College Essays

text: think you are really so, you will find he will exercise every means to convince you that he
name: Real College Essays

text: considers himself your master, instead of acknowledging, by implicit obedience, that you are his."
name: Real College Essays

text: Those, who imagine that a horse is to be corrected only with the whip, are very much mistaken.
name: Real College Essays

text: The aids and animations of the leg, the bridle-hand, the body, and the voice, may be made sufficiently
name: Real College Essays

text: severe to correct and render a horse obedient in all ordinary cases. Severe flogging seldom
name: Real College Essays

text: produces any good effect; and, in most contests between a horse and his rider, when both get
name: Real College Essays

text: out of temper, the former usually gains some important advantage. The best way to correct a
name: Real College Essays

text: horse is to dishearten, and make him do what he would fain avoid;--not so much by force and
name: Real College Essays

text: obstinate resolution, in contesting openly and directly with him, when he is perfectly prepared
name: Real College Essays

text: to resist, as, by a cool opposition and indirect means. There are different methods of attaining
name: Real College Essays

text: the same end; and those which are the least obvious to the animal should be adopted: a lady
name: Real College Essays

text: cannot rival him in physical strength, but she may conquer him by mere ingenuity, or subdue
name: Real College Essays

text: him by a calm, determined assumption of superior power.
name: Real College Essays

text: VICES.
name: Real College Essays

text: Some horses are addicted to a very troublesome and vicious habit of turning round suddenly,--we
name: Real College Essays

text: do not here allude to shyness, but restiveness,--without exhibiting any previous symptom of
name: Real College Essays

text: their intention. A horse soon ascertains that the left hand is weaker than the right, and,
name: Real College Essays

text: consequently, less able to oppose him; he, therefore, turns on the off side, and with such
name: Real College Essays

text: force and suddenness, that it is almost impossible, even if the rider be prepared for the attack,
name: Real College Essays

text: to prevent him.
name: Real College Essays

text: In this case, it would be unwise to make the attempt: the rider would be foiled, and the horse
name: Real College Essays

text: become encouraged, by his success in the struggle, to make similar endeavours to have his own
name: Real College Essays

text: way, or dismount his rider. The better plan is, instead of endeavouring to prevent him from
name: Real College Essays

text: turning, with the left hand, to pull him sharply with the right, until his head has made a
name: Real College Essays

text: complete circle, and he finds, to his astonishment, that he is precisely in the place from
name: Real College Essays

text: which he started.
name: Real College Essays

text: Should he repeat the turn, on the rider's attempting to urge him on, she should pull him round,
name: Real College Essays

text: on the same side, three or four times, and assist the power of the hand in so doing, by a smart
name: Real College Essays

text: aid of the whip, or the leg. While this is doing, she must take care to preserve her balance,
name: Real College Essays

text: by an inclination of her body to the centre of the circle described by the horse's head.
name: Real College Essays

text: The same plan may be pursued when a horse endeavours to turn a corner, contrary to the wish
name: Real College Essays

text: of his rider; and, if he be successfully baffled, three or four times, it is most probable
name: Real College Essays

text: that he will not renew his endeavours.
name: Real College Essays

text: On the same principle, when a horse refuses to advance, and whipping would increase his obstinacy,
name: Real College Essays

text: or make him rear, or bolt away in a different direction, it is advisable to make him walk backward,
name: Real College Essays

text: until he evinces a willingness to advance.
name: Real College Essays

text: A runaway might, in many instances, be cured of his vice by being suffered to gallop, unchecked,
name: Real College Essays

text: and being urged forward, when he shewed an inclination to abate his speed, rather than by attempting
name: Real College Essays

text: to pull him in: but this remedy is, in most situations, dangerous, even for men; and all other
name: Real College Essays

text: means should be tried before it is resorted to by a lady. Should our fair young reader have
name: Real College Essays

text: the misfortune to be mounted on a runaway, she may avoid evil consequences, if she can contrive
name: Real College Essays

text: to retain her self-possession, and act as we are about to direct. She must endeavour to maintain
name: Real College Essays

text: her seat, at all hazards, and to preserve the best balance, or position of body, to carry her
name: Real College Essays

text: defences into operation. The least symptom of alarm, on her part, will increase the terror
name: Real College Essays

text: or determination of the horse. A dead heavy pull at the bridle will rather aid him, than otherwise,
name: Real College Essays

text: in his speed, and prevent her from having sufficient mastery over his mouth and her own hands
name: Real College Essays

text: to guide him. She must, therefore, hold the reins in such a manner as to keep the horse together
name: Real College Essays

text: when at the height of his pace, and to guide him from running against anything in his course;
name: Real College Essays

text: and, it is most probable that he will soon abate his speed, and gradually subside into a moderate
name: Real College Essays

text: pace. Sawing the mouth (that is, pulling each rein alternately) will frequently bring a horse
name: Real College Essays

text: up, in a few minutes. Slackening the reins for an instant, and then jerking them with force,
name: Real College Essays

text: may also produce a similar effect: but, if the latter mode be adopted, the rider must take
name: Real College Essays

text: care that the horse, by stopping suddenly, do not bring her on his neck, or throw her over
name: Real College Essays

text: his head.
name: Real College Essays

text: In whatever manner the runaway be stopped, it is advisable for the lady to be on the alert,
name: Real College Essays

text: lest he should become so disunited, by the operation, as to fall.
name: Real College Essays

text: Our readers may think, perhaps, that this advice, however easy to give, is difficult to follow:
name: Real College Essays

text: we beg leave, however, to tell them, that although it is not so easy as drawing on a glove,
name: Real College Essays

text: or replacing a stray curl, it is much more practicable than they may imagine; though, we trust,
name: Real College Essays

text: they may never have occasion to put it to the proof.
name: Real College Essays

text: There is another situation, in which it is advisable to force the horse, apparently, to have
name: Real College Essays

text: his own way, in order to baffle his attempts. Restive horses, or even docile animals, when
name: Real College Essays

text: put out of temper, sometimes endeavour to crush their riders' legs against walls, gates, trees,
name: Real College Essays

text: posts, &c. An inexperienced lady, under such circumstances, would strive to pull the horse
name: Real College Essays

text: away; but her exertions would be unavailing: the animal would feel that he could master the
name: Real College Essays

text: opposition, and thus discovering the rider's weakness, turn it to her disadvantage on future
name: Real College Essays

text: occasions. We cannot too often repeat, that, although a rider should not desist until she have
name: Real College Essays

text: subdued her horse, she must never enter into an open, undisguised contest with him. It is useless
name: Real College Essays

text: to attack him on a point which he is resolute in defending: the assault should rather be directed
name: Real College Essays

text: to his weaker side. If he fortify himself in one place, he must proportionately diminish his
name: Real College Essays

text: powers of defence in another. He anticipates and prepares to resist any attempt to overcome
name: Real College Essays

text: him on his strong side; and his astonishment at being attacked on the other, and with success,
name: Real College Essays

text: on account of his weakness in that quarter, goes far to dishearten and subdue him. If he plant
name: Real College Essays

text: himself in a position of resistance against being forced to advance, it is a matter of very
name: Real College Essays

text: little difficulty to make him go back. If he appear to be determined not to go to the right,
name: Real College Essays

text: the rider may, on account of the mode in which he disposes his body and limbs, turn him, with
name: Real College Essays

text: great facility, to the left. If he stand stock-still, and will not move in any direction, his
name: Real College Essays

text: crime may be made his punishment: the rider, in such case, should sit patiently until he shew
name: Real College Essays

text: a disposition to advance, which he probably will in a very short time, when he discovers that
name: Real College Essays

text: she is not annoyed by his standing still. Nothing will subdue a horse so soon as this mode
name: Real College Essays

text: of turning his attacks against himself, and making his defences appear acts of obedience to
name: Real College Essays

text: the rider's inclination. When, therefore, a horse viciously runs on one side towards a wall,
name: Real College Essays

text: pull his head forcibly in the same direction and, if, by the aid of the leg or whip, you can
name: Real College Essays

text: drive his croup out, you may succeed in backing him completely away from it. It is by no means
name: Real College Essays

text: improbable, that when he finds that his rider is inclined to go to the wall as well as himself,
name: Real College Essays

text: he will desist. Should he not, his croup may be so turned, outward, that he cannot do his rider
name: Real College Essays

text: any mischief.
name: Real College Essays

text: In shying, the same principle may be acted upon, more advantageously, perhaps, than in any
name: Real College Essays

text: other case. Should the lady's horse be alarmed at any object, and, instead of going up to,
name: Real College Essays

text: or passing it, turn round, the rider should manage him as we have recommended in cases where
name: Real College Essays

text: the horse turns, through restiveness. He should then be soothed and encouraged, rather than
name: Real College Essays

text: urged by correction, to approach, or pass, the object that alarms him: to attempt to force
name: Real College Essays

text: him up to it would be ridiculous and dangerous. If the horse swerve from an object, and try
name: Real College Essays

text: to pass it at a brisk rate, it is useless to pull him towards it; for, if you succeed in bringing
name: Real College Essays

text: his head on one side, his croup will be turned outward, and his legs work in an opposite direction.
name: Real College Essays

text: This resistance will increase proportionately to the exertions made by the rider. A horse,
name: Real College Essays

text: in this manner, may fly from imaginary, into real danger; for he cannot see where he is going,
name: Real College Essays

text: nor what he may run against. Pulling in the rein, therefore, on the side from which the horse
name: Real College Essays

text: shies, is improper; it should rather be slackened, and the horse's head turned away from the
name: Real College Essays

text: object which terrifies him. By this mode, a triple advantage is gained: in the first place,
name: Real College Essays

text: the horse's attention is diverted to other things; secondly,--the dreaded object loses half
name: Real College Essays

text: its terror when he finds no intention manifested on the rider's part to force him nearer to
name: Real College Essays

text: it; and, lastly,--he is enabled to see, and, consequently, avoid any danger in front, or on
name: Real College Essays

text: the other side of him.
name: Real College Essays

text: A horse may be coaxed and encouraged to go up to the object that alarms him; and, if the rider
name: Real College Essays

text: succeed in making him approach it, a beneficial effect will be produced: the horse will discover
name: Real College Essays

text: that his fears were groundless, and be less likely to start again from any similar cause. After
name: Real College Essays

text: the first impulse of terror has subsided, the animal, if properly managed, will even manifest
name: Real College Essays

text: an inclination to approach and examine the object that alarmed him: but, while he is so doing,
name: Real College Essays

text: the rider must be on her guard; for the least movement, or timidity, on her part,--the rustling
name: Real College Essays

text: of a leaf, or the passing of a shadow,--will, in all probability, frighten him again, and he
name: Real College Essays

text: will start round more violently than before. After this, it will be exceedingly difficult to
name: Real College Essays

text: bring him up to the object. Astley, however, whom we have before quoted, says, that should
name: Real College Essays

text: the first trial prove unsuccessful, it must be repeated, until you succeed; adding, that the
name: Real College Essays

text: second attempt should not be made until the horse's fears have subsided, and his confidence
name: Real College Essays

text: returned.
name: Real College Essays

text: A horse that is rather shy, may, in many cases, be prevented from starting, by the rider turning
name: Real College Essays

text: his head a little away from those objects, which, she knows by experience, are likely to alarm
name: Real College Essays

text: him, as well before she approaches as while she passes them.
name: Real College Essays

text: A lady, certainly, should not ride a horse addicted to shying, stumbling, rearing, or any other
name: Real College Essays

text: vice: but she ought, nevertheless, to be prepared against the occurrence of either; for, however
name: Real College Essays

text: careful and judicious those persons, by whom her horse is selected, may be, and however long
name: Real College Essays

text: a trial she may have had of his temper and merits, she cannot be sure, when she takes the reins,
name: Real College Essays

text: that she may not have to use her defences against rearing or kicking, or be required to exercise
name: Real College Essays

text: her skill to save herself from the dangers attendant on starting or stumbling, before she dismounts.
name: Real College Essays

text: The quietest horse may exhibit symptoms of vice, even without any apparent cause, after many
name: Real College Essays

text: years of good behaviour; the best-tempered are not immaculate, nor the surest-footed infallible:
name: Real College Essays

text: it is wise, therefore, to be prepared.
name: Real College Essays

text: Stumbling is not merely unpleasant, but dangerous. To ride a horse that is apt to trip, is
name: Real College Essays

text: like dwelling in a ruin: we cannot be comfortable if we feel that we are unsafe; and, truly,
name: Real College Essays

text: there is no safety on the back of a stumbling nag. The best advice we can offer our reader,
name: Real College Essays

text: as to such an animal, is never to ride him after his demerits are discovered: although the
name: Real College Essays

text: best horse in the world, may, we must confess, make a false step, and even break his knees.
name: Real College Essays

text: When a horse trips, his head should be raised and supported, by elevating the hand; and the
name: Real College Essays

text: lady should instantly throw herself back, so as to relieve his shoulders from her weight. It
name: Real College Essays

text: is useless to whip a horse after stumbling (as it is, also, after shying); for, it is clear,
name: Real College Essays

text: he would not run the risk of breaking his knees, or his nose, if he could help it. If a horse
name: Real College Essays

text: be constantly punished for stumbling, the moment he has recovered from a false step, he will
name: Real College Essays

text: start forward, flurried and disunited, in fear of the whip, and not only put the rider to inconvenience,
name: Real College Essays

text: but run the risk of a repetition of his mishap, before he regains his self-possession. It being
name: Real College Essays

text: generally the practice,--and a very bad practice it is,--for riders to correct horses after
name: Real College Essays

text: having made a false step, an habitual stumbler may be easily detected. When a horse, that is
name: Real College Essays

text: tolerably safe, makes a false step, he gathers himself up, and is slightly animated for a moment
name: Real College Essays

text: or two only, or goes on as if nothing had happened; but if he be an old offender, he will remember
name: Real College Essays

text: the punishment he has repeatedly received immediately after a stumble, and dash forward in
name: Real College Essays

text: the manner we have described, expecting the usual flagellation for his misfortune.
name: Real College Essays

text: When a horse evinces any disposition to kick, or rear, the reins should be separated, and held
name: Real College Essays

text: by both hands, in the manner we have described in a previous page. This should also be done
name: Real College Essays

text: when he attempts to run away, grows restive, or shies. The body should also be put in its proper
name: Real College Essays

text: balance for performing the defences: the shoulders should be thrown back, the waist brought
name: Real College Essays

text: forward, and the head well poised on the neck. Every part of the frame must be flexible, but
name: Real College Essays

text: perfectly ready for action.
name: Real College Essays

text: The principal danger attendant on the horse's rearing is, that the rider may fall over the
name: Real College Essays

text: croup, and, perhaps, pull the horse backward upon her. To prevent either of these consequences,
name: Real College Essays

text: immediately that a horse rises, slacken the reins, and bend the body forward, so as to throw
name: Real College Essays

text: its weight on his shoulders; and the moment his fore-feet come to the ground,--having recovered
name: Real College Essays

text: your position, gradually, as he descends,--correct him smartly, if he will bear it; or, endeavour
name: Real College Essays

text: to pull him round two or three times, and thus divert him from his object.
name: Real College Essays

text: The latter course may also be adopted to prevent his rearing, if the rider should foresee his
name: Real College Essays

text: intention.
name: Real College Essays

text: A horse that displays any symptoms of kicking, should be held tight in hand. While his head
name: Real College Essays

text: is well kept up, he cannot do much mischief with his heels.
name: Real College Essays

text: If, however, when the rider is unprepared, in spite of her exertions he should get his head
name: Real College Essays

text: down, she must endeavour, by means of the reins, to prevent the animal from throwing himself;
name: Real College Essays

text: and also, by a proper inclination of her body backward, to save herself from being thrown forward.
name: Real College Essays

text: Should an opportunity occur, she must endeavour to give him two or three sharp turns: this
name: Real College Essays

text: may also be done, with advantage, if she detect any incipient attempts in the animal to kick.
name: Real College Essays

text: A horse inclined to rear seldom kicks much: but he may do both alternately; and the rider should
name: Real College Essays

text: be prepared against his attempts, by keeping her balance in readiness for either of the opponent
name: Real College Essays

text: defences. She must also take care, that, while she is holding her horse's head up and well
name: Real College Essays

text: in hand to keep him from kicking, she do not cause him to rear, by too great a degree of pressure
name: Real College Essays

text: on his mouth.
name: Real College Essays

text: EXERCISES IN THE PACES.
name: Real College Essays

text: Although our limits will not permit us to enter into an elaborate detail of the lessons taken
name: Real College Essays

text: by a pupil in the riding school, it is right that we should give the learner a few useful hints
name: Real College Essays

text: on the rudiments of riding, and not devote our whole space to the improvement of those who
name: Real College Essays

text: have made considerable progress. While we endeavour to correct bad habits in the self-taught
name: Real College Essays

text: artist,--in the pupil of a kind friend, an affectionate relative, or of a mere groom,--to confirm
name: Real College Essays

text: the regularly educated equestrian in the true principles and practice of the art,--to remind
name: Real College Essays

text: her of what she has forgotten, and to improve upon the knowledge she may have acquired,--we
name: Real College Essays

text: must not forget those among our young friends, who, having never mounted a horse, are desirous
name: Real College Essays

text: of learning how to ride with grace and propriety, and who dwell at a distance, or do not feel
name: Real College Essays

text: inclined to take lessons, from a master. To such, one-third, at least, of our preceding observations
name: Real College Essays

text: are applicable; and we recommend an attentive perusal of what we have said, as to Mounting,
name: Real College Essays

text: the Aids, &c., before they aspire to the saddle. Our other remarks they will find useful when
name: Real College Essays

text: they have acquired a little practice.
name: Real College Essays

text: A quiet and well-trained horse, and a careful attendant, should, if possible, be procured.
name: Real College Essays

text: A horse, that knows his duty, will almost instruct his rider; and if a friend, who is accustomed
name: Real College Essays

text: to horses, or a careful servant, accompany the pupil, there is little or nothing to fear, even
name: Real College Essays

text: in the first attempts. The friend, or groom, may also, by his advice, materially assist the
name: Real College Essays

text: learner in her progress.
name: Real College Essays

text: It would be needless for us to repeat our advice as to the manner of mounting, holding the
name: Real College Essays

text: reins, making the horse advance, stop, turn, &c., or the proper disposition of the body and
name: Real College Essays

text: limbs: all these, in her early lessons, the pupil should gradually practise.
name: Real College Essays

text: THE WALK.
name: Real College Essays

text: Let the pupil walk the horse forward in a straight line, and at a slow rate, supporting his
name: Real College Essays

text: head in such a manner as to make him keep time in the beats of his pace; but not holding the
name: Real College Essays

text: reins so tight as to impede the measurement of his steps, or to make him break into a trot
name: Real College Essays

text: on being slightly animated. The hand should be so held, that it may delicately, but distinctly,
name: Real College Essays

text: feel, by the operation of the horse's mouth on the reins, every beat of his action. If he do
name: Real College Essays

text: not exert himself sufficiently, he should be somewhat animated. Should he break into a trot,
name: Real College Essays

text: he must be checked by the reins; but the pull must neither be so firm nor continued as to make
name: Real College Essays

text: him stop. The moment he obeys the rein and drops into a walk, the hand is to be relaxed. Should
name: Real College Essays

text: he require animating again, the movement for that purpose must be more gentle than before,
name: Real College Essays

text: lest he once more break into a trot.
name: Real College Essays

text: After walking in a straight line for a short time, the lady should practise the turn to the
name: Real College Essays

text: right and to the left; alternately using both hands in these operations, in the manner directed
name: Real College Essays

text: in a previous page. She must observe, that when she pulls the right rein in order to turn the
name: Real College Essays

text: horse on that side, the other hand must be relaxed and lowered, or advanced, to slacken the
name: Real College Essays

text: left rein and ease the horse's mouth, and vice vers?.
name: Real College Essays

text: If the horse do not readily obey the hand in turning, or bring forward his croup sufficiently,
name: Real College Essays

text: he must be urged to throw himself more on the bit, by an animation of the leg or whip. The
name: Real College Essays

text: animations, during the first lessons, should be commenced with great gentleness, and the rider
name: Real College Essays

text: will easily discover, by a little experience, to what degree it is necessary to increase them,
name: Real College Essays

text: in order to procure obedience. This observation should be attended to, were it only for the
name: Real College Essays

text: pupil's safety; for, if she begin with her animations above the horse's spirit, his courage
name: Real College Essays

text: will be so raised as to endanger, or, at least, alarm her, and thus render what would otherwise
name: Real College Essays

text: be an agreeable exercise, unpleasant.
name: Real College Essays

text: After the pupil has practised walking in a straight line, and turning on either side, for a
name: Real College Essays

text: few days, she may walk in a circle, and soon make her horse wheel, change, demi-volt, &c. The
name: Real College Essays

text: circle should be large at first; but when the pupil has acquired her proper equilibrium, &c.,
name: Real College Essays

text: it must, day by day, be gradually contracted.
name: Real College Essays

text: In riding round a circle, the inner rein should be rather lowered, and the body inclined inward.
name: Real College Essays

text: This inclination must be increased during succeeding lessons, as the circle is contracted,
name: Real College Essays

text: and the pupil quickens the pace of her horse. She must practise in the large circle, until
name: Real College Essays

text: she is able, by her hands and aids, to make the horse perform it correctly. The inside rein
name: Real College Essays

text: must be delicately acted upon; if it be jerked, at distant intervals, or borne upon, without
name: Real College Essays

text: intermission, the horse, in the former case, will swerve in and out, and, in the latter, the
name: Real College Essays

text: rider's hand, and the animal's mouth, will both become, in some degree, deadened; and thus
name: Real College Essays

text: their correspondence will be decreased. In order to procure correct action, the inner rein
name: Real College Essays

text: should be alternately borne on in a very slight degree, and relaxed the next instant,--the
name: Real College Essays

text: hand keeping exact time in its operations with the cadence of the horse's feet. The direction
name: Real College Essays

text: is to be frequently changed; the pupil alternately working to the right and the left, so as
name: Real College Essays

text: to bring both her hands into practice.
name: Real College Essays

text: As soon as the rider becomes tolerably well confirmed in her seat and balance, and in the performance
name: Real College Essays

text: of the simple aids and animations, as well in large as small circles, she should begin to ride
name: Real College Essays

text: in double circles; at first of considerable diameter, but decreasing them, by degrees, as she
name: Real College Essays

text: improves. Riding in double circles, is guiding the horse to perform a figure of 8; and this,
name: Real College Essays

text: in the language of the riding-school, is effecting the large and narrow change, according to
name: Real College Essays

text: the size of the circles. The number of the circles may be increased, and the sizes varied,
name: Real College Essays

text: with great advantage both to the rider and the horse. They may be at some distance from each
name: Real College Essays

text: other, and the horse be guided to work from one to the other diagonally. Thus, suppose he starts
name: Real College Essays

text: from a, he may be made to leave the upper circle at e, and enter the lower one at d; leave
name: Real College Essays

text: it at c, and enter the first again at b; and so continue for some time: then, beginning at
name: Real College Essays

text: f, to quit the lower circle at c, enter the upper one at b, leave it at e, and enter the lower
name: Real College Essays

text: circle again at d. Thus, the position of the rider and horse are alternately changed, from
name: Real College Essays

text: working from the right to a straight line, thence to the left, thence to a straight line, and
name: Real College Essays

text: thence again to the right. To give an instance of riding in a greater number of circles, of
name: Real College Essays

text: different diameters, let the horse start from a (see figure, p. 77), and leave the upper circle
name: Real College Essays

text: at b, traversing to the outer small circle at c, passing round, so as to enter the inner circle
name: Real College Essays

text: at e, and going round, by f, to g; quitting it at g, and entering the lower circle at h; quitting
name: Real College Essays

text: the latter again, after passing round i, at k, and thence proceeding towards the outer small
name: Real College Essays

text: circle; entering at l, going round and entering the inner circle at e, passing round, and quitting
name: Real College Essays

text: it at f, to return again to a, by entering the upper circle at m. These exercises may be diversified
name: Real College Essays

text: in various ways; the pupil, for instance, may perform the upper circle, and one or both of
name: Real College Essays

text: the pair below, return to the upper circle, cross from that, diagonally, to the lower circle,
name: Real College Essays

text: quit it, at h or k, to perform one of the middle circles, return to the lower circle again,
name: Real College Essays

text: pass thence to the other middle circle, and quit it at c or f (as the case may happen), to
name: Real College Essays

text: return to the upper circle again. Nothing can be more beneficial than this variety of action;
name: Real College Essays

text: it tends at once to confirm the pupil in her seat; to exercise her in her balance and aids;
name: Real College Essays

text: and to render the horse obedient: while, if he be kept in only one direction, he will perform
name: Real College Essays

text: the figure mechanically, without either improving his own mouth and action, or the rider's
name: Real College Essays

text: hands, aids, or balance.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the art of riding, working on a circle is called a volt; in angles, or a zig-zag direction,
name: Real College Essays

text: changes reverse; and on half a circle from a line, a demi-volt. These figures may first be
name: Real College Essays

text: performed separately; but there can be no objection to the demi-volt and changes reverse being
name: Real College Essays

text: afterwards embodied in the exercises on circles. As in the last figure, the lady may work from
name: Real College Essays

text: a in the mode directed, for some time; then perform the variations, by going across from a
name: Real College Essays

text: to b, and describe a demi-volt round by c e to a; then return from a to b, and work a demi-volt,
name: Real College Essays

text: in an opposite direction, from b to a: thence, the lady may proceed in a line, enter the lower
name: Real College Essays

text: circle at d, and re-commence riding in circles. The change reverse may at any time be performed,
name: Real College Essays

text: by quitting the upper circle at e or f, and working on the traversing lines, so as to cross
name: Real College Essays

text: the lower circle at g or h, and enter it at i or k. In fact, these exercises may be varied,
name: Real College Essays

text: ad libitum; and the more they are diversified, the greater advantage the lady will derive from
name: Real College Essays

text: them, provided she persevere until she can perform one figure with accuracy, before she enter
name: Real College Essays

text: upon another that is more complicated. Should the horse, in changing, yield his head, but withhold
name: Real College Essays

text: his croup so as to destroy the union of his action, or mar the perfection of the change, the
name: Real College Essays

text: rider should bring it to the proper position, or sequence, by an aid of the whip or leg, as
name: Real College Essays

text: the case may be.
name: Real College Essays

text: THE TROT.
name: Real College Essays

text: The lady should begin to practise this pace as soon as she is tolerably perfect in the walking
name: Real College Essays

text: lessons. It will be as well for her, at first, to trot in a straight line: she may then work
name: Real College Essays

text: in the large circle, and proceed, gradually, through most of the figures which she has performed
name: Real College Essays

text: in a walk. To make the horse advance from a walk to a trot, draw upwards the little finger
name: Real College Essays

text: of each hand (or that of the left hand only, when the pupil has advanced enough to hold the
name: Real College Essays

text: reins in one hand), and turn them towards the body: an animation of the leg or whip should
name: Real College Essays

text: accompany this motion. The trot should be commenced moderately: if the horse start off too
name: Real College Essays

text: rapidly, or increase the pace beyond the rider's inclination, she must check him by closing
name: Real College Essays

text: the hands firmly; and, if that will not suffice, by drawing the little fingers upwards and
name: Real College Essays

text: towards the body. This must not be done by a jerk, but delicately and gradually; and, as soon
name: Real College Essays

text: as the proper effect is produced, the reins are again to be slackened. If the horse do not
name: Real College Essays

text: advance with sufficient speed, or do not bring up his haunches well, the animations used at
name: Real College Essays

text: starting him are to be repeated. When the horse proceeds to the trot, the lady must endeavour
name: Real College Essays

text: to preserve her balance, steadiness and pliancy, as in the walk. The rise in trotting is to
name: Real College Essays

text: be acquired by practice. When the horse, in his action, raises the rider from her seat, she
name: Real College Essays

text: should advance her body, and rest a considerable portion of her weight on the right knee; by
name: Real College Essays

text: means of which, and by bearing the left foot on the stirrup, she may return to her former position
name: Real College Essays

text: without being jerked; the right knee and the left foot, used in the same manner, will also
name: Real College Essays

text: aid her in the rise. Particular attention must be paid to the general position of the body
name: Real College Essays

text: while trotting: in this pace, ordinary riders frequently rise to the left, which is a very
name: Real College Essays

text: bad practice, and must positively be avoided. The lady should also take care not to raise herself
name: Real College Essays

text: too high; the closer she maintains her seat, consistently with her own comfort, the better.
name: Real College Essays

text: THE CANTER.
name: Real College Essays

text: The whole of the exercises on circles should next be performed in a canter; which may be commenced
name: Real College Essays

text: from a short but animated trot, a walk, or even a stop. If the horse be well trained, a slight
name: Real College Essays

text: pressure of the whip and leg, and an elevation of the horse's head, by means of the reins,
name: Real College Essays

text: will make him strike into a canter. Should he misunderstand, or disobey these indications of
name: Real College Essays

text: the rider's will, by merely increasing his walk or trot, or going into the trot from a walk,
name: Real College Essays

text: as the case may be, he is to be pressed forward on the bit by an increased animation of the
name: Real College Essays

text: leg and whip;--the reins, at the same time, being held more firmly, in order to restrain him
name: Real College Essays

text: from advancing too rapidly to bring his haunches well under him; for the support of which,
name: Real College Essays

text: in this position, he will keep both his hind feet for a moment on the ground, while he commences
name: Real College Essays

text: the canter by raising his fore feet together.
name: Real College Essays

text: The canter is by far the most elegant and agreeable of all the paces, when properly performed
name: Real College Essays

text: by the horse and rider: its perfection consists in its union and animation, rather than its
name: Real College Essays

text: speed. It is usual with learners who practise without a master, to begin the canter previously
name: Real College Essays

text: to the trot; but we are supported by good authority in recommending, that the lady should first
name: Real College Essays

text: practise the trot, as it is certainly much better calculated to strengthen and confirm her
name: Real College Essays

text: in the balance, seat &c. than the canter.
name: Real College Essays

text: The lady is advised, at this stage of her progress, to practise the paces, alternately, in
name: Real College Essays

text: the various combinations of the figures we have described; performing her aids with greater
name: Real College Essays

text: power and accuracy in turning and working in circles, when trotting or cantering, than when
name: Real College Essays

text: walking. She should also perfect herself in her aids, the correspondence, and balance, by alternately
name: Real College Essays

text: increasing and diminishing the speed in each pace, until she attain a perfect mastery over
name: Real College Essays

text: herself and her horse, and can not only make him work in what direction, and at what pace,
name: Real College Essays

text: but, also, at what degree of speed in each pace, she pleases.
name: Real College Essays

text: The horse ought to lead with the right foot: should he strike off with the left, the rider
name: Real College Essays

text: must either check him to a walk, and then make him commence the canter again, or induce him
name: Real College Essays

text: to advance the proper leg by acting on the near rein, pressing his side with the left leg,
name: Real College Essays

text: and touching his right shoulder with the whip. His hind legs should follow the direction of
name: Real College Essays

text: the fore legs, otherwise the pace will be untrue, disunited, and unpleasant, both to horse
name: Real College Essays

text: and rider: therefore, if the horse lead with his near fore leg (unless when cantering to the
name: Real College Essays

text: left--the only case when the near legs should be advanced), or with his near hind leg, except
name: Real College Essays

text: in the case just mentioned--although he may lead with the proper fore leg--the pace is false,
name: Real College Essays

text: and ought to be rectified.
name: Real College Essays

text: THE GALLOP. Any remarks, on our part, with regard to this pace, would, therefore, be all but
name: Real College Essays

text: needless.
name: Real College Essays

text: STOPPING AND BACKING.
name: Real College Essays

text: The lady must learn how to perform the perfect stop in all the paces. The perfect stop in the
name: Real College Essays

text: walk, is a cessation of all action in the animal, produced instantaneously by the rider, without
name: Real College Essays

text: any previous intimation being given by her to the horse. The slovenly stop is gradual and uncertain.
name: Real College Essays

text: The incorrect stop is a momentary and violent check on the action in the middle, instead of
name: Real College Essays

text: the conclusion, of the cadence, while the fore legs are coming to the ground. The proper movements
name: Real College Essays

text: should be performed, by the rider, so that the stop may conclude correctly with the cadence.
name: Real College Essays

text: The firmness of the hand should be increased, the body be thrown back, the reins drawn to the
name: Real College Essays

text: body, and the horse's haunches pressed forward by the leg and whip, so that he may be brought
name: Real College Essays

text: to bear on the bit.
name: Real College Essays

text: The stop in the trot is performed as in the walk: the rider should operate when the advanced
name: Real College Essays

text: limbs of the animal, before and behind, respectively, have come to the ground, so that the
name: Real College Essays

text: stop may be perfected when the other fore leg and hind leg advance and complete the cadence.
name: Real College Essays

text: The stop in the canter is performed by the rider in a similar manner: the time should be at
name: Real College Essays

text: the instant when the horse's fore feet are descending;--the hind feet will immediately follow,
name: Real College Essays

text: and at once conclude the cadence. In an extended canter, it is advisable to reduce the horse
name: Real College Essays

text: to a short trot, prior to stopping him, or to perform the stop by a double arr?t;--that is,
name: Real College Essays

text: in two cadences instead of one.
name: Real College Essays

text: It is necessary that the lady should learn how to make a horse back, in walking: to do this,
name: Real College Essays

text: the reins must be drawn equally and steadily towards the body, and the croup of the horse kept
name: Real College Essays

text: in a proper direction by means of the leg and whip.
name: Real College Essays

text: LEAPING.
name: Real College Essays

text: In riding-schools, ladies who never intend to hunt, are frequently taught to leap the bar.
name: Real College Essays

text: The practice is certainly beneficial; as it tends to confirm the seat, and enables the rider
name: Real College Essays

text: more effectually to preserve her balance, should she ever be mounted on an unsteady or vicious
name: Real College Essays

text: horse.
name: Real College Essays

text: Leaps are taken, either standing or flying, over a bar, which is so contrived as to fall, when
name: Real College Essays

text: touched by the horse's feet, if he do not clear it: it is placed at a short distance from the
name: Real College Essays

text: ground, at first; and raised, by degrees, as the rider improves. The standing leap, which is
name: Real College Essays

text: practised first, the horse takes from the halt, close to the bar. The flying leap is taken
name: Real College Essays

text: from any pace, and is easier than the standing leap, although the latter is considered the
name: Real College Essays

text: safer of the two to begin with; as, from the steadiness with which it is made by a trained
name: Real College Essays

text: horse, the master or assistant can aid the pupil at the slightest appearance of danger.
name: Real College Essays

text: The position of the rider is to be governed in this, as in all other cases, by the action of
name: Real College Essays

text: the horse. No weight is to be borne on the stirrup; for, in fact, pressure on the stirrup will
name: Real College Essays

text: tend to raise the body, rather than keep it close to the saddle. The legs--particularly the
name: Real College Essays

text: right one--must be pressed closely against the saddle, and the reins yielded to the horse,
name: Real College Essays

text: so that the rider can just distinguish a slight correspondence between her own hand and the
name: Real College Essays

text: horse's mouth. The animations thus produced, and the invitation thus given, will make the horse
name: Real College Essays

text: rise. As his fore quarters ascend, the lady is to advance forward; the back being bent inward,
name: Real College Essays

text: and the head kept upright and steady. A moment before the horse's hind legs quit the ground,
name: Real College Essays

text: the body should be inclined backward; the rider taking care not to bear heavily on the reins,
name: Real College Essays

text: lest the horse force her hand, and pull her forward on his neck, or over his head, as he descends.
name: Real College Essays

text: When the leap is cleared, the rider should bring the horse together, if at all disunited, and
name: Real College Essays

text: resume her usual position.
name: Real College Essays

text: In the flying leap, the seat is to be preserved as in the standing leap; except, that it is
name: Real College Essays

text: needless, and, indeed, unwise, to advance the body as the horse rises: because, in the flying
name: Real College Essays

text: leap, the horse's position, especially in a low leap, is more horizontal than when he rises
name: Real College Essays

text: at the bar from a halt; and there is great danger of the rider being thrown, if she lean forward,
name: Real College Essays

text: in case the horse suddenly check himself and refuse the leap; which circumstance occasionally
name: Real College Essays

text: happens. The waist should be brought forward, and the body suffered to take that inclination
name: Real College Essays

text: backward which will be produced by the spring forward of the horse. The horse's head is to
name: Real College Essays

text: be guided towards the bar, and the reins yielded to him as he advances.
name: Real College Essays

text: The proper distance for a horse to run previous to the leap, is from ten to fifteen yards.
name: Real College Essays

text: If he be well trained, he may be suffered to take his own pace; but it is necessary to animate
name: Real College Essays

text: an indolent animal into a short, collected gallop, and urge him, by strong aids, to make the leap.
name: Real College Essays

text: DISMOUNTING.
name: Real College Essays

text: The first operation, preparatory to dismounting, is to bring the horse to an easy, yet perfect,
name: Real College Essays

text: stop. If the lady be light and dexterous, she may dismount without assistance, from a middle-sized
name: Real College Essays

text: horse: but, it is better not to do so if the animal be high.
name: Real College Essays

text: The right hand of the lady, when preparing to dismount, is to receive the reins, and be carried
name: Real College Essays

text: to the off crutch of the saddle. The reins should be held sufficiently tight to restrain the
name: Real College Essays

text: horse from advancing; and yet not so firm as to cause him to back or rear; nor uneven, lest
name: Real College Essays

text: it make him swerve.
name: Real College Essays

text: The lady should next disengage her right leg, clearing the dress as she raises her knee; remove
name: Real College Essays

text: her right hand to the near crutch; and then take her foot from the stirrup.
name: Real College Essays

text: Thus far the process is the same whether the lady dismount with or without assistance.
name: Real College Essays

text: If the lady be assisted, the gentleman, or groom, may either lift her completely off the saddle
name: Real College Essays

text: to the ground; or, taking her left hand in his left hand, place his right hand on her waist,
name: Real College Essays

text: and, as she springs off, support her in her descent. She may also alight, if she be tolerably
name: Real College Essays

text: active, by placing her right hand in that of the gentleman (who, in this case, must stand at
name: Real College Essays

text: the horse's shoulder), and descend without any other support. Should there be any objection
name: Real College Essays

text: to, or difficulty found in alighting by either of these modes, the gentleman, or groom, may
name: Real College Essays

text: place himself immediately in front of the lady, who is then to incline sufficiently forward
name: Real College Essays

text: for him to receive her weight, by placing his hands under her arms, and thus easing her descent.
name: Real College Essays

text: If the lady dismount without assistance, after the hand is carried from the off to the near
name: Real College Essays

text: crutch, she must turn round so as to be able to take, in her left hand, a lock of the horse's
name: Real College Essays

text: mane; by the aid of which, and by bearing her right hand on the crutch, she may alight without
name: Real College Essays

text: difficulty. In dismounting thus, without assistance, she must turn as she quits the saddle,
name: Real College Essays

text: so as to descend with her face towards the horse's side.
name: Real College Essays

text: By whatever mode the lady dismounts, but especially if she do so without assistance, she should--to
name: Real College Essays

text: prevent any unpleasant shock on reaching the ground--bend her knees, suffer her body to be
name: Real College Essays

text: perfectly pliant, and alight on her toes, or the middle of her feet. She is neither to relinquish
name: Real College Essays

text: her hold, nor is the gentleman, or groom, if she make use of his ministry, to withdraw his
name: Real College Essays

text: hand, until she is perfectly safe on the ground.
name: Real College Essays

text: In order to dismount with grace and facility, more practice is required than that of merely
name: Real College Essays

text: descending from the saddle after an exercise or a ride. It is advisable to mount and dismount,
name: Real College Essays

text: for some days, several times, successively, either before or after the ride;--commencing with
name: Real College Essays

text: the most simple modes, until a sufficient degree of confidence and experience is acquired to
name: Real College Essays

text: perform either of these operations in a proper manner, with the mere aid of the assistant's hand.
name: Real College Essays

text: CONCLUDING REMARKS.
name: Real College Essays

text: The lady should perform her first lessons with a snaffle bridle, holding the reins in both
name: Real College Essays

text: hands, and without a stirrup. When she has acquired some degree of practice in the balance,
name: Real College Essays

text: aids, and general government of the horse, she may use a bridle with double reins, and hold
name: Real College Essays

text: them in the left hand, managing them as we have directed in some of the preceding pages.
name: Real College Essays

text: If the lady be but in her noviciate in the art, we strongly advise her not to place too much
name: Real College Essays

text: reliance on her own expertness, or to attempt too much at first; but, rather, to proceed steadily,
name: Real College Essays

text: and be satisfied with a gradual improvement; as it is utterly impossible to acquire perfection
name: Real College Essays

text: in the nicer operations of riding, before the minor difficulties are overcome.
name: Real College Essays

text: The lady, in all cases, should recollect that her horse requires occasional haltings and relaxation.
name: Real College Essays

text: The time occupied in each lesson should be in proportion to the pace and animation in which
name: Real College Essays

text: it has been performed. If the exercise be varied and highly animated, the horse should rest
name: Real College Essays

text: to recruit himself at the expiration of twelve or fifteen minutes; when refreshed, by halting,
name: Real College Essays

text: he may be made to go through another of the same, or rather less duration, and then be put
name: Real College Essays

text: up for the day. It would be still better to make two halts in the same space of time;--the
name: Real College Essays

text: exercise taken in such a lesson being equal to three hours' moderate work. When the lessons
name: Real College Essays

text: are less animated, they may be made proportionally longer; but, it is always better, if the
name: Real College Essays

text: pupil err in this respect, to do so on the side of brevity, than, by making her lessons too
name: Real College Essays

text: long, to harass her horse.
name: Real College Essays

text: WHITEHEAD AND COMP^Y. PRINTERS, 76, FLEET STREET, LONDON.
name: Real College Essays

text: We now entered upon what turned out to be one of the most interesting periods in the history
name: Real College Essays

text: of the Battalion. The idea at the moment was that the 46th Division should take part in an
name: Real College Essays

text: early offensive against Beaurains, just south of Arras, and the immediate purpose of our relief
name: Real College Essays

text: was to withdraw to the Sus-St. Leger area and dig a model of the front to be attacked, ready
name: Real College Essays

text: for one of the other Brigades of the Division to practise over. With this object we moved back
name: Real College Essays

text: on February 20th, to Ivergny, where we spent the first few days refitting and reorganising.
name: Real College Essays

text: The latter was now becoming of great moment, for important changes were taking place. To begin
name: Real College Essays

text: with the Battalion Grenade Platoon, that picked body of specially trained Bombers, to which
name: Real College Essays

text: it was everyone's ambition to belong, ceased to exist, and the personnel rejoined their Companies,
name: Real College Essays

text: in which from this time onward each platoon had its own section of Bombers. This was only a
name: Real College Essays

text: preliminary to the absolute reorganisation of the platoon, which was now rightly coming into
name: Real College Essays

text: its own, and regarded as the most important tactical fighting unit. We had already been lectured
name: Real College Essays

text: at Souastre by Lieut.-General Sir Ivor Maxse, our Corps Commander, and later Director General
name: Real College Essays

text: of Training, also by Major-General Thwaites, on the new organisation of the platoon, which
name: Real College Essays

text: was now to consist of four specialist sections: (1) Riflemen, (2) Bombers, (3) Rifle Grenadiers,
name: Real College Essays

text: (4) Lewis Gunners. We now began the preliminaries of this new organisation, which was to remain
name: Real College Essays

text: practically unchanged for the rest of the war. The Signallers were also reorganised under Lieut.
name: Real College Essays

text: Warner, and divided into "Battalion" and "Company" Signallers.
name: Real College Essays
